Features:

The hologram fused to the back of the NGC holder is slightly damaged in the area displaying the QR code, making the QR code unreadable.

Relatively rare in this condition
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 09h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Gold
Year: 1262 (AH 661 on the coin) Fineness: 958
Country: Mamlūk Sultanate Weight (g): Measured: 7.4; Expected: -
Issuer: Mamlūk Sultanate Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 24; Expected: -
Unit: Dinar Thickness (mm): -
Mint: al-Qāhirah (القاهرة) Mintage:
Mint mark: القاهرة Emission period: AH 658-676
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS62 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Balog#36; Album#880; Fr#5; ICV1#959
Varieties:

None
Note:

The early centre of the Fāṭimid Caliphate, which controlled, at various times, much of the Islamic world from Morocco to Syria, was situated in that part of North Africa which had been ruled by the Aghlabid Emirate (800-909). Therefore, it was natural that the earliest Fatimid coinage resembled that of the Aghlabids in style, fabric and appearance. Only the date, mint and inscriptions differentiated the coins of the Fāṭimids from the issues of their predecessors. It is likely that Aghlabid and Fāṭimid coins circulated together during the first decades of the new regime in Ifriqīyah and Sicily, that is, until enough of the older coinage had been melted and reminted in the Fāṭimid model that the latter would predominate in circulation.

The coinage issues of individual caliphs are surprisingly quite varied and distinctively different given that the Fāṭimid Caliphate's rule lasted for 260-odd years. The coins of the Fāṭimids fall into two main categories: the gold dinar and its fractions and the silver dirham and its fractions and multiples. Within these two categories, the dinar itself and the half dirham are the two denominations that have survived to the present day in rather large quantities. Some denominations were peculiar to certain geographical areas, whereas others were common to all parts of the Fāṭimid realm. The dinar was the standard gold coin in use throughout the Fatimid Empire, except in Sicily, where the quarter dinar predominated. The half dirham, common throughout North Africa and Egypt, was almost unknown in Sicily, which had a variety of silver fractions in use throughout the island. The half dirham was also not common in Syria and Palestine, but full dirhams and even silver coins of approximately two dirhams weight are not unknown, although one hesitates to call the latter "double dirhams." Billon coinage was produced by a number of Palestinian mints and are known in a wide range of weights, but were probably all generically called dishams. The silver issues of the later Fāṭimid caliphs, almost exclusively struck in Egypt were the small, irregularly-shaped black dirhams, the production of which was continued by the Ayyūbid Sultanate of Egypt (1171-1260). A very few copper or bronze coins have been encountered. Some of these exhibit traces of a silver wash, which indicated that they were not considered to be copper coins as such, but rather small change in the dirham series.

Fāṭimid coinage, and particularly gold coinage, played an important part in the economy of North Africa and the Middle East during the period of the Fāṭimid Caliphate. Indeed, the Fāṭimid dinar had a wider impact throughout the Mediterranean world because of the reputation the regime's coinage carried with it far beyond the borders of the empire. Fāṭimid gold coins were struck to a high standard of fineness and this standard was generally maintained during most of the time the Fāṭimid Caliphate was in power. In the Syrian and Palestinian territories, the dinar was frequently struck to a lighter standard, especially in the later years of the Fāṭimid Caliphate.
Historical notes:

al-Ẓāhir (li-I'zāz Dīn Allāh) (الظاهر لإعزاز دين الله) (born on 10 Ramadān AH 395 (20 June 1005); proclaimed caliph on 10 Dhū al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021); died on 15 Sha'bān AH 427 (13 June 1036))

(To the right) Photograph of the al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo, Egypt, taken by an anonym in 2018. The Fāṭimid Caliphate conquered Egypt and founded Cairo (al-Qāhira) in AH 358 (969). The mosque was established in AH 361 (972) and the capital of the Fāṭimid Caliphate moved from al-Manṣūrīyah to Cairo in AH 362 (972-973).

Some time passed after the disappearance of his predecessor al-Ḥākim on 27 Shawwāl AH 411 (13 February 1021) before al-Ẓāhir was proclaimed caliph on 10 Dhū al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021). The Fāṭimid regime was fairly stable during the first few years of al-Ẓāhir's caliphate, but this situation did not last very long. By 414-415 AH (1024-1025), the wasteful extravagances of al-Ḥākim's rule began to take a toll on the health of the empire. A financial crisis ensued in which the cash reserves of the treasury were depleted. The army remained unpaid for an overly long period, then riots in Cairo and the provinces broke out, al-Ẓāhir lost control of his government and a ruling clique came to be in charge in the capital. This was followed by first drought and then famine in Egypt during AH 415 (1024-1025).

Despite his political incompetence and a life given over to the pursuit of pleasure, al-Ẓāhir was able to weather the political storm and on 16 Jumādā II AH 420 (2 July 1029), his heir, Abū Tamīm Ma'add, who was destined to become the Caliph al-Mustanṣir, was born.

Trouble did not long stay away from al-Ẓāhir, however. His military commanders exercised almost independent control and in AH 421 (1030), attacks by the army on the populace in North Africa diminished support for the caliph. A powerful earthquake caused massive destruction in Palestine and al-Ẓāhir spent massive sums to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem during the years AH 421-424 (1030-1033). Famine once again visited North Africa in AH 425 (1034) and in the midst of all these problems, al-Ẓāhir died some two years later, just under thirty-two years of age.

 -

+ AD 1252 - England - Penny - Henry III:

Open description in new window
Period: Middle Ages; Kingdom of England (927-1649); House of Plantagenet (1154-1399)
Ruler: Henry III (1216-1272)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Large round portrait of Henry III, surrounded by an inner beaded border, facing, with round eyes formed by a pellet in a circle, small crescents in field between and below hair curls (depicted by pellet-in-crescent motifs), crowned with a large and well defined fleur as a central ornament atop the crown and pellets at crown ends, holding a sceptre in the right hand
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 10h) hE(ligature NR)ICVS REX III
Traduction: King Henry III
Designer: -

Director: Nicole (1247-circa 1270)

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Voided long cross pommée with a pellet at the centre and a trefoil in each quadrant, surrounded by an inner beaded border
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h, in each of the four quadrants) NIC (1st quadrant; first half of the director's name) oLE (2nd quadrant; second half of the director's name) (ligature oN)C (4th quadrant) (ligature aN)T (3rd quadrant)
Traduction: Nicole of Canterbury
Designer: -

Director: Nicole (1247-circa 1270)

Engraver: -
Features:

Total NGC (PCGS) Census: 47 (-)
NGC (PCGS) Census in this grade: 14 (-)
NGC (PCGS) Census in higher grade: 13 (-)
NGC (PCGS) Top Pop: 2 MS62, 1 MS61 (-)
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 07h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 1252 (not dated) Fineness: 925
Country: England Weight (g): Measured: 1.37; Expected: 1.48
Issuer: England Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Penny (1158-1970) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Canterbury Mintage:
Mint mark: ONC ANT Emission period: 1250-1272
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: AU55 (NGC) Variety: Class 5a2
References: S1#1367A; North1#991/2; CT#C232
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the letter X has either straight limbs (Class 5a2) or one straight limb and one S-shaped limb (Class 5a3).

This coin is classified as "Long Cross" type (1250-1279), Phase III (1250-1272, post-provincial phase), Class 5a2 (1251-circa 1253).
Note:

By the middle of Henry III's reign the "Short Cross" coinage in circulation was in a poor state and, in 1247, a new "Long Cross" coinage was ordered with the cross on the reverse being extended to the edge of the coin in an attempt to prevent clipping. The earliest coins (Class 1a) showed the name of neither the mint nor the moneyer. Class 1b includes the name of the mint. From Class 2 onwards all coins show the name of both the mint and the moneyer.

Following publication of the 1908 Brussels Hoard by Churchill and Thomas (2012) the classification of the "Long Cross" coinage was revised. This divided the "Long Cross" coinage into four phases: Phase I (1247, pre-provincial), Phase II (1248-1250, provincial, when sixteen provincial mints, in addition to the main mints of London and Canterbury plus Bury St Edmunds were opened to facilitate the production and distribution of the new coins), Phase III (1250-1272, post-provincial, in which the mint of Durham re-opened, operating intermittently), and Phase IV (1272-1280, posthumous, when the "Long Cross" coinage was continued in the name of Henry III through the first seven years of the reign of Edward I).

In Phases I and II the obverse features the Henry III's head without a sceptre (Classes 1-3) but during Phase III the sceptre was re-introduced (Class 4 onwards). No round hald-pennies ir farthings were struck during the "Long Cross" coinage but cut halves and quarters were used in considerable numbers.

Mint marks features in all coins from Class 1 to 4 and are an important aid to both chronology and identification. Five main varieties of mint mark exist, all in the shape of a star.
Historical notes:

Henry III (born on 1st Octobre 1207 in Winchester; accession on 28 Octobre 1216; died on 16 Novembre 1272)

(To the right) Illustration of the coronation of Henry III, accompanied by a short account of his reign in Anglo-Norman prose, from the recto of the parchment folio f.6 (referred to as f.6r) of the work "Cotton MS Vitellius A XIII", created circa 1280-circa 1300 and conserved at the British Library in London. It is part of a collection of four folios representing the kings of England from Edward the Confessor (r. 1042–1066) to Edward I (r. 1272–1307). These folios were extracted in 1939 from a manuscript that was damaged in the fire of Ashburnham House, which was the repository of the Cotton Library, on 23 October 1731, and are now mounted in separate glass frames. In this folio, Henri III is crowned by two accompanying bishops, He is represented as holding in his hand a model of Westminster Abbey, which he enlarged, laying the first stone himself; and caused to be there erected the magnificent monument of Edward the Confessor. It was very common with the illuminators, to make the principal figure holding a model of the abbey, or monastery, they were benefactors to. The author gives a rudimentary description of his reign: "Apres Jon regna Henry le Terz, sun fiz, Ivi aunz ; se fust de ix aunz de age quant fust corone. E en sun tens fust la bataylle de Eveshame, ou fust occys syr Syraund de Munfort, e sun fiz Henry ; e syre Hugh le Despenser, e muz des Barons e des Chevalers de Engletere – Puis morust cyl Henry le Roy, e gyst a Westminster.", which can be translated in English as "After John, reigned Henry the Third, his son, 56 years; he was nine years of age when he was crowned. In his time was the battle of Evesham, where was slain Sir Simon de Mountfort, and his son Henry; and Sir Hugh le Despenser, and many barons and knights of England. – After died this Henry the king, and lies [buried] at Westminster.”

Henry III, King John's son, was only nine when he became king. By 1227, when he assumed power from his regent, order had been restored, based on his acceptance of Magna Carta. However, the king's failed campaigns in France (1230 and 1242), his choice of friends and advisers, together with the cost of his scheme to make one of his younger sons, Edmund, King of Sicily and help the Pope against the Holy Roman Emperor, led to further disputes with the barons and united opposition in Church and State.

Although Henry was extravagant and his tax demands were resented, the king's accounts show a list of many charitable donations and payments for building works (including the rebuilding of Westminster Abbey which began in 1245).

The Provisions of Oxford (1258) and the Provisions of Westminster (1259) were attempts by the nobles to define common law in the spirit of Magna Carta, control appointments and set up an aristocratic council. Henry tried to defeat them by obtaining papal absolution from his oaths, and enlisting the help of King Louis IX (saint Louis) of France. Henry renounced the Provisions in 1262 and war broke out. The barons, under their leader, Simon de Montfort, were initially successful and even captured Henry. However, Henry escaped, joined forces with the lords of the Marches (on the Welsh border), and finally defeated and killed de Montfort at the Battle of Evesham in 1265. Royal authority was restored by the Statute of Marlborough (1267), in which the king also promised to uphold Magna Carta and some of the Provisions of Westminster.

Henry died in 1272 and his tomb is in Westminster Abbey, in front of the Church's High Altar, the former resting place of Edward the Confessor, who his son Edward I was named after.

+ AD 1178 - Royaume de France - Denier - Chapitre ou Évêché de Clermont (Anonyme):

Open description in new window
Period: Moyen Âge ; Royaume de France (987-1792) ; Maison de Capet (987-1328)
Ruler: Robert II, dit « le Pieux » (996-1031)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: (starting at 9h) Lettres V, R, B et S disposées en forme de croix, entourée d'un grènetis intérieur, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (entre les grènetis intérieur et extérieur) ✠·arVerNa·
Traduction: Urbs Arverna (Ville de Clermont)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Croix pattée à bras rectilignes, entourée d'un grènetis intérieur, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (entre les grènetis intérieur et extérieur) ✠S(ligature ct)a·Maria
Traduction: Sancta Maria (Sainte Marie)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was sent to NGC for grading. Despite some minor environmental damage in the form of a few spots of green residue on the surface of both the obverse and reverse, the grade that I expected it would receive was XF45. The grade that it received was AU55, which exceeded my expectation. The emission period attributed by NGC to this coin type is 1200-1300 instead of 1030-1099. I have not found the reference(s) that NGC may have used to make this attribution. To reflect the uncertainty in the emission period, I have assigned the year 1178 to this coin type.

Cette pièce me fait penser à la période où j'habitais rue du Port à Clermont-Ferrand, laquelle fut une des plus riches de ma vie. 🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 08h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 1178 (not dated) Fineness: 500
Country: Royaume de France Weight (g): Measured: 1.06; Expected: 1.17
Issuer: Chapitre ou Évêché de Clermont Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 20.5
Unit: Denier tournois (987-1795) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Clermont-Ferrand Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1030-1099
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: AU55 (NGC) Variety: Sans cantonnement
References: PA1#2241; DyFeo1#825; Boudeau#377; Roberts#4158
Varieties:

Il existe plusieurs variétés: de grand module, sans ponctuation à l'avers et au revers, avec la croix au revers sans cantonnement (DyFeo1#824), et de module de taille normale, avec ponctuation à l'avers et avec (DyFeo1#825 et DyFeo1#828) ou sans (DyFeo1#826 et DyFeo1#827) ponctuation au revers, avec la croix au revers sans cantonnement (DyFeo1#825) ou cantonnée d'un V au 1er canton et (DyFeo1#826), d'un V aux 2ème et 3ème cantons (DyFeo1#827) et d'un besant divergeant du centre aux 1er et 4ème cantons (DyFeo1#828). Cette dernière variété (DyFeo1#828) a également les lettres R et B du motif en forme de croix au centre de l'avers inversées.
Note:

Le comté d'Auvergne, fief du duché d'Aquitaine, entre dans la maison de Toulouse en 928, puis dans celle de Poitiers en 950. Mais la maison de Poitiers ne le garda pas longtemps. En effet, Guillaume Taillefer, comte de Toulouse, en lutte avec cette dernière, s’empare du comté d'Auvergne à la mort du comte de Poitiers (qui était aussi comte d'Auvergne), Guillaume Tête d'Etoupe, en 963. En 979, il investit Guy Ier, vicomte de Clermont des comtés d’Auvergne et de Velay. La vacance laissée par le dernier comte d’Auvergne (Guillaume Tête d'Etoupe), a très probablement incité le vicomte Guy Ier à se proclamer par la suite comte d'Auvergne. A partir de ce moment l'histoire de l'Auvergne se résume dans une lutte obscure et continuelle dont la suzeraineté de la province, que se disputent les ducs d'Aquitaine et les rois de France, est l'enjeu.

Bien avant la fin de la dynastie Carolingienne, les comtes d'Auvergne usurpèrent les droits régaliens et battirent monnaie. La frappe des deniers au monogramme carolingien a été quelque temps continuée par les comtes d’Auvergne, mais ils n’ont pas tardé à altérer le monogramme carolingien et à substituer leur nom propre au nom royal. Cette pratique pris fin lorsque, en 1030, Guillaume V céda au chapitre de Notre-Dame de Clermont sa monnaie avec ses monnayeurs. Plus tard, le privilège devint commun entre le chapitre et l'évêque ; cependant, des textes ultérieurs prouvent que le comte avait gardé une certaine suprématie sur la monnaie de Clermont et peut-être une part des profits.

Le chapitre ou les évêques de Clermont ne paraissent pas avoir eu un monnayage antérieur. Le premier type, avec les lettres V, R, B et S disposées en forme de croix, est du XIème siècle et, au lieu de Claromont, on reprend la légende Urbs Arverna. D'où vient le type adopté par le chapitre de Clermont ? A-t-il voulu copier, en le défigurant, le monogramme carolingien ? C'est ce qu'il est difficile d'établir, en l'absence des monnaies intermédiaires. Peut-être aussi, pour ce monnayage tout nouveau, a-t-on créé un nouveau type. Au XIIème siècle, nous trouvons un changement radical dans le type des monnaies sur lesquelles nous voyons paraitre la tête de face de la Vierge. L'influence des évêques dut être fort probablement la cause de ce changement de type.

En 1269, l'évêque avait émis une monnaie plus faible de 1/5 que l'ancienne ; sur la plainte d'Alphonse de Poitiers, son frère Louis IX (saint Louis) intervint. En 1295, Philippe IV le Bel délivre à l'évêque et au chapitre une lettre de non-préjudice à l'occasion du monnayage royal de Montferrand. Le denier de Clermont est encore mentionné en 1315 (13 pour 12 denier tournois), mais c'était la fin de la monnaie frappée à Clermont, et plus généralement de la plupart des monnaies seigneuriales (laïques et ecclésiastiques). Cependant, jusqu'en 1360, l'évêque, en prenant possession de sa charge, prêtait serment auprès du souverain de ne rien changer à la monnaie. Celle-ci était en réalité devenue théorique.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Clocher de la Basilique Notre-Dame-du-Port de Clermont-Ferrand, dessiné par Charles-Justin Le Cœur (1830-1906) entre 1868 et 1882

La basilique Notre-Dame-du-Port de Clermont-Ferrand est une église collégiale française de style roman auvergnat, située dans le centre historique de Clermont-Ferrand, au cœur du quartier du Port, entre la place Delille et la cathédrale Notre-Dame de l’Assomption de Clermont. Classée monument historique de France sur la première liste de 1840, elle a été inscrite en 1998 sur la « Liste du patrimoine mondiale » de l'United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) au titre des « Chemins de Saint-Jacques-de-Compostelle en France ». Sa dénomination proviendrait du nom du quartier où elle a été construite, « le Port », en occitan « Lo Pòrt », dérivant lui-même du latin "portus", et qui signifient tous deux « l'entrepôt ». C'était l'endroit où l'on apportait et stockait les marchandises. En auvergnat, on disait Nòstra-Dama dóu-Pòrt. Dans les parlers plus méridionaux se trouve la forme Nòstra Dòna del Pòrt. L'ancienne Porte Royale qui se situait en bas de l'actuelle rue du Port, était le lieu par lequel arrivaient les marchandises dans la ville, ce qui confirme le rôle de passage et d'échange de l'endroit. Néanmoins, « le Port » n'est pas attesté dans les écrits anciens avant 1065. L'église a d'abord porté le nom de « Sainte-Marie Principale », ce qui la distinguait de la cathédrale nommée « Sainte-Marie » et de l'abbaye de Saint-Alyre nommée « Sainte-Marie-d'Entre-Saints ».

+ AD 1128 - India - Gajapati pagoda - Gangas of Talakad (Anonymous):

Open description in new window
Period:
Ruler: Romanos IV Diogenes (1068-1071)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: The three co-emperor stepsons of Romanos IV, all wearing a loros with a loros-waist and a crown with cross and pendilia, standing facing on a single dais represented as a dotted exergual band, the field surrounded by a double grènetis: in the centre, Michael, large, holding a labarum-headed sceptre in the right hand and an akakia in the left hand; to the left and the right, Konstantios and Andronikos, respectively, holding a globus cruciger in the outer hand and an akakia in the inner hand
Script: Greek
Lettering: (starting at 08h) KѠN MX ANΔ
Traduction: Konstantios, Michael and Andronikos
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: In the centre, Christ, large, nimbate, wearing a tunic and a himation, standing facing on a square footstool, crowing: to the left Romanos IV, wearing a loros, a sakkos, and a crown with cross and pendilia; to the right, Eudokia, wearing a loros, a kite-shaped panel, and a crown with pinnacles and pendilia; both standing facing, holding the outer hand on the breast and a globus cruciger in the inner hand and the inner hand on the breast; with divided inscription I̅C̅ X̅C̅ (Jesus Christ; partly abbreviated form of the Greek "᾽Ιησου̑ς Ξριστὸς"), across the field on the sides of Christ's head; the field surrounded by a double grènetis
Script: Greek
Lettering: +IѠMA CVΔKIA
Traduction: Romanos and Eudokia
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin makes me think of my children Léonie and Louis. 🦛🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Gold
Year: 1128 (not dated) Fineness: 667
Country: India Weight (g): Measured: 4.4; Expected: 4.55
Issuer: Gangas of Talakad Shape: Concave (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 27
Unit: Second Solidus Nomisma ("Reform" of Leo III; 720-1092) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Cōnstantīnopolis Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1068-1071
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS61 (NGC) Variety: Without footstools
References: BCV#1861; DOC3_2#2; Fr#261
Varieties:

There are three varieties, for which the three co-emperor stepsons of Romanos IV are standing on footstools set on a single dais represented as a dotted exergual band (BCV#1860 and DOC3_2#2) or without the single dais (BCV#1859 and DOC3_2#1) or without the footstools (BCV#1861).
Note:

The twin pivots of the Byzantine monetary system in the 5th and 6th centuries had been the gold solidus or nomisma and the copper nummus. The gold solidus was a coin struck 72 to the Roman pound and consequently weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. The nummus, sometimes called by contemporaries a denarius, was a small coin of varying weight, usually about 1 g or a little less. It has then been reckoned as 1/7200 of the solidus, but its value in fact varied and seems frequently to have fallen to a much lower figure. The gap between the solidus and the nummus was bridged in part by real coins (the gold semissis and tremissis, fractions of the solidus, and the copper pentanummium, decanummium, half follis, and follis, multiples of the nummus), in part by a money of account, the keration, and in part by the miliaresion, which was sometimes one and sometimes the other.

Treating them in descending order of value, the semissis and tremissis require no discussion. They were actual coins, worth one-half and one-third of a solidus, respectively. Miliaresion was a Greek loan word from the Latin "miliarense", a term applied to a silver coin current in the 4th century from the period of the Tetrarchy onward. In the 6th century, when no silver coinage was being struck for regular circulation in the East, it had become the generic name for any silver coin at all, being applied indifferently to the Roman denarius and to the Persian dirham. When the hexagram was created by the Byzantine emperor Heraclius (r. 610–641) this was known as the silver coin of six grammata, and when the hexagram ceased to be struck the term remained available for application to whatever silver coin would take its place.

The keration was not a coin, but primarily a unit of weight, 1/1728 of the Roman pound, 1/144 of the Roman ounce, or about 0.189 g in modern terms. Since the solidus was one-sixth of a Roman ounce, the solidus weighed 24 keratia. Consequently, as a money of account, the keration was 1/24 of the Roman solidus, a relationship that lasted throughout the whole of the Byzantine Empire's history. Keratia are omnipresent in Byzantine monetary reckonings, but they are always notional. A debt expressed in solidi, keratia, and fractions of keratia would be paid in solidi, miliaresia, folles, and such fractions of these as were in circulation at the time.

The follis, sometimes called the obol, reintroduced in 498 with the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Anastasius I Dicorus (r. 491-518), was a copper coin worth forty nummi. Various fractions were struck during the 6th and 7th centuries, the half follis, decanummium, and pentanummium being the most important. In the mid 6th century the follis was reckoned 180 to the solidus. How the relationships between the solidus, keration, follis and nummus were affected by the "debasement" of the follis in the later 6th and 7th centuries – the gradual reduction of its weight to less than one-sixth of what it had been in the peak years of Justinian I's reign (527-565) – is a question to which there is not yet any answer. The nummus disappeared completely as a coin, but since the follis and its fractions still bore marks of value expressed as multiples of nummi, these were presumably still thought of as the lowest units in the monetary system.

This monetary system was not as unified in the three and a half centuries between the accession of the Byzantine emperor Leo III (r. 717-741) in 717, marking the end of the "Twenty Years' Anarchy" (695-717), and the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Alexios I Komnenos (r. 1081-1118) in 1092, following his accession in 1081, marking the end of a prolonged period of civil war resulting from the defeat to the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The silver miliaresion introduced by Leo III in 720 and continued by his successors provided a certain element of unity nonetheless. The essential features of the monetary system during this period may be summarized as follows:

Gold coinage – In the East, the semissis and tremissis ceased to be struck, save as ceremonial coins, toward the middle of the 8th century. Henceforward the only gold coin was the solidus. Its fineness remained virtually unchanged down to the 1030's, when debasement set in, and while its weight seems ot have declined very slightly the coin remained one theoretically struck 72 to the Roman pound. In the reign of Nikephoros II Phokas (r. 963-969), however, there began a series of experiments in light-weight nomismata comparable to the light-weight solidi of the 6th and 7th centuries. Of these the light-weight nomisma of 22 keratia, known as a tetarteron, finally gained the day, so that from the late 10th century down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092 one has to distinguish between the full-weight nomisma histamenon and the light-weight nomisma tetarteron.

Things went differently in the West. The solidus and tremissis continued to be struck in mainland Italy as long as the mints of Ravenna and Rome remained in Byzantine hands, i.e., to the mid and late 8th century, respectively. In Sicily they continued down to the reign of Basil I (r. 867-886), and there was even a revival of the use of the semissis in the early 9th century. The weight standard of the western gold coins, however, was substantially less than that of their eastern counterparts, and both on the mainland and in Sicily there was a serious reduction in fineness during the last decades of Byzantine rule. The fate of the fractional gold was related inversely to the presence or absence of a silver coinage, since the miliaresion flourished in the East but was not adopted in the West.

Silver coinage – The history of the silver coinage is that of a new miliaresion, a coin much lighter than the hexagram of the 7th century, which was introduced by Leo III in 720. It lasted, with remarkably few changes in external appearance, down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092. The weight, however, was several times altered, and in its final phase it was badly debased in both weight and fineness. Fractions were struck only under Leo III, of whose half miliaresion specimens are known, and in the middle of the 11th century. Over much of the period the miliaresion was valued as a double keration, i.e., as a coin worth 1/12 of a solidus, so that sums of money are as commonly expressed in terms of nomismata and miliaresia as of nomismata and keratia. But when this ratio became fixed, or how the value of the actual coins changed, in relation to the debased nomisma, during the last decades of their existence, are not known exactly.

Copper Coinage – The evolution of the copper resembled that of the gold in that both underwent a process of drastic simplification and differed from it in that the weight of the follis altered greatly over the centuries.
Historical notes:

Romanos IV (Diogenes) (born circa 1030; crown emperor on 1st January 1068; died in 1072)

(To the right) Photograph of the Grand Çamlıca Mosque in Istanbul, Turkey, taken by an anonym in 2021. The landmark complex was completed in 2019. The mosque has six minarets, which represent the six articles of Islamic faith (iman). Four of the minarets, centred around the central dome, feature three balconies that stand 107.1-metre high in recognition of the victory of the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The other two minarets, on the outer ends of the mosque, feature two balconies and are 90-metre high.

The final act of Constantine X (Doukas) before he died in 1067 was to demand that only his two sons he had elevated to co-emperors, Michael and Konstantios, succeed him, thereby forcing his wife Eudokia (Makrembolitissa) to take a vow not to remarry. Michael was about 17-year old while Konstantios was about 7-year old at the time. Since they were too young to rule, Eudokia ruled as regent until 1st January 1068, when she married Romanos IV (Diogenes) and crowned him emperor. Romanos IV was now the senior emperor and guardian of his stepsons Michael, Konstantios, and Andronikos who he also elevated to co-emperor. However, his accession to the throne had antagonised not only the Doukas family, in particular Constantine X (Doukas)'s brother John Doukas who led the opposition of the palace officials to Romanos IV (Diogenes) authority, but also the Varangian Guard, who openly expressed their discontent at the marriage of Eudokia. Romanos IV (Diogenes) therefore decided that he could only exercise his authority by placing himself at the head of the army in the field, thereby focusing the whole government's attention on the war against the Seljuk Turks.

By 1067, the Seljuk Turks had been making incursions at will across the eastern border of the Byzantine Empire. In 1068, the new emperor immediately set about trying to defend Asia Minor against the advance of the Seljuk Turks. He was confident of Byzantine superiority on the field of battle, looking on the Seljuk Turks as little more than hordes of robbers who would melt away at the first encounter. He did not take into account the degraded state of the Byzantine army, which had suffered years of neglect from his predecessors, in particular Constantine X (Doukas). With an army composed mainly of ill-disciplined, disorganised, and uncoordinated foreign mercenaries he achieved some initial success, but at the famous battle of Mantzikert in 1071 the Seljuk Turks won a devastating victory and Romanus IV (Diogenes) himself was taken prisoner. The opposition party in Constantinople took the opportunity to depose the unfortunate emperor and re-establish Eudokia on the throne together with her eldest son Michael VII (Dukas).

 -

+ AD 1068 - Byzantine Empire - Histamenon nomisma - Romanos IV Diogenes:

Open description in new window
Period: Middle Ages; Byzantine Empire (395-1453); Doukid dynasty (1059-1081)

Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: The three co-emperor stepsons of Romanos IV, all wearing a loros with a loros-waist and a crown with cross and pendilia, standing facing on a single dais represented as a dotted exergual band, the field surrounded by a double grènetis: in the centre, Michael, large, holding a labarum-headed sceptre in the right hand and an akakia in the left hand; to the left and the right, Konstantios and Andronikos, respectively, holding a globus cruciger in the outer hand and an akakia in the inner hand
Script: Greek
Lettering: (starting at 08h) KѠN MX ANΔ
Traduction: Konstantios, Michael and Andronikos
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: In the centre, Christ, large, nimbate, wearing a tunic and a himation, standing facing on a square footstool, crowing: to the left Romanos IV, wearing a loros, a sakkos, and a crown with cross and pendilia; to the right, Eudokia, wearing a loros, a kite-shaped panel, and a crown with pinnacles and pendilia; both standing facing, holding the outer hand on the breast and a globus cruciger in the inner hand and the inner hand on the breast; with divided inscription I̅C̅ X̅C̅ (Jesus Christ; partly abbreviated form of the Greek "᾽Ιησου̑ς Ξριστὸς"), across the field on the sides of Christ's head; the field surrounded by a double grènetis
Script: Greek
Lettering: +IѠMA CVΔKIA
Traduction: Romanos and Eudokia
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

Relatively rare in this condition
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Gold
Year: 1068 (not dated) Fineness: 667
Country: Byzantine Empire Weight (g): Measured: 4.4; Expected: 4.55
Issuer: Byzantine Empire Shape: Concave (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 27
Unit: Second Solidus Nomisma ("Reform" of Leo III; 720-1092) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Cōnstantīnopolis Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1068-1071
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients MS; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Without footstools
References: BCV#1861; DOC3_2#2; Fr#261
Varieties:

There are three varieties, for which the three co-emperor stepsons of Romanos IV are standing on footstools set on a single dais represented as a dotted exergual band (BCV#1860 and DOC3_2#2) or without the single dais (BCV#1859 and DOC3_2#1) or without the footstools (BCV#1861).
Note:

The twin pivots of the Byzantine monetary system in the 5th and 6th centuries had been the gold solidus or nomisma and the copper nummus. The gold solidus was a coin struck 72 to the Roman pound and consequently weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. The nummus, sometimes called by contemporaries a denarius, was a small coin of varying weight, usually about 1 g or a little less. It has then been reckoned as 1/7200 of the solidus, but its value in fact varied and seems frequently to have fallen to a much lower figure. The gap between the solidus and the nummus was bridged in part by real coins (the gold semissis and tremissis, fractions of the solidus, and the copper pentanummium, decanummium, half follis, and follis, multiples of the nummus), in part by a money of account, the keration, and in part by the miliaresion, which was sometimes one and sometimes the other.

Treating them in descending order of value, the semissis and tremissis require no discussion. They were actual coins, worth one-half and one-third of a solidus, respectively. Miliaresion was a Greek loan word from the Latin "miliarense", a term applied to a silver coin current in the 4th century from the period of the Tetrarchy onward. In the 6th century, when no silver coinage was being struck for regular circulation in the East, it had become the generic name for any silver coin at all, being applied indifferently to the Roman denarius and to the Persian dirham. When the hexagram was created by the Byzantine emperor Heraclius (r. 610–641) this was known as the silver coin of six grammata, and when the hexagram ceased to be struck the term remained available for application to whatever silver coin would take its place.

The keration was not a coin, but primarily a unit of weight, 1/1728 of the Roman pound, 1/144 of the Roman ounce, or about 0.189 g in modern terms. Since the solidus was one-sixth of a Roman ounce, the solidus weighed 24 keratia. Consequently, as a money of account, the keration was 1/24 of the Roman solidus, a relationship that lasted throughout the whole of the Byzantine Empire's history. Keratia are omnipresent in Byzantine monetary reckonings, but they are always notional. A debt expressed in solidi, keratia, and fractions of keratia would be paid in solidi, miliaresia, folles, and such fractions of these as were in circulation at the time.

The follis, sometimes called the obol, reintroduced in 498 with the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Anastasius I Dicorus (r. 491-518), was a copper coin worth forty nummi. Various fractions were struck during the 6th and 7th centuries, the half follis, decanummium, and pentanummium being the most important. In the mid 6th century the follis was reckoned 180 to the solidus. How the relationships between the solidus, keration, follis and nummus were affected by the "debasement" of the follis in the later 6th and 7th centuries – the gradual reduction of its weight to less than one-sixth of what it had been in the peak years of Justinian I's reign (527-565) – is a question to which there is not yet any answer. The nummus disappeared completely as a coin, but since the follis and its fractions still bore marks of value expressed as multiples of nummi, these were presumably still thought of as the lowest units in the monetary system.

This monetary system was not as unified in the three and a half centuries between the accession of the Byzantine emperor Leo III (r. 717-741) in 717, marking the end of the "Twenty Years' Anarchy" (695-717), and the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Alexios I Komnenos (r. 1081-1118) in 1092, following his accession in 1081, marking the end of a prolonged period of civil war resulting from the defeat to the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The silver miliaresion introduced by Leo III in 720 and continued by his successors provided a certain element of unity nonetheless. The essential features of the monetary system during this period may be summarized as follows:

Gold coinage – In the East, the semissis and tremissis ceased to be struck, save as ceremonial coins, toward the middle of the 8th century. Henceforward the only gold coin was the solidus. Its fineness remained virtually unchanged down to the 1030's, when debasement set in, and while its weight seems ot have declined very slightly the coin remained one theoretically struck 72 to the Roman pound. In the reign of Nikephoros II Phokas (r. 963-969), however, there began a series of experiments in light-weight nomismata comparable to the light-weight solidi of the 6th and 7th centuries. Of these the light-weight nomisma of 22 keratia, known as a tetarteron, finally gained the day, so that from the late 10th century down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092 one has to distinguish between the full-weight nomisma histamenon and the light-weight nomisma tetarteron.

Things went differently in the West. The solidus and tremissis continued to be struck in mainland Italy as long as the mints of Ravenna and Rome remained in Byzantine hands, i.e., to the mid and late 8th century, respectively. In Sicily they continued down to the reign of Basil I (r. 867-886), and there was even a revival of the use of the semissis in the early 9th century. The weight standard of the western gold coins, however, was substantially less than that of their eastern counterparts, and both on the mainland and in Sicily there was a serious reduction in fineness during the last decades of Byzantine rule. The fate of the fractional gold was related inversely to the presence or absence of a silver coinage, since the miliaresion flourished in the East but was not adopted in the West.

Silver coinage – The history of the silver coinage is that of a new miliaresion, a coin much lighter than the hexagram of the 7th century, which was introduced by Leo III in 720. It lasted, with remarkably few changes in external appearance, down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092. The weight, however, was several times altered, and in its final phase it was badly debased in both weight and fineness. Fractions were struck only under Leo III, of whose half miliaresion specimens are known, and in the middle of the 11th century. Over much of the period the miliaresion was valued as a double keration, i.e., as a coin worth 1/12 of a solidus, so that sums of money are as commonly expressed in terms of nomismata and miliaresia as of nomismata and keratia. But when this ratio became fixed, or how the value of the actual coins changed, in relation to the debased nomisma, during the last decades of their existence, are not known exactly.

Copper Coinage – The evolution of the copper resembled that of the gold in that both underwent a process of drastic simplification and differed from it in that the weight of the follis altered greatly over the centuries.
Historical notes:

Romanos IV (Diogenes) (born circa 1030; crown emperor on 1st January 1068; died in 1072)

(To the right) Photograph of the Grand Çamlıca Mosque in Istanbul, Turkey, taken by an anonym in 2021. The landmark complex was completed in 2019. The mosque has six minarets, which represent the six articles of Islamic faith (iman). Four of the minarets, centred around the central dome, feature three balconies that stand 107.1-metre high in recognition of the victory of the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The other two minarets, on the outer ends of the mosque, feature two balconies and are 90-metre high.

The final act of Constantine X (Doukas) before he died in 1067 was to demand that only his two sons he had elevated to co-emperors, Michael and Konstantios, succeed him, thereby forcing his wife Eudokia (Makrembolitissa) to take a vow not to remarry. Michael was about 17-year old while Konstantios was about 7-year old at the time. Since they were too young to rule, Eudokia ruled as regent until 1st January 1068, when she married Romanos IV (Diogenes) and crowned him emperor. Romanos IV was now the senior emperor and guardian of his stepsons Michael, Konstantios, and Andronikos who he also elevated to co-emperor. However, his accession to the throne had antagonised not only the Doukas family, in particular Constantine X (Doukas)'s brother John Doukas who led the opposition of the palace officials to Romanos IV (Diogenes) authority, but also the Varangian Guard, who openly expressed their discontent at the marriage of Eudokia. Romanos IV (Diogenes) therefore decided that he could only exercise his authority by placing himself at the head of the army in the field, thereby focusing the whole government's attention on the war against the Seljuk Turks.

By 1067, the Seljuk Turks had been making incursions at will across the eastern border of the Byzantine Empire. In 1068, the new emperor immediately set about trying to defend Asia Minor against the advance of the Seljuk Turks. He was confident of Byzantine superiority on the field of battle, looking on the Seljuk Turks as little more than hordes of robbers who would melt away at the first encounter. He did not take into account the degraded state of the Byzantine army, which had suffered years of neglect from his predecessors, in particular Constantine X (Doukas). With an army composed mainly of ill-disciplined, disorganised, and uncoordinated foreign mercenaries he achieved some initial success, but at the famous battle of Mantzikert in 1071 the Seljuk Turks won a devastating victory and Romanus IV (Diogenes) himself was taken prisoner. The opposition party in Constantinople took the opportunity to depose the unfortunate emperor and re-establish Eudokia on the throne together with her eldest son Michael VII (Dukas).

+ AD 1036 - Fāṭimid Caliphate - ¼ Dinar - al-Ẓāhir li-I'zāz Dīn Allāh (الظاهر لإعزاز دين الله):

Open description in new window
Period: Middle Ages; Fāṭimid Caliphate (909-1171); Fāṭimid dynasty (909-1171)
Ruler: al-Ẓāhir li-I'zāz Dīn Allāh (الظاهر لإعزاز دين الله) (AH 411-427)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Two concentric circles with a single marginal incription on the outer circle and an inscription within the inner circle (Nicol "Type C1")
Script: Arabic
Lettering: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) بسم الله ضرب هذا الدینار بالمنصورية سبع و عشرون و أربعمائة (within the inner circle) لصبر المؤمنين/لإعزاز دين الله/الظاهر
Traduction: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) In the Name of God this Dinar was struck in al-Manṣūrīyah in Seven and Twenty and Four Hundred (within the inner circle) He Who Appears Openly (al-Ẓāhir)/To Strengthen the Religion of God (li-I'zāz Dīn Allāh)/For the Patience of the Faithful (al-ṣabr al-mu'minīn)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Two concentric circles with a single marginal incription on the outer circle and an inscription within the inner circle (Nicol "Type C1")
Script: Arabic
Lettering: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) محمد رسول الله ارسله بالهدی و دین الحق لیظهره علی الدین کله و لو کره المشرکون (within the inner circle) على ولى الله/محمد رسول الله/لا اله الا الله
Traduction: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) Qur'ān IX:33 Muhammad is the Messenger of God Who has Sent Him with Guidance and the Religion of Truth that He May Make it Prevail over all Religion, even if the Polytheists are Averse (within the inner circle) There is No Deity but God/Muhammad is the Messenger of God/Ali is the Chosen Guardian of God
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This NGC-certified coin was described incorrectly on the certification label as: AH421. Siqilliya. It was sent to NGC for correction. The certification label was corrected.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 05h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Gold
Year: 1036 (AH 427 on the coin) Fineness: 958
Country: Fāṭimid Caliphate Weight (g): Measured: 0.89; Expected: 1.1
Issuer: Fāṭimid Caliphate Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: ¼ Diameter (mm): Measured: 12; Expected: 11.4
Unit: Dinar Thickness (mm): -
Mint: al-Manṣūrīyah (المنصورية) Mintage:
Mint mark: المنصورية Emission period: AH 411-427
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS64 (NGC) Variety: Nicol "Type C1" and without سنة
References: Nicol#1573; Album#715; Fr#27; ICV1#836
Varieties:

The lettering on the outer circle on the observe is missing "سنة" (literally "year") before the year (AH 427).

There is a large variety in the types and styles of the issues of individual caliphs. The earlier caliphs settled on one or two main types, but varieties made their appearance, especially from mints far from the capital. In the middle years of the Fāṭimid Caliphate, new types were introduced periodically, but there was often an overlap and several types might have been produced in the same mint in the same years. In Sicily, which seems to have been a world of its own, multiple types were struck, seemingly in a single mint, in any given year. This may mean that a single mint, perhaps that at Palemo, operated a number of workshops and the die makers of each workshop were able to create the dies in an independent manner, at least in deciding the design of the coin.
Note:

The early centre of the Fāṭimid Caliphate, which controlled, at various times, much of the Islamic world from Morocco to Syria, was situated in that part of North Africa which had been ruled by the Aghlabid Emirate (800-909). Therefore, it was natural that the earliest Fatimid coinage resembled that of the Aghlabids in style, fabric and appearance. Only the date, mint and inscriptions differentiated the coins of the Fāṭimids from the issues of their predecessors. It is likely that Aghlabid and Fāṭimid coins circulated together during the first decades of the new regime in Ifriqīyah and Sicily, that is, until enough of the older coinage had been melted and reminted in the Fāṭimid model that the latter would predominate in circulation.

The coinage issues of individual caliphs are surprisingly quite varied and distinctively different given that the Fāṭimid Caliphate's rule lasted for 260-odd years. The coins of the Fāṭimids fall into two main categories: the gold dinar and its fractions and the silver dirham and its fractions and multiples. Within these two categories, the dinar itself and the half dirham are the two denominations that have survived to the present day in rather large quantities. Some denominations were peculiar to certain geographical areas, whereas others were common to all parts of the Fāṭimid realm. The dinar was the standard gold coin in use throughout the Fatimid Empire, except in Sicily, where the quarter dinar predominated. The half dirham, common throughout North Africa and Egypt, was almost unknown in Sicily, which had a variety of silver fractions in use throughout the island. The half dirham was also not common in Syria and Palestine, but full dirhams and even silver coins of approximately two dirhams weight are not unknown, although one hesitates to call the latter "double dirhams." Billon coinage was produced by a number of Palestinian mints and are known in a wide range of weights, but were probably all generically called dishams. The silver issues of the later Fāṭimid caliphs, almost exclusively struck in Egypt were the small, irregularly-shaped black dirhams, the production of which was continued by the Ayyūbid Sultanate of Egypt (1171-1260). A very few copper or bronze coins have been encountered. Some of these exhibit traces of a silver wash, which indicated that they were not considered to be copper coins as such, but rather small change in the dirham series.

Fāṭimid coinage, and particularly gold coinage, played an important part in the economy of North Africa and the Middle East during the period of the Fāṭimid Caliphate. Indeed, the Fāṭimid dinar had a wider impact throughout the Mediterranean world because of the reputation the regime's coinage carried with it far beyond the borders of the empire. Fāṭimid gold coins were struck to a high standard of fineness and this standard was generally maintained during most of the time the Fāṭimid Caliphate was in power. In the Syrian and Palestinian territories, the dinar was frequently struck to a lighter standard, especially in the later years of the Fāṭimid Caliphate.
Historical notes:

al-Ẓāhir (li-I'zāz Dīn Allāh) (الظاهر لإعزاز دين الله) (born on 10 Ramadān AH 395 (20 June 1005); proclaimed caliph on 10 Dhū al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021); died on 15 Sha'bān AH 427 (13 June 1036))

(To the right) Photograph of the al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo, Egypt, taken by an anonym in 2018. The Fāṭimid Caliphate conquered Egypt and founded Cairo (al-Qāhira) in AH 358 (969). The mosque was established in AH 361 (972) and the capital of the Fāṭimid Caliphate moved from al-Manṣūrīyah to Cairo in AH 362 (972-973).

Some time passed after the disappearance of his predecessor al-Ḥākim on 27 Shawwāl AH 411 (13 February 1021) before al-Ẓāhir was proclaimed caliph on 10 Dhū al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021). The Fāṭimid regime was fairly stable during the first few years of al-Ẓāhir's caliphate, but this situation did not last very long. By 414-415 AH (1024-1025), the wasteful extravagances of al-Ḥākim's rule began to take a toll on the health of the empire. A financial crisis ensued in which the cash reserves of the treasury were depleted. The army remained unpaid for an overly long period, then riots in Cairo and the provinces broke out, al-Ẓāhir lost control of his government and a ruling clique came to be in charge in the capital. This was followed by first drought and then famine in Egypt during AH 415 (1024-1025).

Despite his political incompetence and a life given over to the pursuit of pleasure, al-Ẓāhir was able to weather the political storm and on 16 Jumādā II AH 420 (2 July 1029), his heir, Abū Tamīm Ma'add, who was destined to become the Caliph al-Mustanṣir, was born.

Trouble did not long stay away from al-Ẓāhir, however. His military commanders exercised almost independent control and in AH 421 (1030), attacks by the army on the populace in North Africa diminished support for the caliph. A powerful earthquake caused massive destruction in Palestine and al-Ẓāhir spent massive sums to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem during the years AH 421-424 (1030-1033). Famine once again visited North Africa in AH 425 (1034) and in the midst of all these problems, al-Ẓāhir died some two years later, just under thirty-two years of age.

Boîte no 03 :

→ Ier millénaire de l'ère « commune » de 0501 à 1000 :

+ AD 0987 - Royaume de France - Obole - Hugues Capet et Hervé, évêque de Beauvais:

Open description in new window
Period: Moyen Âge ; Royaume de France (987-1792) ; Maison de Capet (987-1328)
Ruler: Hugues Capet (987-996)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Croix pattée cantonnée d'un besant aux 2ème et 3ème cantons, entourée d'un grènetis intérieur, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (betwen the interior and exterior grènetis) (ligature He)R(ligature Ve)VSHVgoReX [(ligature He)R(ligature Ve)VS HVgo ReX]
Traduction: Hervé, Hugues, roi
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Monogramme carolingien de Karolus, entouré d'un grènetis intérieur, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (betwen the interior and exterior grènetis, starting at 10h) BelVAcVscIVITAs (BelVAcVs cIVITAs)
Traduction: Ville de Bellovacus (Beauvais)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

Cette pièce me fait penser aux cours d'« histoire-géo » à l'école élémentaire, que j'ai souvent trouvés informatifs mais incompréhensibles.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 09h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 987 (not dated) Fineness: 917
Country: Royaume de France Weight (g): Measured: 0.52; Expected: 0.56
Issuer: Évêché de Beauvais Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: ½ Diameter (mm): Expected: 15.5
Unit: Denier tournois (987-1795) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Beauvais Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 987-998
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: XF40 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Ciani#14; Lafaurie#7; DyRoy1#2
Varieties:

Aucune
Note:

Quelques années avant son élection comme roi des Francs en 987, Hugues Capet avait battu monnaie avec le titre de duc des Francs (« dux francorum ») à Paris, Saint-Denis et Senlis. Il ne semble pas que ces monnaies aient encore été émises après 987. Quant aux deniers et oboles de Paris, de différents types, avec le titre royal, ce sont des faux modernes, fabriqués à partir de 1914 par Louis Farigault (1860-1942).

Les seules monnaies authentiques du roi Hugues Capet actuellement connues sont les deniers et oboles de Beauvais et le denier de Laon. On ne sait pas pour quelle raison – partage des bénéfices de la monnaie ou simple hommage – Hervé, évêque de Beauvais entre 987 et 998, ajouta le nom du roi au sien sur ses monnaies, qui furent immobilisées pendant un certain temps après la mort de l'un et de l'autre. Le denier de Laon, qui ne porte pas le nom d'Adalbéron, évêque de Laon, fut sans doute frappé lorsque la ville de Laon fut restituée à Hugues Capet en 991, suite à la capture de Charles de Basse-Lotharingie, avant d'être abandonnée à l'évêque Adalbéron quelque temps après.
Historical notes:

Hugues Capet (naissance vers 939-941 probablement à Dourdan ; avènement le 3 juillet 987 ; mort le 24 octobre 996)

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de Hugues Capet, peinte par Charles Auguste, baron de Steuben (1788-1856) vers 1837. Cette œuvre fait partie d'une série de portraits, commandée par Louis-Philippe entre 1836 et 1838 afin d'enrichir les collections du Musée historique de Versailles.

Hugues Capet, comte de Paris et d'Orléans, marquis de Neustrie et duc des Francs, élu roi par les grands du royaume, fut couronné à Noyon le 3 juillet 987. Dès le 30 décembre de la même année, il s'associa à son fils Robert (II), dit « le Pieux » pour consolider la nouvelle dynastie. En 996, à la mort de son père, Robert II est couronné roi des Francs. Ainsi fondée, la dynastie capétienne reste la dernière dynastie royale de l'histoire de France.

Tenu en échec pendant trois ans de 988 à 991 par Charles de Basse-Lotharingie, oncle et héritier légitime du dernier roi carolingien Louis V, il ne réussit à le faire prisonnier que grâce à la traîtrise d'Adalbéron, évêque de Laon, qui le lui livre dans la nuit du 29 au 30 mars 991.

+ AD 0914 - Abbāsid Caliphate - 1 Dinar - al-Muqtadir bi'Llāh (المقتدر بالله):

Open description in new window
Period: Middle Ages; Abbāsid Caliphate (750-1258; 1261-1517); Abbāsid dynasty (750-1258)
Ruler: al-Muqtadir bi'Llāh (المقتدر بالله) (AH 295-320)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Two concentric circles with a single marginal incription on the outer circle and an inscription above the blason of Baybars (I) (lion passant to left) within the inner circle
Script: Arabic

Designer: -

Traduction: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) Qur'ān IX:33 Muhammad is the Messenger of God Who has Sent Him with Guidance and the Religion of Truth that He May Make it Prevail over all Religion, even if the Polytheists are Averse (within the inner circle) There is No Deity but God/Muhammad is the Messenger of God/Ali is the Chosen Guardian of God

Note:

The early centre of the Fāṭimid Caliphate, which controlled, at various times, much of the Islamic world from Morocco to Syria, was situated in that part of North Africa which had been ruled by the Aghlabid Emirate (800-909). Therefore, it was natural that the earliest Fatimid coinage resembled that of the Aghlabids in style, fabric and appearance. Only the date, mint and inscriptions differentiated the coins of the Fāṭimids from the issues of their predecessors. It is likely that Aghlabid and Fāṭimid coins circulated together during the first decades of the new regime in Ifriqīyah and Sicily, that is, until enough of the older coinage had been melted and reminted in the Fāṭimid model that the latter would predominate in circulation.

The coinage issues of individual caliphs are surprisingly quite varied and distinctively different given that the Fāṭimid Caliphate's rule lasted for 260-odd years. The coins of the Fāṭimids fall into two main categories: the gold dinar and its fractions and the silver dirham and its fractions and multiples. Within these two categories, the dinar itself and the half dirham are the two denominations that have survived to the present day in rather large quantities. The dinar was the standard gold coin in use throughout the Fatimid Empire, except in Sicily, where the quarter dinar predominated. The half dirham, common throughout North Africa and Egypt, was almost unknown in Sicily, which had a variety of silver fractions in use throughout the island. The half dirham was also not common in Syria and Palestine, but full dirhams and even silver coins of approximately two dirhams weight are not unknown, although one hesitates to call the latter "double dirhams." Billon coinage was produced by a number of Palestinian mints and are known in a wide range of weights, but were probably all generically called dishams. The silver issues of the later Fāṭimid caliphs, almost exclusively struck in Egypt were the small, irregularly-shaped black dirhams, the production of which was continued by the Ayyūbid Sultanate of Egypt (1171-1260). A very few copper or bronze coins have been encountered. Some of these exhibit traces of a silver wash, which indicated that they were not considered to be copper coins as such, but rather small change in the dirham series.

Fāṭimid coinage, and particularly gold coinage, played an important part in the economy of North Africa and the Middle East during the period of the Fāṭimid Caliphate. Indeed, the Fāṭimid dinar had a wider impact throughout the Mediterranean world because of the reputation the regime's coinage carried with it far beyond the borders of the empire. Fāṭimid gold coins were struck to a high standard of fineness and this standard was generally maintained during most of the time the Fāṭimid Caliphate was in power. In the Syrian and Palestinian territories, the dinar was frequently struck to a lighter standard, especially in the later years of the Fāṭimid Caliphate.
Historical notes:

al-Ẓāhir (li-I'zāz Dīn Allāh) (الظاهر لإعزاز دين الله) (born on 10 Ramadān AH 395 (20 June 1005); proclaimed caliph on 10 Dhū al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021); died on 15 Sha'bān AH 427 (13 June 1036))

(To the right) Photograph of the al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo, Egypt, taken by an anonym in 2018. The Fāṭimid Caliphate conquered Egypt and founded Cairo (al-Qāhira) in AH 358 (969). The mosque was established in AH 361 (972) and the capital of the Fāṭimid Caliphate moved from al-Manṣūrīyah to Cairo in AH 362 (972-973).

Some time passed after the disappearance of his predecessor al-Ḥākim on 27 Shawwāl AH 411 (13 February 1021) before al-Ẓāhir was proclaimed caliph on 10 Dhū al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021). The Fāṭimid regime was fairly stable during the first few years of al-Ẓāhir's caliphate, but this situation did not last very long. By 414-415 AH (1024-1025), the wasteful extravagances of al-Ḥākim's rule began to take a toll on the health of the empire. A financial crisis ensued in which the cash reserves of the treasury were depleted. The army remained unpaid for an overly long period, then riots in Cairo and the provinces broke out, al-Ẓāhir lost control of his government and a ruling clique came to be in charge in the capital. This was followed by first drought and then famine in Egypt during AH 415 (1024-1025).

Despite his political incompetence and a life given over to the pursuit of pleasure, al-Ẓāhir was able to weather the political storm and on 16 Jumādā II AH 420 (2 July 1029), his heir, Abū Tamīm Ma'add, who was destined to become the Caliph al-Mustanṣir, was born.

Trouble did not long stay away from al-Ẓāhir, however. His military commanders exercised almost independent control and in AH 421 (1030), attacks by the army on the populace in North Africa diminished support for the caliph. A powerful earthquake caused massive destruction in Palestine and al-Ẓāhir spent massive sums to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem during the years AH 421-424 (1030-1033). Famine once again visited North Africa in AH 425 (1034) and in the midst of all these problems, al-Ẓāhir died some two years later, just under thirty-two years of age.

 -

+ AD 0878 - Royaume de Francie occidentale - Denier - Charles II, dit « le Chauve »:

Open description in new window
Period: Moyen Âge ; Royaume de Francie occidentale (843-987) ; Dynastie carolingienne (751-987)
Ruler: Charles II, dit « le Chauve » (843-877)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Monogramme carolingien de Karolus, entouré d'un grènetis intérieur, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (betwen the interior and exterior grènetis, starting at 9h) ✠GRaTIad̄IReX (✠ GRaTIa d̄I ReX ; le macron au-dessus de la lettre d indiquant que des lettres suivant celle-ci sont manquantes, ici la lettre e pour deI)
