Grade: AU58★ (NGC) Variety: None
References: Gariel2_1#45; ProuCarol#404; DepeyrotCarol#128; MG#887; MEC1#854
Varieties:

La lettre initiale H, avec le « h » aspiré comme pour les mots d'origine germanique se retrouve sur plusieurs pièces conformes à l'édit de Pîtres et d’un voisinage certain: (ligature HC)VRTIsasONIeN (Curtisasonien, probablement maintenant Courcessin), (ligature HC)VsTaNcIeN (Constantia, maintenant Coutances) ou (ligature HC)VsTeNsIsONeM (Coutances), et la présence de la lettre O en onciale se retrouve sur les mêmes pièces, comme aussi sur celles de Dijon.
Note:

Jusqu'à l'introduction de la réforme monétaire par l'édit de Pîtres en 864, Charles le Chauve n'a pas réussi à maintenir l'économie monétaire étroitement contrôlée et gérée efficacement dont il avait hérité de son père, Louis Ier, dit « le Pieux » ou « le Débonnaire » (778-840 ; r. 814-840). Les ateliers monétaires semblaient alors avoir pu exercer un certain degré d'autonomie, notamment dans la région troublée de l'Aquitaine, tandis que la qualité de la monnaie en circulation s'était dégradée. Les trouvailles de monnaies carolingiennes témoignent que presque tous les types monétaires portaient au droit le nom royal — CAR(O)LVSREXFR — autour d'une croix, mais au revers le nom de l'atelier monétaire était inscrit soit dans le champ, soit autour d'un temple, d'une croix, ou du monogramme carolingien. Les querelles intestines et les attaques vikings et sarrasines auxquelles le roi a été confronté ont pu mener à une cette situation. Cela met en évidence le grand succès de la réforme initiée par l’édit de Pitres en 864. Le poids et la finesse de la monnaie ont été restaurés. Pratiquement tous les ateliers monétaires du royaume ont été contraints de produire un seul type de monnaie, à l'exception notable de ceux situés en Aquitaine rebelle.

L'article XI de l'édit de Pîtres préscrit :

Ut in denariis novae nostrae monetae ex una parte nomen nostrum habeatur in gyro et in medio nostri nominis monogramma, ex altera vero parte nomen civitatis et in medio crux habeatur.

Ceci peut être traduit en français par: « Que les deniers de notre nouvelle monnaie aient d'un côté notre titre en cercle, et au centre le monogramme de notre nom, et de l'autre côté le nom de la ville, et au centre une croix. » Les trouvailles de ces monnaies du type de l'édit de Pîtres indiquent que la légende donnant le titre est « GRATIAD̅IREX », c'est-à-dire « GRATIADEIREX ». Ce type monétaire est ainsi souvent qualifié de « GDR ».

L'article XII de l'édit de Pîtres préscrit :

Sequentes consuetudinem praedecessorum nostrorum, sicut in illorum capitulis invenitur, constituimus, ut in nulla loco alio in omni regno nostro moneta fiat, nisi in palatio nostro et in Quentovico ac Rotomago, quae moneta ad Quentovicum ex antiqua consuetudine pertinet, et in Remis et in Senonis et in Parisio et in Aurelianis et in Cavillono et in Metullo et in Narbona.

Ceci peut être traduit en français par: « Suivant la coutume de nos prédécesseurs, comme on le trouve dans leurs capitulaires, nous décrétons qu’en aucun autre lieu dans tout notre royaume ne peut être fabriquée de la monnaie, sauf au palais, à Quentovic et Rouen — dont la monnaie appartenait de coutume ancienne à Quentovic —, à Reims, à Sens, à Paris, à Orléans, à Chalon(-sur-Saône), à Melle, et à Narbonne. » Bien que l'année suivante l'évêque de Châlons-sur-Marne obtint qu'un nouvel atelier soit ouvert dans sa ville, et que d'autres concessions aient été accordées vraisemblablement sans qu'aucun texte ne nous en soit parvenu, les collections permettent de répertorier 125 noms de lieux sur les monnaies au type créé par l'édit de Pîtres. Jusqu'à présent les numismates ont pensé que l'édit était resté lettre morte et que l'anarchie monétaire s'était déjà instaurée dans le royaume de Charles le Chauve. L'étude minutieuse de la gravure des monnaies résultant de celle des coins de frappe, a permis récemment de trouver quelques exemples d'utilisation d'un même coin au monogramme carolingien associé à des coins portant des noms de lieux différents. Donc ces coins étaient réunis en un même endroit et l'article XII de l'édit de Pîtres, si controversé, reçoit de ce fait une explication logique. Ce qui est créé est un ensemble de dix ateliers de fabrication, plutôt bien répartis dans le royaume, sous l'autorité du comte de l'endroit où ils sont situés, mais ces ateliers ne sont pas destinés uniquement à la frappe des monnaies de ce lieu, mais de plusieurs lieux situés dans les environs. Ce sont des ateliers travaillant à la demande, où sont concentrés les techniciens dont la compétence est garante d'une fabrication conforme aux directives du pouvoir central. Il est à noter que l'étude de la circulation monétaire n'est pas entachée par cette constatation car les monnaies sont émises dans le lieu dont elles portent le nom. Les quelques exemples découverts de ces stimulantes liaisons de coins permettent de penser qu'il sera possible, un jour, par l'examen minutieux de très nombreuses monnaies d'établir la carte du ressort de chacun des dix ateliers de l'édit de Pîtres. Ce n'est qu'une question de matériel, d'illustrations des catalogues des collections et de trouvailles permettant des comparaisons qui jusqu'ici ne sont pas disponibles. En attendant, il est probable que l'atelier de Bayeux dépendait de celui de Rouen qui est le plus proche géographiquement.
Historical notes:

Charles II (naissance le 13 juin 823 à Francfort-sur-le-Main ; avènement en août 843 ; mort le 6 octobre 877 à Avrieux)

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de Charles II, empereur d'Occident, peinte par Charles Auguste, baron de Steuben (1788-1856) vers 1837. Cette œuvre fait partie d'une série de portraits, commandée par Louis-Philippe entre 1836 et 1838 afin d'enrichir les collections du Musée historique de Versailles.

Fils de l'empereur Louis Ier, dit « le Pieux » (ou « le Débonnaire »), et de sa seconde épouse Judith de Bavière (vers 797-843), Charles II, dit « le Chauve » fut la cause involontaire d'une violente discorde lorsque, en 829, son père le fit duc d'Alémanie, incluant la Rhétie, l'Alsace et une partie de la Bourgogne, alors qu'il était âgé de six ans. L'action de l'empereur Louis le « Pieux » précipita une série de guerres civiles, qui durèrent jusqu'en 838, au cours desquelles les trois fils de son premier mariage avec Ermengarde de Hesbaye (vers 778-818), Lothaire Ier (795-855), Louis II, dit « le Germanique » (vers 806-876), et Pépin Ier d'Aquitaine (797-838), s'efforcèrent de maintenir ou d'augmenter les droits qui leur avaient été garantis en juillet 817 par l'Ordinatio Imperii, le règlement successoral de l'Empire carolingien conçu originellement par l'empereur. Pépin Ier d'Aquitaine est mort en 838, mais après la mort de Louis le « Pieux » en 840, la guerre civile a repris et s'est poursuivie jusqu'à ce que Louis II « le Germanique » et Charles II « le Chauve » s'allient militairement contre Lothaire Ier (par les Serments de Strasbourg en 842) et le forcent à accepter le traité de Verdun en 843, par lequel Charles II « le Chauve » a reçu la Francie occidentale (France), Louis II « le Germanique » la Francie orientale (Germanie), et Lothaire Ier la Francie médiane (Lotharingie) ainsi que le titre d'Empereur des Romains.

Jusqu'en 864, la situation politique de Charles II « le Chauve » était précaire car peu de vassaux lui étaient loyaux. Ses terres ont souffert des raids des Vikings, qui ne sont partis qu'après avoir reçu des rançons ; il a été vaincu par les Bretons et, en 858, a fait face à une invasion par Louis II « le Germanique ». Pourtant, il réussit à prendre le contrôle de l'Aquitaine après la capture du fils de Pépin Ier d'Aquitaine en 864 ; et, par le traité de Meerssen en août 870, avec Louis II « le Germanique » ils se partagèrent la Lotharingie septentrionale, le royaume que leur feu neveu Lothaire II (vers 835-869) avait hérité de son père Lothaire Ier.

Lorsque le fils aîné de Lothaire Ier, l'empereur Louis II, dit Louis « le Jeune » (825-875), meurt en 875, Charles II « le Chauve » se rend en Italie et est couronné empereur le 25 décembre 875 par le pape Jean VIII (vers 820-882). En 876, après la mort de Louis II « le Germanique », Charles II « le Chauve » envahit ses territoires mais fut vaincu le 8 octobre 876 à Andernach par le fils de Louis II « le Germanique », Louis III, dit « le Jeune » (vers 835-882). La mort de Charles II « le Chauve » l'année suivante en 877 s'est produite lorsqu'un autre fils de Louis II « le Germanique », Carloman de Bavière (vers 830-880), marchait contre lui et lorsque ses propres vassaux majeurs étaient en révolte. Il avait à peine eu le temps de reconnaître un début d'hérédité pour les « honneurs» (fonctions publiques) et les bénéfices que le pouvoir central avait confié aux grands du royaume, tant pour assurer l'ordre que pour se créer des partisans. Et c'est ce glissement de l'autorité centrale qui caractérisa la période suivante, qui vit s'esquisser la féodalité.

+ AD 0728 - Royaume des Francs - Denier, dit « à l'E croiseté et aux "pseudo-légendes" » - Mérovigiens (Anonyme):

Open description in new window
Period: Moyen Âge ; Royaume des Francs (481-843) ; Dynastie mérovingienne (481-751)
Ruler: Mérovigiens (vers 670-751)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Petite tête barbare stylisée, à droite, les cheveux sous forme de trois rangs de perles superposés, entourée d'un grènetis intérieur, le buste ou les jambes au-dessous sous la forme de la lettre A, à cheval sur le grènetis intérieur, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: Légende indéterminée, bien que des lettres soient reconnaissables: ºF[...]CTCCTº selon Clairand et Téreygeol (2009), ou plutôt F[...]CALLTO
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Grande lettre E ou M lunaire (Є ou m, en onciale), croisetée (la traverse crucigère n'étant pas visible sur cet exemplaire), entourée de quatre besants (globules), deux à droite, un au-dessus et un au-dessous, le champ entouré d'un grènetis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was AU58. The coin was not encapsulated by NGC. It was described as "Ineligible Type" on the certification label, that is a class of coin, medal or token that NGC does not certify, regardless of its condition. NGC will refund the grading fee, less a USD 5 processing charge. I learnt a lesson in the process: NGC does not certify Merovingian coins. PCGS does not appear to certify Merovingian coins either. Hence, I decided to encapsulate this coin myself for convenience of storage and long-term preservation of the coin. To proceed, I purchased a coin of similar diameter, encapsulated by NGC Ancients (with the certification # 6828451-004), so that I could "crack" the NGC holder and replace the coin by this coin. The operation was a success, though fitting the coin in the holder turned out not to be a trivial task.

Traditionnellement, ces deniers avec la lettre E lunaire (ϵ, en onciale) croisetée au revers sont attribués à Paris, mais sans argument convaincant. Les analyses métalliques tendraient à prouver que ces monnaies ont été frappées avec de l’argent de Melle en Poitou et qu'elles proviendraient plutôt d'un atelier monétaire local. La lettre Є croisetée serait alors la lettre M lunaire (m, en onciale) croisetée, la lettre M étant la première lettre des diverses variations des anciens noms de la ville de Melle (Metalus Vicus, Metulo, Metullo, Metulum, Metullum, Metalo, Metallo, Metalum, Metallum, etc.). L'atelier monétaire de Melle, dans le sud est des Deux-Sèvres, fut important à l'époque carolingienne et semble avoir fonctionné dès l'époque mérovingienne. Les mines de plomb argentifère sont toujours accessibles et visitables par un large public. D'après les informations que l'on aurait transmises au précédent acquéreur, cette monnaie aurait été trouvée à Richelieu en Touraine, qui se trouve à environ 100 km de Melle. Cette proximité géographique est compatible avec une frappe dans un atelier monétaire de la région melloise.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R3 Material: Silver
Year: 728 (not dated) Fineness: 917
Country: Royaume des Francs Weight (g): Expected: 0.88
Issuer: Royaume des Francs Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 12
Unit: Denier (vers 670-751) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Melle, Deux-Sèvres (?) Mintage:
Mint mark: Є Emission period: vers 670-751
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: AU58 (CCN) Variety: Tête, « pseudo-légendes » et globules
References: ProuMerov#812var; DeBelfort4#6337var; Roberts#0467var
Varieties:

Il existe plusieurs variétés de styles de tête et de « pseudo-légendes » à l'avers. L'agencement des globules, aussi bien à l'avers qu'au revers, est également variable d'un exemplaire à l'autre.
Note:

Différentes monnaies d'or, d'argent et de cuivre circulaient en Gaule à la fin de l'Empire romain d'Occident en 476. Aux temps mérovingiens ne subsiste guère que la monnaie d'or, sou (du nom de la monnaie romaine d'or, le solidus) et surtout tiers de sou, appelé aussi triens (du nom de la monnaie romaine d'or, le tremissis, valant un tiers de solidus), imitations plus ou moins réussies des pièces impériales romaines. Le triens d'or devient quasiment espèce unique au début du VIIème siècle. L'or provient principalement du bassin méditerranéen, en particulier des monnaies de l'Empire byzantin. Mais vers 650, le centre de gravité des relations commerciales européennes se déplace vers le nord de l'Europe où les anglo-saxons et les frisons qui développe le commerce le long des côtes de la mer du Nord utilisent des monnaies d'argent, les sceattas. Les monnayages mérovingiens passent ainsi du monométalisme or au monométalisme argent, inspiré des pays nordiques. Vers 670, le sou d'or est complété par une pièce d'argent : le denier (du nom de l'ancienne monnaie romaine d'argent, le denarius, remplacé au IIIème siècle par l'antoninianus, puis par d'autres monnaies d'argent). Entre 670 et 751 environ, seul l'argent est frappé dans le royaume mérovingien, sous forme de denier et de demi-denier ou obole.

Par son aspect le denier d'argent mérovingien ne diffère qu'assez peu du triens d'or. Ce sont les mêmes types qui sont continués au moins pendant un certain temps, les légendes indiquent le nom du lieu d'émission, le nom du monétaire. Le diamètre qui varie entre 11 et 13 mm est le même, seul le métal diffère. Cependant, avec le temps, le denier se transforme. Les légendes deviennent sibyllines ou disparaissent complètement, les diamètres des deniers de certains ateliers monétaires augmentent, 12 à 14 mm, les gravures sont plus grossières et schématiques et l'iconographie devient parfois exubérante. L'épigraphie aussi se transforme, au moins dans certains ateliers monétaires, et les inscriptions, avant de disparaître, deviennent souvent incohérentes. Un bon exemple de cette incohérence est fourni par cet exemplaire pour lequel la légende à l'avers est sujette à interprétation.

Le contrôle des monnaies semble échapper en grande partie au pouvoir royal mérovingien. Le pouvoir royal sur la monnaie sera réaffirmé sous l'égide de la dynastie carolingienne (à partir de 751) qui imposera le denier d'argent carolingien comme monnaie unique et prescrira un ensemble de règlements et de contrôles organisant sa fabrication et sa mise en circulation.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de la « Bataille de Poitiers. Octobre 732 », peinte par Charles Auguste, baron de Steuben (1788-1856) en 1837. Cette œuvre fut commandée par Louis-Philippe en 1834 afin d'enrichir les collections du Musée historique de Versailles. La peinture est une représentation romantique du général franc Charles Martel (718-741) combattant le général omeyyade Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd Allah Al-Ghafiqi à la Bataille de Tours (également connue sous le nom de « Bataille de Poitiers » et, dans les sources arabes, de « Bataille de la Route des Martyrs ») en 732. Le combat en tête-à-tête décrit n'a jamais eu lieu, car Abd Al-Rahman a été tué par une lance et ses forces ont battu en retraite de manière désorganisée.

+ AD 0678 - Royaume des Francs - Denier, dit « au cavalier » - Mérovigiens (Anonyme):

Open description in new window
Period: Moyen Âge ; Royaume des Francs (481-843) ; Dynastie mérovingienne (481-751)
Ruler: Mérovigiens (vers 670-751)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Cheval et son cavalier allant vers la gauche du champ, deux croisettes pattées placées, l'une au dessus de la crinière (non visible sur cet exemplaire), l'autre au dessus de la croupe du cheval, le champ inscrit dans un cercle perlé ; le cheval et son cavalier représentés au moyen de traits rectilignes qui figurent les principaux éléments anatomiques : corps, encolure, crinière, lignes inférieure et supérieure de la tête, oreilles, jambes, queue du cheval ; jambes, buste, cou du cavalier ; et qui sont bouletés aux extremités, sortes d'« épingles », à l'exception de ceux figurant la crinière, marquant ainsi la base et les extrémités des oreilles, le nez, les sabots, le bout de la queue du cheval ; les pieds, le torse, la tête du cavalier ; deux globules marquant le garrot et la croupe du cheval, reliés entre eux par un trait plus gros que les autres
Script: Latin
Lettering: Légende indéterminée, bien qu'une lettre (A ?) soit discernable derrière le cheval
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Monogramme « AR », formé des Iettres AR, les deux premières du nom de lieu d'emission, Arvernis ; Ieurs fûts bouletés à la ligne de pied, les fûts internes reliés à leur base et surmontés d'un macron, la pointe de la lettre A, bouletée, accostée de deux perles, une autre se trouvant sous la lettre R, une croisette aux extrémités bouletées pendue à la traverse brisée de la lettre A, dont la brisure est alignée avec la ligne de pied, le champ inscrit dans un cercle perlé
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was meant be sent to NGC for grading. However, I found out that NGC does not certify Merovingian coins. PCGS does not appear to certify Merovingian coins either. Hence, I decided to encapsulate this coin myself for convenience of storage and long-term preservation of the coin. To proceed, I purchased a coin of similar diameter, encapsulated by NGC Ancients (with the certification # 6828451-091), so that I could ""crack"" the NGC holder and replace the coin by this coin. The operation was a success, though fitting the coin in the holder turned out not to be a trivial task.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓

Ces deniers au monogramme « AR » sont attribués à Clermont-Ferrand (Arvernus). Le monogramme « AR » est formé des Iettres AR, les deux premières du nom de lieu d'emission, Arvernis. Des trouvailles assez nombreuses de monnaies portant cette marque, parfois en monogramme, ont été faites en Auvergne pour confirmer cette attribution et éliminer quelques propositions d'y voir les marques d'Aurelianis (Orléans), Arelate (Arles) ou Argentorate (Strasbourg). Lafaurie (1992) présente un rapport détaillé sur les deniers, dit « au cavalier », de Clermont-Ferrand. Le seul de ces deniers qui soit issu d'un trésor connu est celui du trésor trouvé à Nice-Cimiez, enfoui autour de 740, qui contenait aussi la plupart des deniers épiscopaux connus de Clermont-Ferrand.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R3 Material: Silver
Year: 678 (not dated) Fineness: 917
Country: Royaume des Francs Weight (g): Expected: 0.88
Issuer: Royaume des Francs Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 11
Unit: Denier (vers 670-751) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Arvernis (?) Mintage:
Mint mark: AR Emission period: vers 670-751
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: AU58 (CCN) Variety: Monogramme
References: ProuMerov#1776var; DeBelfort1#411; Roberts#0662
Varieties:

Il existe plusieurs variétés de styles de cheval et de cavalier à l'avers, ainsi qu'une variété avec le monogramme « AR » renversé au revers (voir Lafaurie, 1992). L'agencement des perles au revers, est également variable d'un exemplaire à l'autre.

Cet exemplaire est issu des mêmes coins de frappe que les exemplaires conservés aux Cabinets des Médailles des Musées des Beaux-Arts de Lyon, provenant du trésor de Nice-Cimiez, et de Copenhague (Belfort#411).
Note:

Différentes monnaies d'or, d'argent et de cuivre circulaient en Gaule à la fin de l'Empire romain d'Occident en 476. Aux temps mérovingiens ne subsiste guère que la monnaie d'or, sou (du nom de la monnaie romaine d'or, le solidus) et surtout tiers de sou, appelé aussi triens (du nom de la monnaie romaine d'or, le tremissis, valant un tiers de solidus), imitations plus ou moins réussies des pièces impériales romaines. Le triens d'or devient quasiment espèce unique au début du VIIème siècle. L'or provient principalement du bassin méditerranéen, en particulier des monnaies de l'Empire byzantin. Mais vers 650, le centre de gravité des relations commerciales européennes se déplace vers le nord de l'Europe où les anglo-saxons et les frisons qui développe le commerce le long des côtes de la mer du Nord utilisent des monnaies d'argent, les sceattas. Les monnayages mérovingiens passent ainsi du monométalisme or au monométalisme argent, inspiré des pays nordiques. Vers 670, le sou d'or est complété par une pièce d'argent : le denier (du nom de l'ancienne monnaie romaine d'argent, le denarius, remplacé au IIIème siècle par l'antoninianus, puis par d'autres monnaies d'argent). Entre 670 et 751 environ, seul l'argent est frappé dans le royaume mérovingien, sous forme de denier et de demi-denier ou obole.

Par son aspect le denier d'argent mérovingien ne diffère qu'assez peu du triens d'or. Ce sont les mêmes types qui sont continués au moins pendant un certain temps, les légendes indiquent le nom du lieu d'émission, le nom du monétaire. Le diamètre qui varie entre 11 et 13 mm est le même, seul le métal diffère. Cependant, avec le temps, le denier se transforme. Les légendes deviennent sibyllines ou disparaissent complètement, les diamètres des deniers de certains ateliers monétaires augmentent, 12 à 14 mm, les gravures sont plus grossières et schématiques et l'iconographie devient parfois exubérante. L'épigraphie aussi se transforme, au moins dans certains ateliers monétaires, et les inscriptions, avant de disparaître, deviennent souvent incohérentes.

Le contrôle des monnaies semble échapper en grande partie au pouvoir royal mérovingien. Le pouvoir royal sur la monnaie sera réaffirmé sous l'égide de la dynastie carolingienne (à partir de 751) qui imposera le denier d'argent carolingien comme monnaie unique et prescrira un ensemble de règlements et de contrôles organisant sa fabrication et sa mise en circulation.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de la « Bataille de Poitiers. Octobre 732 », peinte par Charles Auguste, baron de Steuben (1788-1856) en 1837. Cette œuvre fut commandée par Louis-Philippe en 1834 afin d'enrichir les collections du Musée historique de Versailles. La peinture est une représentation romantique du général franc Charles Martel (718-741) combattant le général omeyyade Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd Allah Al-Ghafiqi à la Bataille de Tours (également connue sous le nom de « Bataille de Poitiers » et, dans les sources arabes, de « Bataille de la Route des Martyrs ») en 732. Le combat en tête-à-tête décrit n'a jamais eu lieu, car Abd Al-Rahman a été tué par une lance et ses forces ont battu en retraite de manière désorganisée.

+ AD 0610 - Byzantine Empire - Tremissis - Heraclius:

Open description in new window
Period: Middle Ages; Byzantine Empire (395-1453); Heraclian dynasty (610-711)
Ruler: Heraclius (610-641)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Heraclius, facing right, seen from three quarters forward, diademed with no pearl visible in the composition of diadem and a cross above its front, draped, cuirassed
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) DNHERCL-IVSPPVC (D N HERCLIVS PP VC)
Traduction: Our Lord (Dominus Noster) Heraclius, perpetual (Perpetuus) Emperor (Augustus) (Dominus Noster Heraclius Perpetuus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Cross potent, with a pellet in the fourth quadrant, the abbreviation "CONOB" (standing for "Cōnstantīnopolis obryzum", with "obryzum" the Latin word for "refined gold") below in exergue
Script: Greek
Lettering: (starting at 08h) VICTORVCVSTORVN (VICTOR VCVSTORVN)
Traduction: The victory of the Emperor (Victoria Augustorum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

Rare in this condition
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Gold
Year: 610 (not dated) Fineness: 1000
Country: Byzantine Empire Weight (g): Measured: 1.47; Expected: 1.52
Issuer: Byzantine Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: ⅓ Diameter (mm): Expected: 15
Unit: First Solidus Nomisma ("Reform" of Anastasius I Dicorus; 498-720) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Ravenna Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 610-613
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AU★; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: BCV#902; DOC2_1#276; MIB3#125A; Ranieri#574; MBR#11.124N; Fr#104
Varieties:

This tremissis might be an example of the Lombard coinage of tremisses from Tuscany (see for instance MEC1#307-310). However, because of their heavy annular border these tremisses are commonly ascribed to Ravenna.

A variety exists (MBR#11.125) with the obverse legend separated as DNHERCLI-VSPPVC rather than DNHERCL-IVSPPVC. The obverse legend of this variety corresponds to that of the semisses of type BCV#899D and MIB3#121. Hence, this variety was probably issued in parallel with the emission of this type of semissis in 637-641.
Note:

The twin pivots of the Byzantine monetary system in the 5th and 6th centuries had been the gold solidus or nomisma and the copper nummus. The gold solidus was a coin struck 72 to the Roman pound and consequently weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. The nummus, sometimes called by contemporaries a denarius, was a small coin of varying weight, usually about 1 g or a little less. It has then been reckoned as 1/7200 of the solidus, but its value in fact varied and seems frequently to have fallen to a much lower figure. The gap between the solidus and the nummus was bridged in part by real coins (the gold semissis and tremissis, fractions of the solidus, and the copper pentanummium, decanummium, half follis, and follis, multiples of the nummus), in part by a money of account, the keration, and in part by the miliaresion, which was sometimes one and sometimes the other.

Treating them in descending order of value, the semissis and tremissis require no discussion. They were actual coins, worth one-half and one-third of a solidus, respectively. Miliaresion was a Greek loan word from the Latin "miliarense", a term applied to a silver coin current in the 4th century from the period of the Tetrarchy onward. In the 6th century, when no silver coinage was being struck for regular circulation in the East, it had become the generic name for any silver coin at all, being applied indifferently to the Roman denarius and to the Persian dirham. When the hexagram was created by the Byzantine emperor Heraclius (r. 610–641) this was known as the silver coin of six grammata, and when the hexagram ceased to be struck the term remained available for application to whatever silver coin would take its place.

The keration was not a coin, but primarily a unit of weight, 1/1728 of the Roman pound, 1/144 of the Roman ounce, or about 0.189 g in modern terms. Since the solidus was one-sixth of a Roman ounce, the solidus weighed 24 keratia. Consequently, as a money of account, the keration was 1/24 of the Roman solidus, a relationship that lasted throughout the whole of the Byzantine Empire's history. Keratia are omnipresent in Byzantine monetary reckonings, but they are always notional. A debt expressed in solidi, keratia, and fractions of keratia would be paid in solidi, miliaresia, folles, and such fractions of these as were in circulation at the time.

The follis, sometimes called the obol, reintroduced in 498 with the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Anastasius I Dicorus (r. 491-518), was a copper coin worth forty nummi. Various fractions were struck during the 6th and 7th centuries, the half follis, decanummium, and pentanummium being the most important. In the mid 6th century the follis was reckoned 180 to the solidus. How the relationships between the solidus, keration, follis and nummus were affected by the "debasement" of the follis in the later 6th and 7th centuries – the gradual reduction of its weight to less than one-sixth of what it had been in the peak years of Justinian I's reign (527-565) – is a question to which there is not yet any answer. The nummus disappeared completely as a coin, but since the follis and its fractions still bore marks of value expressed as multiples of nummi, these were presumably still thought of as the lowest units in the monetary system.

This monetary system was not as unified in the three and a half centuries between the accession of the Byzantine emperor Leo III (r. 717-741) in 717, marking the end of the "Twenty Years' Anarchy" (695-717), and the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Alexios I Komnenos (r. 1081-1118) in 1092, following his accession in 1081, marking the end of a prolonged period of civil war resulting from the defeat to the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The silver miliaresion introduced by Leo III in 720 and continued by his successors provided a certain element of unity nonetheless. The essential features of the monetary system during this period may be summarized as follows:

Gold coinage – In the East, the semissis and tremissis ceased to be struck, save as ceremonial coins, toward the middle of the 8th century. Henceforward the only gold coin was the solidus. Its fineness remained virtually unchanged down to the 1030's, when debasement set in, and while its weight seems ot have declined very slightly the coin remained one theoretically struck 72 to the Roman pound. In the reign of Nikephoros II Phokas (r. 963-969), however, there began a series of experiments in light-weight nomismata comparable to the light-weight solidi of the 6th and 7th centuries. Of these the light-weight nomisma of 22 keratia, known as a tetarteron, finally gained the day, so that from the late 10th century down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092 one has to distinguish between the full-weight nomisma histamenon and the light-weight nomisma tetarteron.

Things went differently in the West. The solidus and tremissis continued to be struck in mainland Italy as long as the mints of Ravenna and Rome remained in Byzantine hands, i.e., to the mid and late 8th century, respectively. In Sicily they continued down to the reign of Basil I (r. 867-886), and there was even a revival of the use of the semissis in the early 9th century. The weight standard of the western gold coins, however, was substantially less than that of their eastern counterparts, and both on the mainland and in Sicily there was a serious reduction in fineness during the last decades of Byzantine rule. The fate of the fractional gold was related inversely to the presence or absence of a silver coinage, since the miliaresion flourished in the East but was not adopted in the West.

Silver coinage – The history of the silver coinage is that of a new miliaresion, a coin much lighter than the hexagram of the 7th century, which was introduced by Leo III in 720. It lasted, with remarkably few changes in external appearance, down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092. The weight, however, was several times altered, and in its final phase it was badly debased in both weight and fineness. Fractions were struck only under Leo III, of whose half miliaresion specimens are known, and in the middle of the 11th century. Over much of the period the miliaresion was valued as a double keration, i.e., as a coin worth 1/12 of a solidus, so that sums of money are as commonly expressed in terms of nomismata and miliaresia as of nomismata and keratia. But when this ratio became fixed, or how the value of the actual coins changed, in relation to the debased nomisma, during the last decades of their existence, are not known exactly.

Copper Coinage – The evolution of the copper resembled that of the gold in that both underwent a process of drastic simplification and differed from it in that the weight of the follis altered greatly over the centuries.
Historical notes:

Heraclius (born circa 575; crown emperor on 5 October 610; died on 11 February 641)

(To the right) Plaque from a cross: Cherub, Heraclius and Khosrow II, allegory of a (tetramorph) Cherub uniting the attributes of the Four Evangelists Matthew (lion), Mark (ox), Luke (man), and John (eagle), witnessing the submission of the Persian Shah Khosrow II to Heraclius, made by an anonym in the Meuse region circa 1160-1170 using Champlevé enamel over gilt copper, acquired by the Musée du Louvre in 1828 from Pierre Henri Révoil (1776-1842)

One of the greatest of all Byzantine rulers, and the founder of a remarkable dynasty, Heraclius came to power when the Empire seemed close to disintegration. The Persians occupied much of Asia Minor, and soon added Syria and Egypt to their conquests. When they captured Jerusalem, the Holy Cross was carried off to Ctesiphon: this was a particularly heavy blow for the Christian Empire. The Slavs and Avars continued to savage the Balkans and Greece, and even penetrated to the Peloponnese and the Greek islands.

The emperor bided his time and took the first steps to recovery by reorganising the administration of those areas still under his control. Large military zones, called "themes", were created and grants of land were made to the soldiers on condition of hereditary service. This system of military government was gradually extended over the whole empire and formed the backbone of the Mediaeval Byzantine State.

Heraclius began his great counter-offensive in 622, and after six years of bitter fighting, the emperor often leading his troops in person, a miraculous change of fortune had occurred. The Avars were driven back from Constantinople and their fleet and army practically annihilated. The Persians were utterly defeated, and the Sassanian Empire, the great rival of the Romans and the Byzantines, stood in ruins. The Persian Shah Khosrow II was deposed and murdered. Amidst great rejoicings Heraclius restored the Holy Cross to Jerusalem, an act symbolic of the victorious conclusion of the war.

Unfortunately the emperor lived long enough to see the undoing of much of his achievements, for the closing years of the reign witnessed the fast dynamic expansion of Mulsim power. Persia succumbed almost without resistance and the Byzantines lost Syria and Palestine before Heraclius died early in 641, a broken man. Egypt fell to the Arabs soon afterwards, but despite these ultimate disasters the reign of Heraclius marked a turning point in Byzantine history, and his work laid the foundations for future greatness.

Boîte no 04 :

→ Ier millénaire de l'ère « commune » de 0001 à 0500 :

+ AD 0388 - Roman Empire - Siliqua - Theodosius I:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); House of Theodosius (379-395)
Ruler: Theodosius I, sometimes called "the Great" (379-395)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Theodosius I, facing right, seen from three quarters forward, pearl-diademed, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type A" and RCV "Type A")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) DNTHEODO-SIVSPFAVG (D N THEODOSIVS P F AVG)
Traduction: Our Lord (Dominus Noster) Theodosius, dutiful (Pius) and happy (Felix) Emperor (Augustus) (Dominus Noster Theodosius Pius Felix Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Roma (Roman goddess and personification of the city of Rome, and in a wider sense the Empire which she had conquered), seated left on cuirass on a base, holding Victoria (Roman goddess and personification of victory) on a globe with the right hand and a reversed spear with the left hand, the mint mark (TR) and the abbreviation "PS" (standing for "pusulatum", the Latin word for "refined silver") below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) VIRTVSRO-MANORVM (VIRTVS ROMANORVM)
Traduction: Bravery of the Romans
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

Reportedly from the Gussage All Saints hoard, as indicated by an older ticket describing the coin, though not traced to any of the known coins from the hoard

The Gussage All Saints hoard of 662 late Roman silver coins was found on 21 March 2010 by Mr I. West using a metal detector on ploughed land in the parish of Gussage All Saints, Dorset, in southwest England. The hoard was contained in a small earthenware flagon, which was lifted and then taken to the British Museum in London where the coins were then removed, conserved and catalogued, following the application of the 1996 Treasure Act as Treasure case No. 2010T177. The find was recorded in the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS; see https://finds.org.uk) with record IDs DOR-A1CCB1 and IARCH-8D9AB1. It was also included in the list of coin hoards published in 2011 in The Numismatic Chronicle, volume 171, pp. 407–24, as item No. 54. The hoard comprised 653 siliquae and 9 miliarenses. Curiously the miliarenses were found at the top, in the neck of the flagon, thereby suggesting careful packing of the coins into the pot at the time of concealment. The earliest coins were issues of Constantius II (r. 337-361), struck in the period 355-361, and the latest coins were issues of Arcadius (r. 383-408) and Honorius (r. 393-423) from the Milan mint struck in the period 395-402. In addition to coins of these Roman emperors, coins of all the Roman emperors in the period 355-402, Julian (as Caesar from 355 to 360 and Augustus from 361 to 363), Jovian (r. 363-364), Valentinian I (r. 364-375), Valens (r. 364-378), Gratian (r. 367-383), Valentinian II (r. 375-392), Theodosius I (r. 379-395), Magnus Maximus (usurper; r. 383-388), Flavius Victor (usurper; r. 383-388), and Flavius Eugenius (usurper; r. 392-394) were all represented. A small number of coins could not be attributed with certainty to a specific emperor and a few others were unidentifiable issues.

The composition of the hoard by emperor and denomination was: Constantius II (22 siliquae), Julian (52 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Jovian (5 siliquae), Valentinian I (10 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Valens (76 siliquae and 3 miliarenses), Gratian (68 siliquae and 2 miliarenses), Valentinian II (38 siliquae), Theodosius I (70 siliquae), Magnus Maximus (72 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Flavius Victor (9 siliquae), Flavius Eugenius (33 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Arcadius (102 siliquae), Honorius (65 siliquae), and unidentified (31 siliquae, of which 1 from the House of Constantine, 13 from the House of Theodosius and 1 from the House of Valentinian).

The majority of the coins were from the Augusta Treverorum (now Trier; 351 coins) and Mediolanum (now Milan; 136 coins) mints. Other western Roman Empire mints represented were Lugdunum (now Lyon; 45 coins), Arelate (now Arles; 44 coins), Roma (now Rome; 27 coins), and Aquileia (17 coins). In addition there were a small number of eastern Roman Empire mints with Siscia (3 coins), Sirmium (3 coins), Thessalonica (1 coin), Constantinople (4 coins), Nicomedia (2 coins) and Antioch (6 coins).

The composition of the Gussage All Saints hoard is comparable to the much larger and more famous Hoxne hoard, found on 16 November 1992 in Hoxne, Suffolk, in east England. In comparison, the Gussage All Saints hoard has a higher percentage of coins of Trier as opposed to Milan and a higher proportion dating from 378-395, perhaps reflecting its slightly earlier deposition than the Hoxne hoard. Many of the coins have been subject to a low level of clipping, a practice common to British found Siliquae of this period; however the extent of clipping is far less severe than that noted for the Hoxne hoard. This, along with the content of the hoard, suggests a date of deposition of circa 410. The hoard therefore dates from the period when the Roman Empire in the West, beset with the collapse of the Rhine frontier and invasions in Gaul and Italy, relinquished its authority over the British province which was left to its own devices and increasingly vulnerable to Germanic and Irish raiding.

On completion of the Treasure process, one coin (siliqua of Valentinian II from the Siscia mint) was acquired by the British Museum, and the rest of the coins along with the earthenware flagon in which the hoard was found were returned to the finder, who brought them to Spink in 2012. Spink offered each variety of the miliarenses, a selection of the best of the siliquae, a few "large lots" and the flagon at auction on 26 September 2012.

The composition of the hoard revealed 47 siliquae of Theodosius I from the Trier mint struck in the period 388-392/395. These coins include all known varieties (RIC9#94B, RIC9#95B and RIC9#106A). The Spink auction offered some of these coins: 1 as individual lot (Lot 425) and a maximum of 7 as part of a "large lot" (Lot 457). Further coins were acquired by coin dealers, including Antiqua, Ltd., who put some of them for sale in their fixed price Catalogue XVII in 2013, and Roma Numismatics Ltd. However, I have not found any trace of the present coin in auction records that report the Gussage All Saints hoard as provenance.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 388 (not dated) Fineness: 970
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 1.87; Expected: 1.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1/24 Diameter (mm): Measured: 16.5; Expected: 17
Unit: Solidus (Reform of Constantine I; 310/324-395) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Augusta Treverorum Mintage:
Mint mark: TR Emission period: 388-392/395
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 3/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC9#94B,106A; RSC5#57A; RCV5#20459; Cohen8#57; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.9.tri.94B; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.9.tri.106A; MRK#160.18; PAS#https://finds.org.uk/database/search/results/q/2010T177
Varieties:

The siliquae of Theodosius I from the Trier mint struck in the period 388-392/395 can referred to those from the RIC 6th Period (from 28 August 388 to 15 May 392; RIC9#94B) or 7th Period (from 15 May 392 to 17 January 395; RIC9#106A), which are based on mint-marks and portraiture.
Note:

Constantine I (the Great; r. 307–337) made further changes to the monetary system that was reformed by Diocletian (r. 284-305) circa 294. In place of the gold aureus, which was currently being struck 60 to the pound, he introduced into the western provinces a new and lighter coin called the solidus, which was struck 72 to the pound and hence was weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. With the defeat of Constantine I’s eastern rival Licinius (r. 308–324) production of the solidus became universal throughout the Roman Empire. The aureus was still occasionally struck thereafter, but its issue was generally confined to the celebration of special occasions. Two gold fractional denominations accompanied the solidus, though they were never produced in the same quantities as the larger piece. The semissis was the equivalent of a half solidus (12 siliquae), while the 9-siliqua piece (also called the one and a half scripulum) was the equivalent of three-eighths of a solidus. In 383 Theodosius I introduced the gold tremissis, or one-third solidus (8 siliquae), which quickly replaced the curious and seemingly inconvenient 9-siliqua piece. The tremissis became one of the commonest denominations in the 5th century and beyond.

In 325 Constantine I resumed production of the siliqua (or argenteus), which had been introduced by Diocletian and had lapsed after about 310. At the same time he introduced the larger silver miliarense, which was one-third heavier than the siliqua (four scrupula instead of three) and the same weight as the gold solidus (4.55 g). A few years later, after the death of Constantine I, a heavier version of the miliarense was introduced. This "heavy miliarenses" was struck 60 to the pound, the same weight as the old gold aureus (5.46 g). Both versions of the miliarense remained in issue over a considerable period of time, extending even into the period of the Byzantine Empire. The siliqua, however, soon underwent some fundamental changes. About 357 Constantius II (r. 337-361), the last surviving son of Constantine I, reduced the weight of the siliqua from 96 to the pound (about 3.41 g or three scrupula) to 144 to the pound (about 2.27 grams or two scrupula). In consequence, the lighter version of the miliarense now became a double siliqua.
Historical notes:

(Flavius) Theodosius I (born on 11 January 347 at Cauca in Gallaecia in the north-west of Spain; proclaimed emperor on 19 January 379; died on 17 January 395 at Mediolanum)

(To the right) St. Ambrose barring Theodosius from Milan Cathedral, painted by Sir Anthony van Dyck (1599-1641) circa 1619-1620. This painting depicts St. Ambrose (circa 339-397), bishop of Milan, stopping the emperor Theodosius I (circa 346–395) and his retinue from entering Milan Cathedral, as punishment for his massacre of the people of Thessalonica, who had murdered the Gothic "magister militum" Butheric (?-390) in 390.

Flavius Theodosius was the namesake son of the celebrated principal general, appointed "magister equitum" by Valentinian I (364-375) from 369 until his execution at Carthage circa 375. Theodosius thus had little reason to love the House of Valentinian and this may well have influenced his future behaviour. On his father's downfall, the future emperor retired to his Spanish estates and settled down to private life. He married Aella Flaccilla (circa 355-386), a fellow Spaniard, about 376. The following year a son, Arcadius (circa 377-408), was born to the couple, and a second son, Honorius (384-423), was added eight years later.

With the death of Valens (364-378), the Roman emperor in the East, in the catastrophic defeat by the Goths of the eastern Roman army at Hadrianopolis (on 9 August 378), Gratian (367-383), the Roman Emperor in the West, was faced with a dilemma. Clearly the throne of Constantinople needed to be filled promptly by a competent replacement. Gratian's younger brother and co-emperor Valentinian II (375-392) was still only eight-year old and obviously unequal to the daunting task. For the time being, Gratian decided to recall Theodosius from his provincial retirement and place him in command of the seriously threatened Danube frontier, with the rank of "magister equitum", which his father had borne under the rule of Valentinian I. He had already gained considerable military experience on his father's staff during the latter's brilliant campaigns against the Picts and the Scots in Britain in 368. Having achieved a measure of success over the invaders, Theodosius was summoned to Sirmium where he was invested by Gratian with the imperial purple and appointed ruler of the Roman emperor in the East in 379. The dynasty which he founded was to rule the eastern Roman Empire for the following seven decades, though unfortunately it did not produce any other rulers of note throughout this period.

The sixteen-year reign of Theodosius I was much troubled by western usurpations, from Magnus Maximus (383-388) and his son (Flavius) Victor (383-388) and Flavius Eugenius (392-394), the quelling of both of them required the emperor's personal intervention. Gratian had been overthrown by Magnus Maximus in the summer of 383 and the young Valentinian II was hardly in a position to avenge his brother. Theodosius, whose relations with Gratian had been steadily deteriorating, may not have been sorry to witness his removal from the political scene at the hands of a third party. Initially he tolerated the rule of the usurper in most of the western provinces and even struck some very rare coin issues in his name in the East. The authority of Valentinian II, the legitimate Roman Emperor in the West, was mostly confined to Italy, a state of affairs which prevailed until 387. At this point Magnus Maximus, clearly wishing to make himself sole Roman Emperor in the West and an equal partner with Theodosius I, invaded the peninsula. Valentinian II and his family were obliged to flee to Thessalonica and place themselves under the protection of Theodosius I. During this time Theodosius I met and fell in love with Valentinian II's sister Galla (circa 365-394) and the imperial nuptials were celebrated in 388 in return for a promise by Theodosius I to invade Italy and remove Magnus Maximus from power. Good to his word, Theodosius I defeated his adversary at Aquileia and executed him shortly thereafter. He may have been reluctant to do this as Magnus Maximus was a kinsman and would have been a far more competent western colleague than Valentinian II, but he made the sacrifice for the sake of his new wife. Valentinian II now returned to the West, but instead of becoming his brother-in-law's full colleague in the government of the Roman Empire, his authority was now restricted to Gaul. Theodosius I considered him too inexperienced to take on this responsibility and placed him under the guardianship of the Frankish "magister militum" Arbogastes (circa 375-394). Theodosius I remained in Italy for some three years while he endeavoured to settle affairs in the western Roman Empire, long subject to the rule of an usurper, but in 391 he returned to Constantinople. Arbogastes saw this as an opportunity to assert his own claims to power and his arrogant behaviour towards the now 21-year-old Valentinian II led the young man to despair of the hopelessness of his situation and to take his own life in 392. After an "interregnum" of over three months Arbogastes now nominated Flavius Eugenius, a former teacher of Latin grammar and rhetoric, to be his puppet-emperor. The empress Galla, obviously much distressed at news of her brother's death, urged her husband to take prompt action against the rebel regime. Perhaps sensing that his health was beginning to fall, Theodosius I raised his ten-year-old younger son Honorius to the rank of Augustus before organising another invasion of the West. On 6 September 394 he defeated the combined forces of the usurpers, probably at the battle of the Frigidus in Pannonia; Flavius Eugenius was executed and Arbogastes took his own life. Little more than four months later, Theodosius I himself died of dropsy (oedema) in his fiftieth year, leaving his inexperienced and incompetent sons Arcadius and Honorius to divide the Empire between them.

An accurate assessment of the abilities and achievements of Theodosius I is rendered difficult by the complexity of his character and the many seeming inconsistencies in his actions. A deeply devout Christian, he championed the cause of orthodoxy and was very intolerant towards "heretical" beliefs. It seems that the title "the Great" was due to his devout Christianity rather than having a secular basis. His religious views were greatly influenced by the powerful bishop Ambrose of Milan (circa 339-397), a patron saint of Milan and of beekeepers, and pagans and paganism received particularly severe treatment. He refused to allow the restoration of the Altar of Victory, which had been removed from the Roman Curia (Senate House) by Gratian in 382. Great controversy surrounded this issue and the altar's removal from its traditional home (since the time of Augustus) became symbolic of the final demise of paganism. It was briefly restored to its place under the usurper Flavius Eugenius but after that there is no further record of it in history. Theodosius I was the last ruler to exercise effective control over the entire Empire and the era of decline was ushered in with the succession in 395 of his two sons, Arcadius in the East and Honorius in the West, neither of whom had any aptitude for leadership.

+ AD 0321 - Roman Empire - AE3 (Billon Nummus) - Constantine I (the Great):

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); House of Constantine (305-363)
Ruler: Constantine I (the Great) (307-337)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Constantine I, facing right, seen from three quarters forward, laureate, cuirassed (RIC "Type B5" and RCV "Type B")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) CONSTANTINVSPAVG (CONSTANTINVS P AVG)
Traduction: Constantinus, dutiful (Pius) Emperor (Augustus) (Constantinus Pius Augustus)
Designer: -
