Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Banded globe, three stars above, set on altar, the inscription "VO-/TIS/XX" (standing for "Votis Vicennalibus", a Latin expression which can be translated into English as "Vows (prayers) for twenty years of the reign of the emperor") on the front, divided abbreviation "C R" (standing for "Claritas Reipublicæ"?, a Latin expression which can be translated into English as "Splendours of the State") on the sides, the abbreviation "PLG" (standing for "pusulatum", the Latin word for "refined silver", and "Lugdunum") below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) BEATATRANQVILLITAS (BEATA TRANQVILLITAS)
Traduction: Blessed peace (calm)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 01h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 321 (not dated) Fineness: 15
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 2.89; Expected: 3
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1/180 Diameter (mm): Expected: 19
Unit: Solidus (Reform of Constantine I; 310/324-395) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Lugdunum Mintage:
Mint mark: LG Emission period: 321
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients MS; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5; Attribute(s): silvering (NGC) Variety: None
References: Bastien#99; RIC7#128; RCV4#16179; Cohen7#23; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.7.lug.128; MRK#136.20
Varieties:

None
Note:

The coinage of Constantine I (the Great; r. 307-337), known as Constantine, is complex and its accurate interpretation presents serious challenges. The radical changes made by Constantine in the monetary system began quite early in his reign, circa 310, with the replacement of the Diocletianic gold aureus, struck 60 to the pound, by the lighter gold solidus, struck 72 to the pound. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. However, at this time there were relatively few mints under direct Constantinian control so the reform was initially confined to the Gallic mints, later to be extended to Italy following Constantine’s defeat of (Marcus Aurelius Valerius) Maxentius (circa 283-312; r. 306-312) in 312. As the territories of the Roman emperor in the West expanded so did the production of the solidus. In the East, however, (Galerius Valerius) Maximinus (Daza; circa 270-313; r. 310-313) and (Valerius Licinianus) Licinius (circa 265-325; r. 308-324) continued striking aurei, the latter right down to his defeat in 324, so for a considerable period of time a confusing situation existed with two gold denominations, of similar appearance but different values, circulating side by side. It hardly helped that Constantine struck some solidi in Licinius' name, while the Roman emperor in the East issued aurei in the name of his western colleague. Two fractional gold denominations also existed, though they are very rare in comparison with the full-weight solidus: the semissis, which was the equivalent to a half solidus, and the 9-siliqua piece (also called the one and a half scripulum), which was equivalent to three-eighths of a solidus. The last was a denomination of uncertain significance which, before the end of the 4th century, was replaced by the slightly lighter and more convenient gold tremissis, or one-third solidus.

Production of coined silver was very insignificant in the early part of Constantine’s reign. The Diocletianic argenteus, struck 96 to the pound, did not long survive the end of the First Tetrarchy in 305, though at Roma (now Rome) and Ostia (the port of Rome) Maxentius extended production until late in his reign. Constantine abandoned the argenteus early, though in 312 he produced at the Trier mint an experimental denomination in billon (25% silver), which usually goes by the name of centenionalis, implying that it was tariffed at 100 to the gold solidus. This coin was also struck in the names of his co-emperors Maximinus and Licinius, each ruler having a distinct reverse type (two Victories for Constantine, Sol in quadriga for Maximinus, and Jupiter on eagle for Licinius). It is noteworthy that Constantine did not adopt the pagan Hercules as his reverse type, this being the year of his "vision of the cross". The billon centenionalis was soon abandoned, though at the mints of Ticinum and Aquileia Constantine did produce some very rare silver multiples, or medallions, which appear to have been on the weight standard of 50 to the pound. The reintroduction of regular silver issues did not occur until the year following the downfall of Licinius, in 325. At this time a denomination of the same weight as the Diocletianic argenteus (96 to the pound), though of thinner fabric, went into production. It is normally referred to as a siliqua, though in reality it was a revival of the argenteus. A larger silver coin, the miliarense, was also introduced by Constantine at this time. Its name, implying the numeral 1000, would seem to indicate that it was either a fraction or a multiple of other units. Being on the same weight standard as the solidus (72 to the pound) the miliarensis was worth 1/18th of the gold coin, while the siliqua was valued at 3⁄4 of the miliarensis. Both new silver denominations were to have long histories extending into early Byzantine times.

The Constantinian billon coinage presents further complexities. At the time of Constantine’s elevation to the rank of Caesar in 306 the Diocletianic follis was still being struck at its full weight of circa 10 g. The following year saw the commencement of its steady decline in size and weight and by 313 it averaged only slightly over 4 g. Various billon fractions were also produced, though not on a regular basis and all are scarce or rare today. Constantine finally abandoned the follis about 318/319, by which time its average weight had fallen to less than 3.5 g. In its place he introduced a new billon coin weighing about 3 g and displaying a range of non-pagan reverse types. In appearance, the coin closely resembles the experimental Trier centenionalis, containing 25% silver, which was issued by Constantine in 312. The new coin even seems to have derived its name from this prototype, despite the fact that its silver content was probably little more than that of the follis which it replaced. Meanwhile in the East, the Roman emperor Licinius continued the production of the traditional follis, still retaining the pagan Jupiter as its principal reverse type. But following Licinius' downfall in 324 and Constantine's acquisition of his eastern mints, the Constantinian denominations were issued uniformly throughout the Empire, thus ending what must have been a rather confusing situation with the gold and billon coinages. In 330 the weight of the centenionalis was reduced from circa 3 g to circa 2.5 g, and in the year preceding Constantine’s death it fell even further to about 1.7 g. This situation was to prevail until 348 when the billon coinage was reformed by Constantine's two surviving sons, Constantius II (317-361; r. 337-361) and Constans (320 or 323-350; r. 337-350).

In addition to coinage in his own name, Constantine produced issues for his wife (Flavia Maxima) Fausta (circa 290-326), his mother (Flavia Julia) Helena (circa between 246 and 248-330), his four sons, Crispus (circa 300-326), Constantine II, Constantius II (317-361; r. 337-361), and Constans, who all served as Caesar during his reign, and his nephews (Flavius) Dalmatius (or Delmatius; ?-337) and (Flavius) Hannibalianus (or Hanniballianus; ?-337). A special coinage commencing in 330 was struck to commemorate the dedication of Constantinople and it included issues honouring the old imperial capital of Rome. At the beginning of his reign Constantine naturally issued coins commemorating his late father, (Flavius Valerius) Constantius (later Constantius I; circa 250-306; r. 305-306), and in 318 a remarkable series of reduced folles and fractions was produced honouring Divus (Marcus Aurelius) Claudius II "Gothicus" (214-270; r. 268-70), who Constantine claimed as an ancestor, his father-in-law (Marcus Aurelius Valerius) Maximianus (circa 250-circa 310; r. 286-305), known as Maximian and nicknamed Herculius, and his father Constantius. This was in the nature of a "pedigree" issue at a time when he was vying with Licinius for pre-eminence in the Roman world. Following Constantine's death in 337 a remarkable series of posthumous coins was struck for him, principally under Constantius II in the East, but also under Constantine II in the West. Constans appears to have disapproved of the issue because of the surprising inclusion of the pagan title "Divus" (abbreviated to "DV") preceding Constantine’s name. It was the last such coinage to be produced.

The imperial minting establishment underwent a number of changes during the long reign of Constantine. Initially, the western mints were of prime importance to him as his power was centred in Gaul. Augusta Treverorum (now Trier), Lugdunum (now Lyon), and Londinium (now London) were his principal establishments down to his victory over Maxentius in 312, after which the Italian mints of Ticinum (now Pavia), Aquileia, and Roma also came under his control. Maxentius’ creation at Ostia also operated briefly under Constantine until its staff was transferred to a new Gallic mint at Arelate (now Arles). Carthage, under Maximian and Maxentius, also struck briefly for Constantine as Caesar prior to its closure in 307. The important mint of Siscia passed under Constantinian control in 316, in the early stages of the first civil was against Licinius. Serdica (now Sofia) struck briefly for Constantine as Caesar in 306-307 and again briefly for Constantine as Augustus in 313-314, just prior to its closure by Licinius. Sirmium was opened by Constantine in 320 and remained operational for about six years. Thessalonica, like Siscia, passed under the control of Constantine at the time of the First Licinian War in 316-317 and remained an important mint down to the end of his reign. After almost four decades of operation the mint of Londinium was closed by Constantine in 325, a victim of the vast expansion of minting capacity inherited by Constantine after his victory over Licinius in 324. Another closure at this time was the northern Italian mint of Ticinum. Its final issues appear to date to the end of 326 and as the first coinage from Constantine's new foundation of Constantinople are of about the same period it may well be that the staff of Ticinum was transferred to the new eastern capital. Constantinople, of course, was to become a mint of immense importance as befitted the capital of the Byzantine Empire, with issues stretching in a virtually unbroken sequence for more than a millennium down to the 15th century. The eastern mints of Licinius, from Heraclea in Thrace to Alexandria in Egypt, all passed to Constantine with the defeat of the eastern emperor in 324. All remained very active until the end of Constantine's reign and, as an important imperial residence, the issues of Nicomedia were of special significance, at least down to the time of the dedication of the new eastern capital of Constantinople in 330.
Historical notes:

(Flavius Valerius) Constantinus I, known as Constantine I (born on 27 February, probably 272 at Naissus in Moesia Superior in the south-east of Serbia; proclaimed emperor on 25 July 306; died on 22 May 337 at Achyron, near Nicomedia)

(To the right) Statue of Constantine I (the Great), designed by Philip (Henry Christopher) Jackson (1944-Present) in 1998, erected in the same year, and standing since then, outside the South Transept of York Minster in York, near the basilica of the Roman legionary fortress of Eboracum (now York), where Constantine I (the Great) was proclaimed emperor by his army, in 306

The reign of Constantine I (the Great; r. 307-337), known as Constantine, marked one of the principal turning-points in the history of the Roman Empire, the outcome of which still resonates today throughout the Western world. Flavius Valerius Constantinus was the eldest son of (Flavius Valerius) Constantius (later Constantius I; circa 250-306; r. 305-306) by his mistress, or first wife, Flavia Julia Helena (later the Empress Helena; between 246 and 248-330; r. 324-330). He later claimed descent through his father from the Emperor (Marcus Aurelius) Claudius II "Gothicus" (214-270; r. 268-70), but the assertion was politically motivated and is unlikely to have been true. Like his father, he adopted a military career and with Constantius' advancement to imperial rank in 293 the young Constantine was appointed a tribune at the court of (Gaius Aurelius Valerius) Diocletianus (between 242 and 245-311/12; r. 284-305), known as Diocletian, in Nicomedia. In the following years, he served under the eastern Caesar Galerius (Valerius Maximianus; circa 258-311; r. 305-311) in the latter’s campaigns against the Persians (298) and the Sarmatians (299). During this period he probably became acquainted with his future rival, (Valerius Licinianus) Licinius (circa 265-325; r. 308-324), who was a friend and protégé of Galerius.

At the time of the joint abdications of Diocletian and (Marcus Aurelius Valerius) Maximianus (circa 250-circa 310; r. 286-305), known as Maximian and nicknamed Herculius, in 305, Constantine was still at Nicomedia. The new Roman emperor in the East, Galerius, wished to keep him there in order to ensure peaceful relations with his western colleague Constantius I. But the latter was insistent that Constantine should join him on a military expedition to Britain necessitated by unrest on the northern frontier. Constantius’ health was beginning to fail and he clearly wanted his son to have an army behind him should his illness prove fatal. Galerius had little choice but to release Constantine. On his long journey westward he took elaborate precautions to avoid assassination at the hands of agents of Galerius or of the western Caesar (Flavius Valerius) Severus (later Severus II; circa 250-307; r. 306-307). Reunited with his father at Boulogne in Gaul, Constantine accompanied him on the gruelling campaign against the Picts. As Constantius’ health further deteriorated his son took command of the army with whom he rapidly became very popular, doubtless all part of his father’s plan. At the legionary fortress of Eboracum (now York) on 25 July 306 Constantius died: the Emperor (Lucius) Septimius Severus (145-211; r. 193-211) had passed away in the same place just 95 years before. The death of Constantius after less than fifteen months of rule was to have devastating consequences for the delicate balance of power created by Diocletian’s tetrarchy system and was ultimately to lead to its total collapse. Eighteen years later the Roman Empire was, once again, to come under the rule of a single Augustus in the person of Constantius’ son, Constantine I (the Great). However, at the time of his father’s death, and for a number of years afterwards, Constantine’s position was not strong and, like the first Augustus three and a half centuries before, he had to tread warily in his dealings with more powerful rivals. But by the skilful use of alliances he gradually strengthened his position until he could finally assert his supremacy in the complex political arena of the early 4th century.

Constantine’s soldiers in Britain immediately proclaimed him emperor in succession to his late father, but Constantine "refused". Inevitably, this would have led to civil war with Galerius, so Constantine accepted the junior imperial rank of Caesar under the new Roman emperor in the West, Severus II, thus preserving the form of the tetrarchy. When Severus II’s authority in Rome was challenged by the uprising of (Marcus Aurelius Valerius) Maxentius (circa 283-312; r. 306-312) (soon to be joined by his father, the former Roman emperor in the West, Maximian) Constantine did not come to the assistance of his imperial colleague. Instead, he remained aloof while Severus II was defeated by the rebel alliance. Galerius’ subsequent invasion of Italy also failed to overcome the insurgency and Galerius was obliged to beat a hasty retreat. Again, Constantine had remained indifferent to the conflict and was even negotiating an alliance with the rebel regime. In the early spring of 307 Maximian paid a visit to the court of the western Caesar in Gaul and the resulting treaty was sealed by the marriage of Constantine to Maximian’s daughter (Flavia Maxima) Fausta (circa 290-326), sister of Maxentius. In the late summer, Constantine adopted the title and rank of Augustus, though he was not accepted as such in the East until 310. The tetrarchy system was now fatally disrupted. Galerius made one final attempt to restore it towards the close of 308 when he convened the "Conference of Carnuntum". But his high-handed elevation of his friend Licinius to the rank of Augustus, over the heads of Constantine and his adopted son (Galerius Valerius) Maximinus (Daza; circa 270-313; r. 310-313), doomed the effort to failure. In order to appease them, Galerius offered the empty title of filii Augustorum ("sons of the Augusti"), but this was clearly unacceptable and by 310 both were regarded as full Augusti throughout the Empire. Before the "Conference of Carnuntum", Maximian had quarrelled with his son Maxentius and had been obliged to flee to Constantine in Gaul, where he remained for the following two years. In 310 he foolishly led an abortive uprising against his son-in-law which was revealed by his own daughter, Constantine’s wife Fausta. Maximian was either forced to commit suicide or was executed for treason.

Galerius’ death from natural causes in 311, left only three legitimate Augusti (Constantine, Licinius, and Maximinus) and the usurper Maxentius in Italy. Constantine now decided it was time to eliminate his brother-in-law Maxentius and made preparations for war. He invaded Italy in the late summer of 312 and advanced on Rome, where Maxentius had decided to make his stand. The battle of the Milvian Bridge, on the sixth anniversary of Maxentius’ rule (28 October), was chiefly notable for Constantine’s supposed "vision of the cross" on the previous night. Whatever the truth of this story, something certainly revolutionised his religious policy at this time, bringing about the rapid demise of belief in the old pagan gods and goddesses and its replacement by devotion to the teachings of the Christian Church. Meanwhile in the East, there was a growing rivalry between Licinius and Maximinus. The latter felt himself threatened when Constantine and Licinius jointly promulgated at Milan the edict on religious toleration and had sealed their accord by the marriage of Licinius to Constantine’s half-sister, (Flavia Julia) Constantia (after 293-circa 330; r. 313-324). Maximinus invaded Licinius’ territory in the early spring of 313 and was totally defeated in a pitched battle fought on 30 April. Out of the political chaos resulting from the collapse of Diocletian’s elaborately conceived tetrarchy system just two emperors now remained as potential rivals, Constantine in the West and Licinius in the East. Remarkably, this fragile status quo was maintained for the following thirteen years, though there were frequent disagreements between the Augusti and on two occasions (316-17 and 324) war was actually declared. During the First Licinian War the Roman emperor in the East audaciously elevated one of his generals, (Aurelius) Valerius Valens (?-317; r. 316-317), to the rank of co-emperor to replace Constantine. This bold move was to cost Licinius most of his European territory when peace was eventually patched up between the two rivals, while the unfortunate Valens had to pay with his life. Constantine now kept a close watch on the activities of Licinius and was clearly biding his time, awaiting an ideal opportunity for the removal of his troublesome colleague. The chance came in 322/3 when Gothic invaders entered Thrace and were promptly confronted by Constantine, who happened to be closer to the affected area than Licinius. Thrace being within his sphere of influence, Licinius interpreted this action as a declaration of war, just as Constantine had intended. Hostilities again broke out between the rivals and this time Constantine was decisively victorious, Licinius being deposed from power shortly after the disastrous battle of Chrysopolis (18 September 324). As in the case of the previous civil war, Licinius had elevated a co-emperor, Martinianus (?-325; r. 324), known as Martinian, to assist him in the struggle against Constantine. Following Chrysopolis, both dethroned emperors were imprisoned and the following year they were executed, despite Constantine’s promise to Licinius’ wife Constantia to spare their lives.

After eighteen years of imperial power Constantine at last found himself sole Augustus, the first ruler to be in this position since Diocletian had succeeded (Marcus Aurelius) Carinus (?-285; r. 283-285) in the spring of 285. He remained sole Augustus for the next thirteen years, until his death in 337 at the age of 65. During this final phase of his reign he focused on a number of domestic issues, though he remained militarily active right up to the end and was even preparing for war against the Sasanid Persians at the time his death. Having espoused Christianity as early as 312, Constantine now made efforts to secure the unity of the Church through convening the Council of Nicaea (the First Ecumenical Council) in 325. This was to establish an orthodox belief formula which all Christians were supposed to accept. The seeds of dissent in the new state religion were thus sown at a very early stage, as many believers followed the teachings of the heretical Alexandrian priest Arius (250 or 256-336). Another event of momentous importance in the closing years of Constantine’s reign was the foundation of a new imperial capital in the East, on the site of the ancient Greek city of Byzantium on the European side of the Bosporus. The decision to found the city of Constantinopolis was probably made as early as 324, just after the defeat of Licinius, though the official dedication only took place on 11 May 330. In future ages the city was to be of immense importance as the capital of the Christian Roman (later Byzantine) Empire and the bastion of European Christendom against the western spread of Islam.

Constantine also gave careful attention to the question of the succession, though his precise intentions in this regard are difficult to ascertain. It is possible that he may have been endeavouring to restore the tetrarchy system on the Diocletianic model, illogical as that may seem in the light of Constantine’s own experiences in his rise to power. Constantine had four sons, Crispus (circa 300-326), by his first wife Minervina, Constantine II (316-340; r. 337-340), probably illegitimate, Constantius II (317-361; r. 337-361), and Constans (320 or 323-350; r. 337-350), by Fausta. He also had two daughters, (Flavia Valeria) Constantina (between 307 and 317-354) and Helena (?-360, r. 360). The picture is further complicated by the existence of three half-brothers and three half-sisters, his father’s issue by his second wife (Flavia Maximiana) Theodora (?-337; r. 305-306), the step-daughter of Maximian. One of these half-brothers, (Flavius) Dalmatius (or Delmatius; after 293-337), had two sons, one named after himself (Flavius) Dalmatius (or Delmatius; ?-337), the other named (Flavius) Hannibalianus (or Hanniballianus; ?-337) after an uncle. These two brothers were thus nephews of Constantine. Crispus, who was probably the most capable of Constantine’s sons, was eliminated early from the succession when he was executed in 326, having been found guilty of treason. The circumstances of this tragic incident remain unclear, but it appears in some way to have involved Constantine’s second wife Fausta. The empress doubtless saw Crispus as a threat to the advancement of her own two sons, Constantius II and Constans, and perhaps fabricated the evidence against her stepson. Filled with remorse for his hasty action against his eldest son, Constantine then condemned his wife to death and she was suffocated in a hot bath. Constantine’s second eldest son, also named Constantine, was born in 317 and was almost immediately raised to the rank of Caesar. His half-brother Crispus and their cousin Licinius II (315-circa 326), also called Licinius Junior, son of the Roman Emperor in the East, Licinius, were similarly elevated on the same day (1 March). It appears that Constantine II must have been illegitimate as Fausta gave birth to Constantius II just six months later. Constans, the youngest son of Constantine, was born either in 320 or 323. Both of the sons of Fausta were proclaimed Caesar, in 324 and 333, respectively. In 337 Constantine I thus had three living sons bearing the rank of Caesar; but two years earlier he had also elevated his nephew Dalmatius (Delmatius) to the same rank and had granted Dalmatius’ brother, Hannibalianus, the extraordinary title of "Rex regum" ("King of kings") with authority over Pontus and Armenia. Doubtless, this represented an initial move in the projected campaign against the Sasanid Persians. Death may have come suddenly and unexpectedly to Constantine I on 22 May, but in truth he left behind him a potentially explosive situation with regard to the succession – no fewer than five contenders for power, all of whom were in their teens or early twenties. Given Constantine’s own experiences in asserting his supremacy over numerous rivals for imperial office, it is hard to imagine how he could have thought that his arrangements for the succession would have a happy outcome. On his deathbed, at Achyron, near Nicomedia, the first Christian emperor was baptised by the Arian bishop Eusebius (between 260 and 265-339). Like his mother, (Flavia Julia) Helena (circa between 246 and 248-330), he was later to be declared a Christian saint and their feast day is still celebrated in the Orthodox Church on 21st May. Constantine is also regarded as the Thirteenth Apostle, a measure of the Church’s recognition of the vital role he had played in the advancement of Christianity from a persecuted minority sect to a world religion.

+ AD 0276 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus (Aurelianianus) - Probus:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Probus (276-282)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Probus, facing right, seen from three quarters forward, radiate, cuirassed (Bastien "Type B", RIC "Type F", and RCV "Type A"), with a knot on the left shoulder retaining a military cloak
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) IMPCMAVRPROBVSAVG (IMP C M AVR PROBVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Caesar Marcus Aurelius Probus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Caesar Marcus Aurelius Probus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Laetitia (Roman goddess and personification of joy), draped, holding a wreath with the right hand and an anchor (in the form of a stylised staff) with the left hand, standing left on a base, the officina mark (IIII) below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) LAETITIAAVG (LAETITIA AVG)
Traduction: Joy of the Emperor (Laetitia Augusti)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin has been sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was Ch MS; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5; silvering. The grade that it received was MS★; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5; silvering, which met somehow my expectation.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 01h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R3 Material: Silver
Year: 276 (not dated) Fineness: 45
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.07; Expected: 3.7
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 22
Unit: Antoninianus (Reform of Caracalla; 215-301) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Lugdunum Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 276
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients MS★; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5; Attribute(s): silvering (NGC) Variety: LAETITIA AVG
References: Bastien#173; RIC5_2#31; RCV3#11990; Cohen6#324; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.5.pro.31; MRK#112.45
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the lettering on the reverse read "LAETITIA AVGVSTI" (Bastien#172 and Cohen6#329) and "LAETITIA AVG" (Bastien#173 and Cohen6#324).

This coin is classified as RIC Period I (mint-marks as numerals and portraits resembling Florianus) and Bastien Emission 2, 2nd Phase, November to December 276 (portraits resembling Florianus).
Note:

In 274, Aurelian undertook an important reform of the coinage which, under his immediate predecessors, had suffered a catastrophic decline. Three years earlier his eradication of abuses in the practices of the Rome mint had led to a revolt of the moneyers which seems to have brought about the temporary closure of the facility. Between 271 and 274 an interim improvement in the quality of the billon coinage saw a small increase in the average weight of the coins and an insistence on the employment of higher standards in their production. Finally, the full reform of 274 saw an increase in the average weight of the antoninianus to about 3.85 g and an improvement in its silver content to 4.5%. The reformed antoninianus also normally bore the mark of value XXI (or KA in Greek numerals at some mints), which is usually taken to mean that the coin was worth 1/20th of its equivalent weight in pure silver. Some scholars have preferred to assign the somewhat awkward name of "aurelianianus" (or "Aurelianus") to the reformed antoninianus. However, there seems no pressing need to depart from the traditional nomenclature simply because Aurelian had enacted a much-needed reform of a long-established denomination that had undergone a series of debasements over the preceding decades. Other denominations featured in Aurelian's reformed coinage were a smaller billon piece with laureate portrait, probably a denarius; a laureate bronze coin, usually regarded as a sestertius of reduced weight; and a larger radiate bronze, probably a reduced double sestertius.

With the restoration of the Empire to its full territorial extent during Aurelian’s reign, the system of mints was inevitably expanded. In Italy Rome was initially augmented by Milan, but in 274 the mint establishment was transferred to nearby Ticinum. With the conquest of the Gallic Empire in the same year the rebel mints of Cologne and Mainz (or Trier) were closed and were replaced by Lugdunum, which had not been active since the rebellion of Clodius Albinus eight decades before. In the militarily important region of the Balkans the products of Siscia were augmented by a new establishment at Serdica, noted for its idiosyncratic obverse legends, and also by a mint the precise location of which has yet to be determined. Cyzicus continued to be active in Asia Minor while Antioch, liberated from the control of the Palmyrene Empire in 272, resumed its role as the major producer of currency in the eastern Mediterranean area. It was assisted by a new mint opened by Aurelian about 273 and attributed to the Phoenician city of Tripolis.

The vast antoninianus coinage of Probus is of exceptional interest and the system of mint marks employed is of considerable complexity. Another interesting feature of Probus' coinage, which provided a limited foretaste of future developments under the Tetrarchy, was the expansion of mint marks in some issues to include the initial letter or letters of the mint name. But perhaps the most noteworthy characteristic, on antoniniani (and aurei), was the dramatic proliferation of obverse bust varieties, unmatched by the coinage of any other reign, to include numerous left-facing military types and others showing the emperor in an elaborate imperial mantle and holding an eagle-tipped sceptre. Such busts had appeared under previous emperors and were to recur occasionally in succeeding reigns, but they were always limited issues, which are rare today. Under Probus, however, they formed part of the regular output of many of the mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Aurelius) Probus (born circa 232 in Sirmium; proclaimed emperor in 276; died in autumn 282 near Sirmium)

(To the right) Bust of Probus, sculpted by an unknown artist between 276 and 282, displayed in the Hall of the Emperors of the Palazzo Nuovo in Rome

Probus, the son of a military tribune, had a brilliant military career spanning the reigns of Valerian (253-260) to Tacitus (275-276) and attained the highest eminence as a general. It was under the reign of Aurelian (270-275) that he became one of the premier general of the Empire. Under the reign Tacitus he received the supreme command in the East, a powerful and highly prestigious posting. Soon after the death of Tacitus, Probus was proclaimed emperor by his troops. Probus had little difficulty in overcoming the feeble opposition of Florianus, the younger half-brother of the late-emperor Tacitus, who had assumed the imperial power, and his election was confirmed by the Senate in 276.

Probus then proceeded to repel a series of barbarian threats to the imperial frontiers: Alamannic and Frankish invaders were expelled across the Rhine frontier; the Burgundians and Vandals were defeated in Raetia; the Sarmatians and the Scythians were crushed in Thrace; the Pamphylian looters and pirates were eliminated in Asia Minor; the Blemmyes invasions were stopped in Africa. By 280 he was able to turn his attention to the East where his primary objective was to confront the Sasanid Persians. However, he had to face the usurpations of Saturninus, Bonosus and Proculus. In the meantime, he signed a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Bahram II (?-293; r. 274-293). Having triumphed over all his opponents, Probus returned to Rome in 281 and celebrated his victories. Before preparing a new expedition against the Sasanid Persians, he fell victim to the wrath of his own soldiers while supervising a land reclamation project near Sirmium in 282.

+ AD 0212 - Roman Empire - Denarius - Caracalla:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Civil Wars and the Early Severans (193-217)
Ruler: Caracalla (198-217)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Laureate head of Caracalla, bearded, facing right
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 05h) ANTONINVSPIVS AVGBRIT (ANTONINVS PIVS AVG BRIT)
Traduction: Antoninus Pius, Emperor (Augustus), victor in Britannia (Antoninus Pius Augustus Britannicus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Elephant, cuirassed, walking right, on a base
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) PMTRPXVCOSIIIPP (P M TR P XV COS III P P), with "XV" re-engraved over "XIIII"
Traduction: Greatest of the Pontifices, holder of tribunician power for the 15th time, consul for the third time, father of the patria (Pontifex Maximus, holder of tribunician power for the 15th time, Consul Tertium, Pater Patriae)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was XF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5. The grade that it received was Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5, which exceeded my expectation.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 212 (not dated) Fineness: 515
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.27; Expected: 3.2
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 19; Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 212
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC4_1#199; RCV2#6827; RSC3#208; Cohen4#208; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.crl.199; MRK#51.85
Varieties:

None
Note:

As coinage in the name of Caracalla did not commence until 196 his issues from the temporary eastern mints are limited to those of Laodicea in Syria and the enigmatic cistophori from the unidentified city in Asia. After the closure of Laodicea in 202 all of Caracalla's subsequent coinage is from the mint of Rome, eastern issues not resuming until the rebellion of Elagabalus against Caracalla's successor Macrinus. The portraiture displayed on Caracalla's coinage is of considerable interest, as it follows closely his physical development from a young boy of eight through adolescence and early manhood, to the full maturity of his final years. That of his younger brother shows a similar progression, though in his case it does not become so fully developed. Geta being only in his 23rd year at the time of his murder.

In 215, during his sole reign, Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.
Historical notes:

Marcus Aurelius Antoninus (born on 4 April 188 in Lugdunum; accession on 28 January 198; died on 8 April 217)

(To the top right) Bust of Caracalla, sculpted by an unknown artist between 212 and 215, displayed in the Palazzo Massimo of the Museo Nazionale Romano in Rome

Born Lucius Septimius Bassianus, the elder of the two sons of (Lucius) Septimius Severus (145-211; r. 193-211) and Julia Domna (circa 160-217; r. 193-211), was born on 4 April 188 at Lugdunum (now Lyon), where his father was serving as governor of Gallia Lugdunensis. The name Bassianus was that of his maternal grandfather, who was high priest of the sun-god Elah-Gabal at the Syrian city of Emesa. The nickname "Caracalla" or "Caracallus" derived from a hooded cloak of Gallic origin which he adopted as his favourite dress during his later years. Towards the end of 195 Septimius Severus (who had ascended the Imperial throne two and a half years before) adopted himself into the Antonine dynasty and changed the name of his elder son to Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, raising him to the rank of Caesar. This, of course, led to civil war with the existing Caesar, (Decimus) Clodius Albinus (circa 150-197), who had been given the junior Imperial title soon after Septimius Severus' accession with the promise of eventual inheritance of the throne. Following Septimius Severus' capture of the Parthian capital of Ctesiphon early in 198, Caracalla was further advanced to the rank of Augustus and co-emperor, his younger brother Geta (189-211; r. 209-211) taking his place as Caesar at the same time. Even though he was less than a year younger than Caracalla, Geta was not made Augustus for a further eleven years, until 209. This was a serious mistake on Septimius Severus' part, which doubtless exacerbated the growing rivalry and mutual antipathy of the two brothers. On the return of the Imperial family to Rome in 202, following an extended absence in the East, the 14-year-old Caracalla was married to (Publia Fulvia) Plautilla (?-211; r. 202-205), daughter of the influential praetorian prefect (Gaius or Lucius Fulvius) Plautianus (circa 150-205). The young man hated his father-in-law and disliked his haughty daughter, so it may be doubted whether the 3-year marriage was ever consummated. Plautilla shared her father's downfall in 205 though, unlike the prefect, escaped with her life for the time being.

In 208 the entire Imperial family departed for Britannia where they were to remain until Septimius Severus death early in 211. Caracalla gained much military experience at this time campaigning with his father in the wild country of Caledonia, far beyond the northern frontier of the Roman province. As Septimius Severus' health continued to decline his elder son played an increasingly prominent role in the prosecution of the war whilst Geta remained further south gaining administrative experience in Ebaracum (now York) and Londinium (now London), the provincial capital. All three emperors, however, received the title of Britannicus in honour of the victories over the barbarians of the north.

With the removal of their father's firm hand in February 211 the fraternal strife of Caracalla and Geta escalated rapidly. On their return to Rome they physically divided the palace between them, posting armed guards at every crossing point. This absurd situation clearly could not last and near the end of the year (probably on 26 December 211) Geta was lured to a meeting of reconciliation by his brother during the course of which he was treacherously murdered. After a mass extermination of thousands of those who had supposedly supported his younger brother, Caracalla spent much of his half decade of sole rule away from the capital. He campaigned in Germania in 213-214, receiving the title Germanicus for his achievements, and then headed east for his projected conquest of Parthia. Driven by a crazed obsession to emulate Alexander III of Macedon (356-323 BC), known as Alexander the Great, his physical and mental health began to deteriorate and he even visited the famous shrine of Asklepios at Pergamum in the hope of finding cures for his numerous ailments. In 215 he established his military headquarters at the Syrian capital of Antioch, accompanied by his mother Julia Domna, who was by now virtually running the Imperial government. Rejected in his outlandish request to receive the hand in marriage of the daughter of the Parthian monarch Artabanus IV (?-224; r. 213-224), Caracalla prepared to attack the rival empire. It is doubtful whether he would have achieved any spectacular and lasting conquests, but in any case the opportunity was denied him by the assassin's hand on the road between the Mesopotamian cities of Edessa and Carrhoe on 8 April 217. He had reigned for almost two decades and was still under 30 years of age. Perhaps his most notable act – whatever the motives – was the granting of Roman citizenship to virtually every free inhabitant of the Empire under the terms of the Constitutio Antoniniana.

(To the bottom right) Photography of Joseph Markowitz (1897-1981), taken by an anonym

Joseph Markowitz was born into a Jewish family in Hungary and later moved to the town of Vršac, then part of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia, in what is today Serbia. Together with his relatives, he was involved in a family firm known as Markowitz Brothers, active in the fur trade and leather tanning. It was in this setting – shaped by enterprise, family tradition, and cultural exchange – that his interest in ancient coins began to take root.

In 1930, he married Rosa, and the family later relocated to Belgrade amid growing political tensions. At some point before the outbreak of war, Joseph Markowitz began building a coin collection, focusing particularly on Roman silver. When he was drafted into the Yugoslav army, he hid the collection in the basement of the family home – a quiet act of foresight in uncertain times.

During the war, Joseph Markowitz was taken prisoner by German forces. Rosa, left alone with their young son Chaim, was forced to flee Belgrade as the persecution of Jews intensified. Like so many Jewish families in the region, they were escaping the horrors of the Holocaust, which would ultimately lead to the annihilation of the Jewish community in Vršac – a community that did not survive.

The family home in Belgrade was later destroyed during bombing raids. After the war, Rosa and Chaim returned to the devastated city. In the rubble of their former home, they searched for what remained – and incredibly, in the ruins of the basement, they found the hidden coin collection, still intact. It had survived when so much else had been lost.

In 1949, the family emigrated to the newly founded State of Israel, bringing the rescued collection with them. They settled in Herzliya, where Joseph quietly rebuilt his life. He continued to care for and expand his collection with great dedication until his death in 1981.

The Joseph Markowitz Collection consists primarily of Roman silver coins, preserved over decades with scholarly care. It reflects not only Joseph Markowitz's love of history and ancient culture, but also a deeply personal journey – shaped by displacement, resilience, and the will to remember.

Leu Numismatik AG offered the collection (702 individual lots and 16 larger lots) at auction on 5–8 July 2025, in the hopes that its dispersal might inspire other numismatists to continue in their efforts and to enable further study into history and ancient culture, and to share the story of a man who, in the face of devastation, carried forward a world that others tried to destroy – and who chose to preserve knowledge, memory, and meaning through the language of coins.

+ AD 0162 - Roman Empire - Denarius - Marcus Aurelius:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Nerva–Antonine dynasty (96-192)
Ruler: Marcus Aurelius (161-180)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Marcus Aurelius, facing right, bare headed
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) IMPMAVRELANTONINVSAVG (IMP M AVREL ANTONINVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Concordia (Roman goddess and personification of harmony) seated left on a stool, draped, holding a patera in the right hand with the arm extended and resting the left forearm on a statuette of Spes (Roman goddess and personification of hope) which appears to form the backrest of the seat, a cornucopia below the seat
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) CONCORDAVGTRPXVI (CONCORD AVG TR P XVI) COSIII (COS III; below in exergue)
Traduction: Harmony of the emperor (Augustus), holder of tribunician power for the 16th time, consul for the third time (Concordia Augustorum, Tribunicia Potestate Sexta Decima, Consul Tertium)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was Ch AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 5/5. The grade that it received was indeed Ch AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 5/5, which met my expectation.

This coin makes me think of my children Léonie and Louis. 🦛🦓

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.

Iridescent lustre
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 162 (not dated) Fineness: 790
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.59; Expected: 3.2
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 162
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 5/5 (NGC) Variety: Cornucopia below the seat
References: RIC3#35; RCV2#4882; RSC2#35; Cohen3#35; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.3.m_aur.35; MRK#37.108
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the cornucopia is below the seat (RIC3#35) or appears to hold the statuette of Specs further away behind the seat (RIC3#40).
Note:

Following the trend of the debasement of silver introduced by Nero in 64, Marcus Aurelius further devalued the denarius upon his accession in 161 to pay for constant wars and increased expenses. The silver content of the denarius was decreased from 83.5% to 79%, the silver weight dropping from 2.68 g to 2.57 g. In 168, he revalued the denarius, increasing its silver content from 79% to 82%, the silver weight increasing from 2.57 g to 2.67 g. However, two years later he reverted to the previous values because of the military crises facing the empire.

Because of the unprecedented length of time during which Marcus Aurelius bore the junior Imperial rank of Caesar (22 years) his coinage under Antoninus is abundant in the full range of denominations. During his own reign Marcus struck additional issues in the names of his wife Faustina Junior, his daughter Lacilla, his co-emperors Lucius Verus and, later, Commodus, and posthumous issues for Divus Antoninus (161), Divus Verus (169) and Diva Faustina (176). At the very end of the reign (from 178) coins were struck for Crispina, wife of the young co-emperor Commodus. However, as her coinage continued into the sole reign of her husband all issues are normally associated with Commodus.
Historical notes:

Marcus Aurelius (Antoninus) (born on 26 April 121 in Rome; accession on 7 March 161; died on 17 March 180)

(To the right) Busts of the Co-emperors Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus, sculpted by an unknown artist between 161 and 170, displayed in Room 70 of the British Museum in London

Originally named Marcus Annius Catilius Severus, the future Emperor Marcus Aurelius Antoninus was born in Rome in 121 and was the nephew of the Empress Faustina Senior, wife of Antoninus Pius (138-161). Following the early death of his father Marcus Annius Verus, brother of the Empress Faustina Senior, in 124, he was brought up in the household of their father and his grandfather, also named Marcus Annius Verus, who had an illustrious public career and was three times consul, a rare distinction for someone outside the Imperial family. The Emperor Hadrian (117-138), who adopted Antoninus Pius, recognised the fine qualities of the youth and arranged for his betrothal to the daughter of Aelius Caesar, who he had also adopted. Later following the death of Aelius Caesar in 138, Hadrian stipulated that the new Caesar, Antoninus Pius, should adopt Marcus Aurelius together with Aelius Caesar's son, Lucius Verus. On the accession of Antoninus Pius in the summer of 138 Marcus Aurelius' career was rapidly advanced and he was even promoted to the rank of Caesar in 139, a clear indication that the new emperor regarded him, rather than Lucius Verus, as the heir to the Imperial throne. The annulment of Marcus Aurelius' betrothal to the daughter of Aelius Caesar provided additional confirmation of Antoninus Pius' intentions, as the young man was now betrothed to the emperor's daughter, Faustina the Younger. In 145 the couple were married and two years later the 26-year-old Caesar was granted the tribunician power. Antoninus Pius survived to the age of 74 and Marcus Aurelius was already in his fortieth year by the time he ascended the throne at his death in 161.

Loyal to the memory of the Emperor Hadrian, one of his first acts as emperor was to associate the younger Lucius Verus with him as co-ruler, thus inaugurating the first joint reign in almost two hundred years of Imperial history. Unfortunately, the experiment was not a resounding success. Lucius Verus proved to be weak and addicted to the pursuit of pleasure and was thus more of a liability than an asset in the demanding task of governing a vast Empire. This merely confirmed Antoninus Pius' earlier judgement and the sudden and untimely death of Lucius Verus in 169 must have come as a considerable relief to Marcus Aurelius. Although gentle and philosophical by nature, Marcus Aurelius was fated to spend long periods of his reign enduring the harsh conditions of military camp life. Throughout the 170s he undertook arduous campaigns on the Rhine and Danube frontiers, where there was much unrest amongst the barbarian tribes, and it was during this trying time that he wrote his celebrated "Meditations" based on the principles of Stoic philosophy. Following the abortive revolt in the East of the general Avidius Cassius in 175, Marcus Aurelius decided to advance his young son Commodus to Imperial status, first as Caesar (175) and then as Augustus and co-emperor late in the following year. Worn out by the cares of state Marcus Aurelius died at the age of 59 in 180 and was succeeded by the 19-year-old co-emperor Commodus. He was immediately deified, an extensive posthumous coinage being issued in his honour. A careful, generous and conscientious autocrat, it has been written of Marcus Aurelius that "in the evening of Rome's greatness her ruler fittingly personified the virtues that had been her glory".

+ AD 0122 - Roman Empire - Denarius - Hadrian:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Nerva–Antonine dynasty (96-192)
Ruler: Hadrian (117-138)

Design: Galley, rowed left, the mast with furled sail in bows, the cabin in stern
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) PMTRPCOSIII (P M TR P COS III)
Traduction: Greatest of the Pontifices, holder of tribunician power, consul for the third time (Pontifex Maximus, Tribunicia Potestate, Consul Tertium)
Designer: -

Engraver: -
Features:

The front of the NGC holder has a bad scratch, which I believe was caused by mishandling at the eBay International Shipping Hub. The layers of the original packaging must have been opened with a sharp object at the eBay International Shipping Hub, probably to check the contents. I subsequently contacted eBay to report this problem but eBay did not acknowledge any responsability. The only solution proposed by eBay was to return the item for a full refund. Since I had no intention to return the item as I would not be able to find a replacement, I kept the item as is. It can be sent to NGC for reholdering, but I am unlikely to do so since the scratch does not bother me that much.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 122 (not dated) Fineness: 850
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.34; Expected: 3.2
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 122
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC2#113; RCV2#3529var; RSC2#1174C; Cohen2#1174; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.2_3(2).hdn.525; MRK#32.86
Varieties:

Several portrait varieties exist. The details of the galley on the reverse can also vary considerably.
Note:

Hadrian's varied and interesting coinage includes many reverse types commemorating the diversity of the Empire's provinces and the personal interest taken in them by the emperor. Like the bulk of his predessor's issues, the annual advancement of the tribunician power is not recorded in the inscriptions, thereby adding to the difficulties of achieving a precise chronological structure for the coinage. Fortunately, this problem has been overcome by Philip V. Hill in his important work "The Dating and Arrangement of the Undated Coins of Rome, AD 98-148", published in 1970. In addition to coinage in his own name Hadrian produced issues honouring his deified predecessor Trajan, the dowager empress Plotina, his mother-in-law Matidia (both lifetime and posthumous), his wife Sabina, and his first heir Aelius Caesar. Additionally, there was a surprisingly extensive posthumous coinage for his favourite Antinoüs, produced principally at Alexandria, but also at many other provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Publius Aelius) Hadrianus (born on 24 January 76 in Italica, Hispania Baetica, Spain; accession on 11 August 117; died on 10 July 138 in Baiae)

(To the top right) Bust of Hadrian, sculpted by an unknown artist between 125 and 130, found in Hadrian's villa in Tibur (modern Tivoli), displayed in the British Museum in London

Publius Aelius Hadrianus, known in english as Hadrian, was born in 76 in Italica, Hispania Baetica, Spain, like his predecessor (Marcus Ulpius) Traianus (53-117; r. 98-117), known in english as Trajan. His father had died when he was still only in his tenth year and he entered the childless household of the future emperor Trajan, eventually marrying Vibia Sabina (83-136 or 137) in 100, daughter of the emperor's favourite niece, Salonia Matidia (68-119). It thus seemed that he had been marked out for the Imperial succession, though no formal adoption ever took place. The young man adopted a military career, serving as tribune of Legiones II Adiatrix and V Macedonica late in the reign of (Titus Flavius) Domitianus (51-96; r. 81-96), known as Domitian, and later as legate of Legio I Minervia during Trajan's Second Dacian War. At the time of Trajan's sudden death in 117 Hadrian was governor of the important province of Syria. After a delay of several days it was announced by the widowed empress Pompeia Plotina (?-121 or 122) that her dying husband had confided to her in secret his desire to adopt Hadrian as his heir. Although there was considerable opposition to the new emperor's accession, especially in senatorial circles, no one dared challenge the word of the late emperor's highly respected consort. In marked contrast to the aristocracy the army was firmly behind him and a reluctant Senate was obliged to ratify what it regarded as a cleverly contrived coup. The hostile relationship between the emperor and the conscript fathers was further exacerbated by the executions of four former consuls, all accused of plotting treason, prior to the new emperor's delayed arrival in Rome in the summer of 118. The philhellene Hadrian had a keen interest in experiencing first hand the diverse people and places of his vast realm. Accordingly, much of his reign was spent in touring virtually all the provinces of the Empire, these peregrinations extending over three great journeys that required his absence from the capital for years at a time. Particular attention was paid to army morale and to frontier defences, his best known undertaking being the construction of the elaborate frontier system in northern England, known as Hadrian's Wall: much of this immense work is still to be seen. The closing years of Hadrian's reign were troubled by a great Jewish uprising known as the Second Revolt or Bar Kokhba War (132-135). This was to result in great loss of life and the rebuilding of Jerusalem as a pagan city (Aelia Capitolina) from which all Jews were excluded. Now in failing health, the emperor retired to his magnificent villa in Tibur (modern Tivoli) to spend his remaining time surrounded by architecture and works of art recalling his travels in the eastern Mediterranean region. Hadrian died in Baiae on 10 July 138 and was succeeded by Titus Aurelius Fulvus Boionius Antoninus (86-161; r. 138-161), soon to be known as Antoninus Pius for his loyal devotion to the memory of his predecessor. The original choice as heir, Lucius Ceionius Commodus (101-138), known as Lucius Aelius Caesar as Imperial heir, had predeceased the emperor on 1 January 138.

(To the bottom right) Photograph of the Sycamore Gap tree (or Robin Hood tree), standing in a dramatic dip in the landscape, next to Hadrian's Wall near Crag Lough (visible in the background) in Northumberland, England, taken by me during an enjoyable walk with my son Louis on 10 August 2022. The 150-year-old sycamore tree was felled in the early morning of 28 September 2023 in what Northumbria Police described as "an act of vandalism". The stump has thrown up seedlings and is still alive, albeit severely coppiced, but is expected to take more than 150 years to recover.

+ AD 0078 - Roman Empire - Denarius - Titus:

Open description in new window

Ruler: Vespasian (69-79)

Reverse:

Design: Sow walking left, with three of her youngs (piglets; one ahead below her head, one in between her front and hind legs below her belly and udder, and one behind below her tail), on a base, the inscription "IMPXIII" below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (in exergue) IMPXIII (IMP XIII)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator) for the thirteenth time (Imperator Tertium Decimum)
Designer: -
