Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was XF★; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5 or, more realistically, XF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5. The grade that it received was Ch VF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 3/5, which did not quite meet my expectation. I learnt a lesson in the process: eye appeal is to some degree subjective and can affect judgement.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 78 (not dated) Fineness: 900
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.34; Expected: 3.2
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 19; Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 78
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch VF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 3/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC2#220; RCV1#2443; RSC2#104; Cohen1#104; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.2_1(2).ves.986; MRK#22.23
Varieties:

None
Note:

For several centuries before the rise of Rome there had been a tradition of featuring animals, birds, fish and insects (as well as various mythological beasts) on the coinages of many of the Greek city states. Rome inherited this tradition, and although the representation of fauna is less frequent and varied than on coins of the Greek series, they nevertheless form a most appealing group within the Roman coinage.

Crocodile, heifer, bull, wild boar, lion attacking stag, eagle, crab and butterfly, capricorn, Pegasus and Sphinx all appear on the coinage of Augustus, who was the inheritor of the late Republican tradition of great diversity in the selection of coin types. However, during the course of his long reign that tradition was gradually superseded by a more conservative approach to the type content of the new Imperial coinage. Accordingly, the coinages of the later Julio-Claudian emperors feature virtually no representations of animals, other than the elephants drawing the car of Divus Augustus on a sestertius issued by Tiberius, and the eagle appearing on the reverse of a Divus Augustus as.

The Flavian revival of earlier coin types led to a reintroduction of the tradition of animal depiction on the Imperial coinage. Several types issued in 78 draw from country life. A reverse shows a goat being milked by a goat-herd and another has a sow, with three of her youngs (piglets). These agricultural scenes may be seen as the outline of a programme for the restauration of agricultural prosperity in Italy, of which no detailed record is known. It is worth nothing that little is known about the morphology of domestic pigs and their forms of keeping in ancient Graeco-Roman times from written sources. The depictions of domestic pigs on ancient artefacts such as coins provide important sources of information (see Meyer et al., 2004).

In the 2nd century the Pegasus and the griffin appear on several aes denominations of Hadrian whilst his successor Antoninus Pius struck asses showing an elephant and a sow suckling its young beneath an oak tree, both types probably having reference to the celebrations connected with the 900th anniversary of the foundation of Rome. An attractive representation of a dove appears on an aureus of Antoninus Pius' daughter, the younger Faustina, and elephants occur on an as of Commodus and a denarius of Septimius Severus.

The "king of beasts" is depicted on the coinage of Caracalla, wearing a radiate crown and holding a thunderbolt in its jaws, and several decades later the lion reappears as part of the "Saeculares" series of Philip (I) the Arab. Similarly, the elephant was popular as a coin type during the first half of the 3rd century, appearing on pieces of Caracalla, Geta, and Philip (I) the Arab. To celebrate the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome in 247-248 Philip (I) the Arab staged magnificent games in which many wild beasts were exhibited in the arenas of the capital. This resulted in a series of coins featuring a gazelle, a European elk (moose), a hippopotamus, a stag, a goat (or hind), and an antelope, in addition to the lion already mentioned. The city's emblem, the she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus), also appears as part of this series.

A few years later, during the sole reign of Gallienus (260-268), an extensive series of "animal" reverses was featured on the debased antoninianus denomination. Subsequent to this date such types appear far less frequently and are, in the main, restricted to the "legionary badge" issues of the usurpers Victorinus in Gaul and Carausius in Britannia. The charismatic Carausius also had types showing the milking of a cow, a griffin, and the traditional wolf and twins device.

In the late Empire, the wolf and twins appear on coins of another usurper, Maxentius (306-312), whose policy was to try to revive the past glories of the Imperial capital; and several decades later on small billon pieces (reduced centenionales) of the time of Constantine and his successors. In the mid 4th century a phoenix is shown on half maiorinae of Constantius II and Constans and a very fine representation of a bull, sometimes accompanied by an eagle, occurs on large billon pieces of Julian II towards the end of his short reign (360-67). One of the last animal representations on the Roman coinage is on a tiny bronze numnus of the easter Emperor Leo I (457-474) where a lion appears as a punning allusion to the emperor's name.
Historical notes:

Titus Flavius Vespasianus (born on 30 December 39; accession on 23 June 79; died on 13 September 81)

(To the right) Photograph of a large crowd of Jewish people marching through the Arch of Titus, taken by an anonym on the day of the Declaration of the Establishment of the State of Israel on 14 May 1948. Many of these people were European refugees who were living in camps for "displaced persons" waiting to resettle in Israel. Some people were holding banners in celebration. The message on the banner to the left of the photograph reads "Long Live the Hebrew State" (תחי המדינה העברית). It is no accident that the celebration was held by the Arch of Titus, a monument honouring the victory of Titus (Flavius Vespasianus; 39-81; r. 79-81) in Judaea in 70. The monument contains panels depicting the triumphal procession celebrated in 71 after the Roman victory in Judaea, culminating in the fall of Jerusalem. The south inner panel depicts the spoils taken from the (Second) Temple in Jerusalem, also known as the Herod's Temple, including the menorah. The menorah is often used as a symbol representing the Jewish people and Judaism in both the Land of Israel and the Diaspora. It eventually became the official emblem of the State of Israel after its establishment in 1948. The Arch of Titus became a symbol of the exile of the Jewish people, and until the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948 Jewish people followed a tradition not to pass under it. Once the State of Israel was established and the Jewish people could return to their homeland, the tradition was annulled. In fact, this photograph shows the Jewish people passing under the arch in the opposite direction to that of the exiles depicted on the arch. The marchers are seen walking in the direction of Jerusalem, as if they were choosing to leave Rome and declaring their victorious return to the Land of Israel after thousands of years of exile. The Arch of Titus has also provided the general model for many triumphal arches erected since the 16th century. It is for instance the inspiration for the Arc de Triomphe in Paris.

Titus (Flavius Vespasianus) was the elder son of Titus Flavius Vespasianus (9-79; r. 69-79), know as Vespasian, and Flavia Domitilla Major (12-69), known as Domitilla the Elder. He was a close boyhood friend of (Tiberius Claudius Caesar) Britannicus (41-55), son of the Emperor (Tiberius) Claudius (Caesar Augustus Germanicus; 10-54; r. 41-54), with whom he was educated. During the reign of Nero (Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus; 37-68; r. 54-68) he served as a military tribune in Germania and Britannia and in 67 accompanied his father to Judaea, where he commanded the Legio XV Apollinaris. When his father made his bid for the imperial throne in 69 Titus was given supreme command over the First Jewish–Roman War. In September 70 he captured Jerusalem, thus effectively ending the Jewish Revolt which had begun four years earlier during the reign of Nero. Although he bore only the junior rank of Caesar throughout Vespasian's reign Titus was, in all other respects, his father's colleague in the rule of the Roman Empire. When Titus returned to Rome in June 71 they celebrated a magnificent joint triumph for the victory in Judaea and Titus was accorded a considerable share in the imperial coinage, with large scale issues in all metals. The share of his younger brother Titus Flavius Domitianus (51-96; r. 81-96), known as Domitian, was considerably smaller and there can be little doubt that the latter felt bitterly resentful of his inferior status (a resentment that was to find expression in the tyranny of Domitian's own reign a decade later). Titus suceeded to the imperial throne on the death of Vespasian on 23 June 79. He reigned for little more than two years, but this brief period witnessed a series of natural disasters. Most famous is the eruption of Vesuvius, which destroyed the towns of Pompeii and Herculaneum in 79, but in the following year in 80 the capital suffered from both plague and a devastating fire. It was in connection with these disasters that Titus issued a series of coins commemorating the services of prayer and propitiation through which he attempted to allay public alarm. One of the rare highlights of the reign was the dedication in June 80 of the great Amphitheatrum Flavium, known as the Colosseum. This magnificent arena, still one of the principal landmarks of modern Rome, had been commenced by Vespasian in 71 on the site of the stagnum (pool), formerly in the gardens of Nero's Golden House. The dedication by Titus was accompanied by lavish celebrations for the Roman populace. Probably exhausted and depressed by his ordeals, Titus died on 13 September 81 at the early age of forty-two. He was succeeded by his younger brother Domitian who, as heir to the throne, had been accorded a considerable coinage in all metals during the reign of Titus.

+ AD 0033 - Roman Empire - Denarius ("Tribute Penny") - Tiberius:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Julio–Claudian dynasty (-27-68)
Ruler: Tiberius (14-37)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Laureate head of Tiberius, facing right
Script: Latin
Lettering: (anticlockwise, starting at 11h) TICAESARDIVI AVGFAVGVSTVS (TI CAESAR DIVI AVG F AVGVSTVS)
Traduction: Augustus, Son of a God (Augustus Divi Filius) (the "god" referred to is Julius Caesar)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Bull butting left, on a base, the inscription "IMPX" below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (in exergue) IMPX (IMP X)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator) for the tenth time (Imperator Decimum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin will be sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expect it will receive is AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5.

There is evidence of an unimportant die break on the reverse.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓 It is somewhat a special coin in that I had discussed tens of examples of such "Tribute Penny" with him for a couple of years. Our discussion always revolved around comparing coins struck during the first half of the 1st century. While I was inclined to acquire one of these "Tribute Pennies" for their historical significance, he was not attracted by the reverse design that displays yet another "chair" as we resolved to describe any reverse with a figure seated on a chair.

This coin is called the "Tribute Penny" in numismatics, in reference to to the coin that was shown to Jesus Christ in the scene "The Question about Paying Taxes" reported in the three "synoptic" Gospels of Matthew (22.15-22), Mark (12.13-17), and Luke (20.19-26), in the New Testament. In this scene, envoys of Jewish religious and political groups try to trap Jesus Christ by asking him whether or not to pay taxes to the Roman emperor. Jesus qualifies them as "hypocrites", then asks them to show a silver coin that is used to pay these taxes and to tell him who is represented on the coin. They answer that it is Caesar. Jesus then replies to them: "Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's." The questioners were impressed by the answer and unable to trap Jesus Christ any further.

One interpretation of this scene is that the questioners asking Jesus Christ if taxes should be paid to the Roman emperor were attempting to trap him into admitting his opposition to doing so, and that upon seeing that the coin was a "Tribute Penny", Jesus Christ avoided the trap by saying that it should be given back to Caesar, because it was his anyway.

The original text in Greek identifies the coin as a δηνάριον (dēnarion), and it is usually thought by scholars that the coin was a Roman denarius with the head of the Roman emperor at this time, Tiberius (Julius Caesar Augustus), who used Caesar as his cognomen, following his two predecessors (Gaius) Julius Caesar and (Gaius Julius Caesar) Augustus. However, it is impossible to determine whether or not Jesus Christ saw this particular type. Denarii in circulation at this time would most probably have included a mix of common Roman Republican, Imperatorial and Imperial types. Besides, it has been suggested by some scholars that denarii were not in common circulation in Judaea during Jesus Christ's lifetime and that the coin may have instead been an Antiochan tetradrachm bearing the head of Tiberius on the obverse and that of Augustus on the reverse (see RPC#4161 and Lewis, 1999a,b).
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 04h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 33 (not dated) Fineness: 950
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.77; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 18; Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Lugdunum Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 18-35
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5 (CCN) Variety: Bull butting left
References: RIC1#30; RCV1#1763; RSC2#16A; Cohen1#16; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.1(2).tib.30; MRK#5.4
Varieties:

There are three varieties, for which the bull is butting right and Augustus' head is facing right (RCV1#1610, RSC1#137 and Cohen1#137) or left (RSC1#139 and Cohen1#139) and the bull is butting left and Augustus' head is facing right (RSC1#141 and Cohen1#141).
Note:

Augustus reformed the monetary system between 23 and 15 BC in order to solve the disorder that had been created in Rome's monetary production. Monetary issues were very numerous, thanks to the spoils that the "princeps" had brought back from the new province of Egypt and the Spanish mines, so much so that it resulted in an excess of money, leading to a cut in interest rates and an increase in the value of landed property. The reform brought an end to emergency issues, minted by mobile mints following the various generals of the Roman Empire, as had been the case during the civil wars. The weight of the silver denarius – which remained the reference currency – was restored following a considerable drop during the civil wars. It was now valued 84 to the pound and the gold aureus was valued at 25 denarii and 41 to the pound. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the denarius and the aureus theoretical weights in modern terms of 3.90 g and 7.99 g, respectively. Denominations below the denarius were more comprehensively reformed. New ratios were fixed among the currencies: the sestertius was now minted from about an ounce of orichalcum, an alloy of copper and zinc, rather than silver, and fixed at a quarter of a denarius. The dupondius, formerly a two-pound bronze coin, was now orichalcum, valued at half a sestertius and weighing half as much. The half-ounce as, worth half a dupondius, the semis, worth half an as, and the quadrans, worth half a semis, were the pure copper coins. The Augustan currency system was to set the pattern for the Roman Imperial coinage for the first two and a half centuries of its history.

The minting of gold and silver coins was brought under under Augustus' personal control and used the new mint of Lugdunum, while the minting of coins from copper and its alloys was left under senatorial control and used the mint of Rome. The latter coins generally bore the inscription "SC" (Senatus Consultum; "by Decree of the Senate"). The reform also marked the definitive presence of the portrait of a living person on coins.
Historical notes:

Tiberius (Julius Caesar Augustus) (born on 16 November 42 BC in Rome; proclaimed emperor on 17 September AD 14; died on 16 March AD 37 in Misenum)

(To the top right) Bust of Tiberius, sculpted by an unknown artist between 14 and 23, displayed in the Musée Saint-Raymond in Toulouse

Tiberius was born in -42, the elder son of the aristocratic Tiberius Claudius Nero, whose name he bore, and Livia Drusilla. When he was only three years of age his parents divorced and Livia married the triumvir Octavian, who was later to become Rome's first emperor under the name Augustus. As a young man Tiberius soon proved himself be a most competent general and in a military career which was to span more than three decades (-20-12) he campaigned extensively in many parts of the Empire. His relationship with his stepfather, however, was always strained and his marriage in -11 to Augustus' daughter Julia was most unhappy. This probably contributed to his decision is -6 to go into voluntary exile on the island of Rhodes, where he remained for the following eight years. He returned to Rome in 2 and on the death of Augustus' grandson Gaius Caesar two years later the emperor was reluctantly obliged to adopt Tiberius and acknowledge him as heir to the throne. Ten years later, on the death of Augustus, he became Rome's second emperor. Although an able administrator Tiberius was suspicious and reclusive by nature and always bore a resentment for the unfair treatment which he felt he had received from his stepfather. His reign was marred by a series of tragedies within the imperial family and by the machinations of the powerful praetorian prefect Sejanus who, prior to his downfall in 31, was probably aiming at usurping the imperial power itself. In 26 Tiberius once again retired to island retreat, this time Capreae, and never again set foot in Rome during the remaining eleven years of his life. He died at Misenum on 16 March 37 in his seventy-ninth year and was succeeded by his great-nephew Caligula. His own son, Drusus, had died fourteen years before, probably a victim of Sejanus.

(To the bottom right) ...

 -

Boîte no 05 :

→ Avant l'ère « commune » :

+ 0013 BC - Roman Empire - Denarius - Augustus:

Traduction: Augustus, Son of a God (Augustus Divi Filius) (the "god" referred to is Julius Caesar)

Design: Bull butting left, on a base, the inscription "IMPX" below in exergue

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 07h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 13 BC (not dated) Fineness: 950

Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)

Mint: Lugdunum Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 15-13 BC
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Bull butting left
References: RIC1#169; RCV1#1610var; RSC1#141; Cohen1#141; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.1(2).aug.169; MRK#2.57
Varieties:

There are three varieties, for which the bull is butting right and Augustus' head is facing right (RCV1#1610, RSC1#137 and Cohen1#137) or left (RSC1#139 and Cohen1#139) and the bull is butting left and Augustus' head is facing right (RSC1#141 and Cohen1#141).
Note:

Augustus reformed the monetary system between 23 and 15 BC in order to solve the disorder that had been created in Rome's monetary production. Monetary issues were very numerous, thanks to the spoils that the "princeps" had brought back from the new province of Egypt and the Spanish mines, so much so that it resulted in an excess of money, leading to a cut in interest rates and an increase in the value of landed property. The reform brought an end to emergency issues, minted by mobile mints following the various generals of the Roman Empire, as had been the case during the civil wars. The weight of the silver denarius – which remained the reference currency – was restored following a considerable drop during the civil wars. It was now valued 84 to the pound and the gold aureus was valued at 25 denarii and 41 to the pound. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the denarius and the aureus theoretical weights in modern terms of 3.90 g and 7.99 g, respectively. Denominations below the denarius were more comprehensively reformed. New ratios were fixed among the currencies: the sestertius was now minted from about an ounce of orichalcum, an alloy of copper and zinc, rather than silver, and fixed at a quarter of a denarius. The dupondius, formerly a two-pound bronze coin, was now orichalcum, valued at half a sestertius and weighing half as much. The half-ounce as, worth half a dupondius, the semis, worth half an as, and the quadrans, worth half a semis, were the pure copper coins. The Augustan currency system was to set the pattern for the Roman Imperial coinage for the first two and a half centuries of its history.

The minting of gold and silver coins was brought under under Augustus' personal control and used the new mint of Lugdunum, while the minting of coins from copper and its alloys was left under senatorial control and used the mint of Rome. The latter coins generally bore the inscription "SC" (Senatus Consultum; "by Decree of the Senate"). The reform also marked the definitive presence of the portrait of a living person on coins.
Historical notes:

(Gaius Julius Caesar) Augustus (born on 23 September 63 BC in Rome; proclaimed emperor on 16 January 27 BC; died on 19 August AD 14 in Nola)

(To the right) Bust of Augustus, sculpted by an unknown artist between 27 BC and AD 14, displayed in the Hall of the Emperors of the Palazzo Nuovo in Rome

Through the gradual elimination of all his political rivals over the period 44-30 BC, and the constitutional reorganisations of the early years of his reign, the emperor Augustus had, with the utmost subtlety guided the transition of the Roman government from a republic to a monarchy. The changes enacted in the summer of 23 BC put the finishing touches to this process. In this year he resigned the consulship, which he had held continuously since 31 BC, receiving in its place proconsular imperium ever all of Rome's territories. At the same time he obtained a lifetime grant of the tribunician power ("tribunicia potestas") thereby acquiring the absolute right of veto. These developments were of immense importance as the gave Augustus, and all of his successors, complete control of the state. Despite the outward appearance of constitutionality in the form of his authority Augustus had effected a revolution in the government of the Roman Empire. What was even more remarkable was that he had accomplished the transformation almost imperceptibly, so awed were the Roman people with the personal "auctoritas" of their leader, now generally referred to as the "princeps". Under his enlightened administration the Roman Empire prospered and stability was restored to all aspects of life, from the revival of agriculture in war-torn Italy to the complete reform of the state's finances and money.

Despite his delicate constitution and frequent bouts of ill-health Augustus lived for seventy-seven years. In the latter part of his life he became increasingly concerned over the question of the imperial succession, especially as he had begun to outlive not only his contemporaries but also some of the younger members of the imperial family. His old friend Agrippa expired suddenly and unexpectedly in 12 BC and even Agrippa's sons, Gaius and Lucius Caesars, grandsons of Augustus, died tragically in AD 4 and AD 2 respectively. Augustus was left with little choice but to designate Tiberius, the empress Livia's son by an earlier marriage, as heir to the throne. His relationship with Tiberius had never been good and this unfortunate turn of events doubtless embittered the emperor's final years. He died on 19 August AD 14 in the Campanian town of Nola. His legacy was a peaceful and secure state free from the strife that had characterised the final decades of the Senate's rule. It was small wonder than when this man passed away there was universal grieving and a strong desire to honour his memory and commemorate his enormous achievements, which had affected the lives of every citizen.

+ 0048 BC - Roman Empire - Denarius - Lucius Hostilius Saserna:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Republic (509-27 BC); Roman Imperatorial period (49-27 BC)
Ruler: Caesar (-49-44)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of a captive Gallic male warrior (Vercingetorix?), facing right, draped, with beard pointing right and bristling hair, a chain around the neck, a Gallic shield behind, the field surrounded by a grènetis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: Lucius Hostilius Saserna (48 BC)

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Naked Gallic warrior, facing backwards, holding a shield with the left hand and wielding a spear with the right hand, in a biga galloping right, driven by a charioteer holding a raising whip with the right hand and the reins with the left hand, with divided director (moneyer)'s name (L·HOSTILIVS SASERN or SASERNA) above and below in exergue, the field surrounded by a grènetis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: Lucius Hostilius Saserna (48 BC)

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was F or, more realistically, VG; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 3/5; bankers marks. The grade that it received was VG; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 2/5; bankers marks, which did not quite meet my expectation. I had requested NGC to include the pedigree to the Helmingham Hoard on the certification label, but my request was not fulfilled. I subsequently contacted NGC to find out what happened with this request and NGC acknowledged that that was this oversight at their end. The certification label was then corrected at no charge to include the pedigree to the Helmingham Hoard.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.

This coin was recorded as coin No. 680 of the Helmingham Hoard, which was discovered at a find spot with Historic Environment Record (HER), formerly Sites and Monuments Record (SMR), "HLM 050", maintained by the Suffolk Archaeological Service. The data from record has not been made public by the Suffolk Archaeological Service at the request of the landowner, most probably to prevent looters from invading the site of the find. The coin was subsequently catalogued as coin No. 259 by Ghey, the curator of hoards in the Department of Money and Medals at the British Museum in London. The full catalogue is available at the British Museum.

On 9 September of 2019, George Ridgway made a discovery of great historical and numismatic importance: the Helmingham Hoard of British Iron Age and Roman coins. An avid treasure hunter from a tender age – having received his first metal detector at just 12 years old as a gift from his grandmother – George Ridgway was drawn to Helmingham Hall in Suffolk, by its historical significance. Happily, Helmingham Hall’s residents shared his passion for the past, and he was granted private permission to detect the grounds. At the request of the landowner, the exact find spot is to remain undisclosed. However, it can be said that the hoard was found in a field close to a Roman road and that it has produced a general assemblage of Roman material. It can also be said that it was found close to a "small oddly shaped crop-circle"; this feature later transpired to be a natural pond, filled in during the course of agricultural work in the 19th century.

The day of discovery started with a scattering of Roman brooches, several of which have been dated to the first century, making them roughly contemporary with the hoard. Some 30 yards down the field came the first coin: a denarius of (Julius) Caesar, which poked its head up and was revealed. Over the next three hours, 206 coins (including the first coin) were found, spread across an area of approximately one and a half metres. George Ridgway, well aware of the significance of this find, was keen that it be properly recorded and assessed for archaeological significance. The local archaeologist was notified and George Ridgway’s father offered to camp at the site and keep watch; he stayed for two nights standing guard to protect the hoard. Shortly after, an extensive three-month-long archaeological dig was undertaken; this yielded a further 205 coins, with 314 more (including this coin) being found in the same archeological context (0001) during controlled metal detecting of the site within a 60-yard radius of the initial find. George Ridgway diligently returned to the site on 1st October 2020 and in 2021, finding a further 9 and 14 coins, respectively. All together, 748 coins were found: one Roman gold aureus of (Tiberius) Claudius (Caesar Augustus Germanicus; -10-54; r. 41-54), 724 Roman silver denarii, 19 British Iron Age gold staters and 4 quarter staters of the pre-Roman Britain king and chieftain of the Catuvellauni, Cunobelin (?-circa 40; r. circa 9-circa 40). This makes this hoard the largest mixed hoard of British Iron Age and Roman coins found to date in Britain.

Sherds of pottery were found near the corner of the field, in very close proximity to one of the denarii. Almost all the sherds are likely to belong to the same vessel, which probably contained the hoard; they are fragments of a grey ware bowl or jug. Among the grey ware fragments an undiagnostic, probably construction building material, fragment was also found.

The hoard was taken to the British Museum in London where the coins were conserved and catalogued, following the application of the 1996 Treasure Act, as Treasure case Nos. 2019T794, 2020T915 and 2021T655, for the finds in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. The finds were recorded with the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS; see https://finds.org.uk) with record IDs SF-8C645E, SF-521A7C and SF-AEA396, respectively. Sixty three coins were retained by various museums, with the rest being returned in early 2024 to the finder and landowners, who brought them to Noonans shortly after. Noonans offered 666 coins of the hoard (235 coins as individual lots and 431 coins as part of larger lots) at auction on 18 September 2024, in the hopes that its dispersal might inspire other treasure hunters and numismatists to continue in their efforts and to enable further study into this important part of Britain's history. When asked what he will do with the money raised from the auction, after splitting it with the landowners, George Ridgway said he will buy his dad a pint!

The earliest coin in the hoard is a denarius of the Roman Republic issued circa 206-195 BC and the latest are two denarii of Claudius issued in 46-47. The terminus post quem for the burial hoard is therefore 46-47, during the rule of the Roman emperor Claudius, just a few years after the beginning of the Roman conquest of Britain. The Claudian invasion of Britain began in 43, with the forces initially led by (Aulus) Plautius (?-before 65). By 47 Plautius had conquered and negotiated treaties with many of the southern tribes, only to be replaced in his role by (Publius) Ostorius (Scapula; ?-52). Early in 47 Ostorius introduced into law the compulsory disarmament of the British tribes, with exception granted for hunting equipment. Unsurprisingly, this was not well received by the subjugated locals; a guerrilla campaign ensued and the western tribes led by Caratacus (circa 10-circa 50; r. circa 40-50), the son of Cunobelin, and king and chieftain of the Catuvellauni, marched eastwards to face the Romans. Ostorius, in response, prepared his men for battle. Today this series of events is known as the Iceni Revolt of 47. Almost everyone, historian or not, has heard of the queen of the Iceni, Boudica (?-60/61; r. circa 60/61), who led the Iceni Rebellion of 60/61. In contrast, the Iceni Revolt of 47 remains far more obscure, both within academic circles and public consciousness; the discovery of the Helmingham Hoard offers a tangible insight into this fascinating period of our Britain’s history.

Helmingham Hall lies just short of twenty seven miles north of Camulodunum (now Colchester in Essex), an important early Roman settlement. It is here that veterans of the Legio XX Valeria Victrix retired to prior to 49. According to (Publius Cornelius) Tacitus (circa 56-circa 120), Ostorius brought down the Iceni Revolt with "allied troops, without the strength of the legions"; it seems quite plausible that legionary veterans would be included in this number. Sixty five miles to the north of Helmingham Hall is Stonea Camp, a hillfort which has been identified as the place where the Romans, finally and ultimately, put down the Iceni Revolt.

Helmingham Hall, then, fell right in the middle of these dramatic events. It is tempting to assume that the hoard’s original owner was an active participant in this conflict. One can speculate from the hoard’s considerable value, with the 724 Denarii equating to just over three years salary for an ordinary legionary, that its owner might have been a high-ranking legionary (e.g., an "optio"). One can go further still, sketching in loosest terms his career in Britain: he came over to Britain in 43 with the Legio XX Valeria Victrix, then travelled up north with Plautius’ forces, settled in Camulodunum for a short while, before heeding Ostorius call to arms to put down the Iceni Revolt; he travelled north to the region of Helmingham Hall where the hoard was buried by the pond, before going onwards up to Stonea Camp where he fell in battle. However, none of this need be true. It was quite common for people who had access neither to banks nor vaults to conceal their wealth in the ground, even in times of peace. Whatever the case, a hoard of this size would not easily be forgotten and its retrieval must have been prevented by some great personal misfortune. The truth is that no one will never know the name or position of the Helmingham Hoard’s original owner; what can be said is that the original owner was a participant in one of the most dramatic and impactful chapters in Britain's history.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 48 BC (not dated) Fineness: 950
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.52; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Revaluation from 10 to 16 asses; 141-27 BC) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage: 570,000
Mint mark: None Emission period: 48 BC
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients VG; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 2/5; Attribute(s): bankers marks (NGC) Variety: ?
References: RRC1#448/2A,2B; RCV1#418; RSC1#2; RSC1#2A; Babelon1#Hostilia/2; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-448.2a; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-448.2b; PAS#https://finds.org.uk/database/search/results/q/2019T794
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the cognomen "Saserna" is written as "Sasern" (RRC1#448/2A and RSC1#2) or "Saserna" (RRC1#448/2B and RSC1#2).

RCC1 noted 57 obverse dies and 63 reverse dies. The question of the number of coins that could be struck from a single ancient die before it was discarded is contentious. Modern experiments suggest that an obverse die could strike about 15,000 acceptable coins, a reverse die only about half as many. However, often more than two reverse dies were used with an obverse die, since dies were often replaced before they wore out. Using a conservative figure of 10,000 coins per die, the production of this denarius type would be 570,000 denarii for 57 obverse dies.
Note:

The regular coinage of the Republican moneyers is typically arranged under the family name of the moneyer responsible for the issue of the coins, when these were identifiable, and then numbered them under each family. This arrangement is widely adopted for reference because it is so much easier than a chronological arrangement. Republican moneyers almost always acted as a board of three members, called the "tresviri monetales" or "tresviri aere argento auro flando feriundo", literally "three men for casting (and) striking bronze, silver (and) gold (coins)", with an annual tenure. Individually, they are often referred to as "triumvir monetalis", which is the singular form of "tresviri monetales". The "tresviri monetales" were included in the "Vigintisexvirate", a college of twenty-six minor magistrates. An office in the "Vigintisexvirate" was for most of them the first step on the cursus honorum. The long title "tresviri aere argento auro flando feriundo" was abbreviated "III. VIR. AAAFF." or even "III. VIR. A.P.F." for "tresviri ad pecuniam feriundam" on the coinage.

The "tresviri monetales" were not simple "monetarii" (mint workers), they were officials who controlled the process, including the design on the coins themselves. The moneyers' control of the legend on the coinage lent itself to the production of coins often containing propagandist political messaging. This served as self-advertising to further the potential political careers of the moneyers themselves, their families or that of those controlling them.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Equestrian statue of Vercingetorix, designed by Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi (1834-1904) in 1899, erected in Place de Jaude in Clermont-Ferrand since 1903

This coin bears the name of the "triumvir monetalis" Lucius Hostilius Saserna (?-?). Hoards showed that he belonged as a "triumvir monetalis" in the same year as the "tresviri monetales" Caius (Vibius) Pansa (Caetronianus; ?-43 BC) and Decimus (Junius) Brutus (Albinus; 81-43 BC). Decimus Brutus certainly belongs in 48 BC since he was besieging Massalia in 49 BC and was appointed to Gallia Transalpina late in 48 BC; Caius Pansa was in Rome in 48 BC. Hence, this coin was most likely struck in 48 BC. Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) designated Caius Pansa as consul for 43 BC, who took office, and Decimus Brutus for 42 BC, but he died before taking office. Lucius Saserna is not known to have held further office.

The cognomen Saserna was common in the "gens" Hostilia. It is then probable that he is the brother of two other people with this cognomen, a Saserna (?-?) whose first name is not known, and Publius Saserna (?-?). The three Saserna (brothers?) were lieutenants of Caesar during the battle of Africa in 46 BC. Lucius Saserna had always remained very attached to Caesar. (Marcus Tullius) Cicero (106-43 BC) indicated that, after the death of Caesar, Lucius Saserna became friend with Marcus Antonius (83-30 BC), known in English as Mark Antony, and Gaius Octavius (-63-14), also known as Octavian and future Augustus.

Lucius Saserna is known to have struck under his name three types (e.g., RRC1#448). The types refer without exception to Caesar's victories during his command in Gaul. The head on the obverse of this coin is frequently identified as that of the celebrated Gallic king and chieftain of the Arverni, Vercingetorix, but this identification must be regarded as highly conjectural. It can also be identified as the head of Pavor (Roman god and personification of fear), a companion of Mars (Roman god and personification of war) along with Pallor (Roman goddess and personification of paleness). Pavor would then appear with the traits of a bearded man with bristling hair; perhaps Pavor was given the traits of Vercingetorix; the Gallic shield placed behind the head allows this conjecture. Lucius Saserna would have thus reminded his contemporaries, at the same time as the recent victorious campaign of Caesar in Gaul, of a family tradition: his ancestor, the legendary third king of Rome Tullus Hostilius (r. circa 673–642 BC) had for the first time erected temples dedicated to Pavor and Pallor. It is recounted that these temples were erected on account of the fear that seized the Roman army in a battle against the Fidenates and Veians. Their allies, the Albans, suddenly turned against them in this battle, and the Roman army fled in fear. Tullus Hostilius then vowed, if he was victorious, to raise a temple dedicated to Pavor and Pallor.

+ 0049 BC - Roman Empire - Denarius - Julius Caesar:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Republic (509-27 BC); Roman Imperatorial period (49-27 BC)
Ruler: Caesar (-49-44)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Elephant walking right, with its trunk defiantly raised upwards, about to trample on what appears to be a "horned serpent" (or a carnyx, a S-shaped trumpet with a bell styled in the shape of the head of some animal, here a horned serpent, used by the Celtic tribes in Gaul), on a base, the inscription "CAESAR" below in exergue, the field surrounded by a grènetis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Pontifical implements: (from left to right) simpulum (small vessel or ladle with a long handle, used to make libations at sacrifices), aspergillum (stick with long horse-hair attached at one end, used to sprinkle holy water at sacrifices), sacena (pontifical securis; axe used to slaughter animals at sacrifices) with the top of the haft surmounted by a dog or wolf head, and apex (skull-cap with a chin-strap and a pointed piece of olive wood on its top, like a spindle, mounted on a little disk of wool at its base, worn by the flamines and Salii, who were Roman priests in charge, amongst other duties, of sacrifices); the field surrounded by a grènetis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.

This is the first coinage to bear (Julius) Caesar's name. These coins were produced in huge numbers (several millions) in order to finance Caesar's military operations after he crossed the Rubicon and invaded Italy from the north in January 49 BC, driving Pompey (the Great) from Rome to seek refuge in Greece. While the size of this production could raise eyebrows, it must be remembered that by the end of his tenure in Gaul Caesar had no fewer than eight legions of about 5,000 men expecting payment, and that the gross salary for an ordinary legionary was 225 denarii per year. Still, minting several millions of coins required vast amount of bullion. As pointed out by Nousek (2008), and as evidence of a proposed minting date in early 49 BC, one need not look far to find a probable source. On 1st April 49 BC, Caesar addressed the remnants of the Senate and the Concilium Plebis (People's Assembly), promising grain distribution and a gift of 75 denarii per man. He then proceeded to the treasury at the Temple of Saturn and demanded access to the aerarium sanctius, the special "emergency" reserve. Although he met with stubborn opposition, Caesar managed to make off with 15,000 bars of gold, 30,000 bars of silver, and a great quantity of silver coins. This purloined bullion is likely to be the source of silver for this coin issue.

Despite being the most widespread of all Caesar’s coins, the design of this type is still somewhat mysterious and subject to interpretation (see Rowan, 2019, for a summary of possible interpretations). Authorities have even debated which side of the coin is which: RCC1 describes the side with the elephant as the obverse, but other experts dispute this. The symbolism of this side of the coin is commonly held to show the triumph of good, represented as an elephant, over evil, represented as a "horned serpent". Alternatively, the "horned serpent" may be intended to represent a carnyx, a S-shaped trumpet with a bell styled in the shape of the head of some animal, here a horned serpent, used by the Celtic tribes in Gaul, whom Caesar had recently overcome in his epic eight-year conquest. In this case the elephant would again represent Caesar himself, or the unstoppable juggernaut of Rome. Unlike Pompey, Caesar brazenly placed his own name on the coinage without having the constitutional authority to do so, as Lucius Cornelius Sulla Felix (138-78 BC), commonly known as Sulla, had done 33 years before, in 82 BC. The other side of the coin depicts pontifical implements, which symbolise the prestigious lifetime office of pontifex maximus that he had held since 63 BC.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 02h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 49 BC (not dated) Fineness: 950
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.73; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Revaluation from 10 to 16 asses; 141-27 BC) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Military mint travelling with Caesar (in Mutina, for instance) Mintage: 7,500,000
Mint mark: None Emission period: 49-48 BC
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients VF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Realistic elephant
References: RRC1#443/1; CRI#9; CRR#1006; RCV1#1399; RSC1#49; Babelon2#Julia/9; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-443.1; MRK#1.8
Varieties:

There are two main varieties, for which the elephant is realistic or cartoonish. One speculation is that the cartoonish elephant was minted in Spain.

RCC1 noted 750 obverse dies and 833 reverse dies. The question of the number of coins that could be struck from a single ancient die before it was discarded is contentious. Modern experiments suggest that an obverse die could strike about 15,000 acceptable coins, a reverse die only about half as many. However, often more than two reverse dies were used with an obverse die, since dies were often replaced before they wore out. Using a conservative figure of 10,000 coins per die, the production of this denarius type would be 7.5 million denarii for 750 obverse dies.
Note:

The Roman Imperatorial period commences with the outbreak of civil war between (Julius) Caesar (100-44 BC) and Pompey (the Great; 106-48 BC) at the beginning of 49 BC and ends about twenty-two years later on 16 January 27 BC when Caesar's heir Gaius Octavius (-63-14), also known as Octavian, was given the name Augustus and effectively became the autocratic ruler of the Roman Empire. The Imperatorial coinage represents the transitional stage between the traditional Republican series and the revolutionary new Imperial coinage of Augustus and his successors.

In its earlier phase (49-45 BC) the Imperatorial series comprised issues bearing the names, though not yet the portraits, of the principal contenders for power. These issues existed side by side with the regular coinage of the Republican moneyers at the Capitoline mint in Rome, though in reality these were nothing more than a propaganda tool in the hands of Caesar and his successors who controlled the output of the Capitoline mint almost from the start of the civil war down to the closure of the establishment by Octavian in 40 BC. Additional coinages were produced at various provincial locations by supporters of Pompey (the Great) and his sons. A major turning point came at the beginning of 44 BC, when Caesar took the unprecedented step of placing his own portrait on the coinage. His assassination followed almost exactly three months later but, once initiated, this revolutionary innovation was irrevocable and portraiture rapidly became the norm, thus paving the way for the coinage of the Roman Empire.

In the post-Caesarian phase of the Imperatorial coinage (44-27 BC) issues initially were divided between the faction of the Second Triumvirate, led by Marcus Antonius (83-30 BC), known in English as Mark Antony, Octavian and (Marcus Aemilius) Lepidus (circa 89-13 BC), and the Republicans, most prominent amongst whom were the tyrannicides (Marcus Junius) Brutus (circa 85-42 BC) and his brother-in-law (Gaius) Cassius (Longinus; circa 86-42 BC). After the pivotal battle of Philippi in the autumn of 42 BC only the two principal Triumvirs, Mark Antony and Octavian, remained to contend for supreme authority in the Roman state. That struggle was finally resolved by the battle of Actium in 31 BC and the subsequent conquest the following year of Mark Antony's last strong-hold, the Ptolemaic kingdom of Egypt.

The Imperatorial coinage subdivides conveniently into four major categories: (1) issues of Pompey (the Great), his sons and their adherents; (2) issues of (Julius) Caesar; (3) issues of the Republican tyrannicides and their adherents; and (4) issues of the Triumvirs and their adherents. Between the years 49 and 40 BC it is important to remember that these essentially military coinages must be viewed in association with the contemporary coinage of the Roman moneyers. These were augmented, between 43 and 41 BC, by an exceptional output of moneyers' gold.
Historical notes:

(Gaius) Julius Caesar (born on 13 July 100 BC in Rome; dictator from 49 BC; died on 15 March 44 BC)

(To the right) Caesar on his chariot, painted by Andrea Mantegna (circa 1431-1506) between the mid-1480s and 1506. This painting is the final painting of a series of nine known as "The Triumphs of Caesar", which can be counted amongst the finest achievements in Italian Renaissance art. They were probably painted for Francesco II Gonzaga (1466-1519), who became the 4th Marquis of Mantua in Italy in 1484. The nine paintings form a sequence, which should really be called the "Triumph of Caesar", because it depicts a single procession, culminating in this final episode – the arrival of Caesar borne on a chariot passing in front of a triumphal arch. The procession cannot be connected with a particular campaign, which is probably why it was seen more generally to celebrate the triumphs of Caesar as an ancient Roman soldier, statesman and historian revered during the Renaissance. "The Triumphs of Caesar" were acquired by the british monarch Charles I (1600-1649; r. 1625-1649) in 1629 when he purchased a large part of the collections formed by the Gonzaga family. They were clearly then considered to be the masterpiece of the collection. The paintings were hung at Hampton Court Palace near London soon after the probable date of their arrival in England in 1630. Since then, they have seldom left Hampton Court Palace, but their dedicated gallery is now undergoing refurbishment (with its completion planned for 2026). Having been generously loaned by the british monarch Charles III (1948-Present; r. 2022-Present), the first six of the nine paintings are now on display in The National Gallery in London, in newly made frames that echo the original arrangement in Mantua. The seventh canvas is off-display, to be analysed in The National Gallery’s conservation studio, while the final two are on view in the Queen’s Presence Chamber in Hampton Court Palace.

(Julius) Caesar pursued the traditional cursus honorum of the young aristocrat and did not rise to political prominence until the latter part of the 60s BC. He was elected to the prestigious lifetime office of pontifex maximus in 63 BC and the next year held a praetorship followed by a successful military command in Spain. Caesar was now poised to occupy the highest magistracy of the Roman Republic and in 59 BC he embarked on the first of his five consulships.

Being now in a position to take the initiative in the political game being played out in Rome he proposed a coalition between himself, Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus (106-48 BC), known in English as Pompey (the Great), and (Marcus Licinius) Crassus (115-53 BC), which has come to be known as the First Triumvirate. Although not an officially constituted body, like the Second Triumvirate sixteen years later, this alliance between the three most powerful and influential men in Rome was a force to be reckoned with and one that could not easily be opposed, even by the Senate. It led to Caesar obtaining a 5-year proconsular command in Gaul, which was to provide him with the military prestige and resources that he needed to make his ultimate bid for supreme power a decade later.

The delicate balance of power was fatally disrupted in 53 BC when Crassus was defeated and killed in the East during his invasion of Parthian Mesopotamia. Caesar and Pompey were now left to face one another as rivals for supremacy in the Roman world. A build-up of tensions starting in late 50 BC, with both Caesar and Pompey refusing to back down, led to the outbreak of Caesar's civil war. Pompey and his allies induced the Senate to demand Caesar give up his provinces and armies in early January 49 BC. Matters escalated a few days later when Caesar refused and instead crossed the Rubicon and invaded Italy from the north, driving Pompey from Rome to seek refuge in Greece. The eventual outcome was Caesar's victory over his rival at Pharsalus on 9 August 48 BC, resulting in Pompey's political downfall and assassination a few weeks later. The struggle between Caesar and the Pompeians, led by the late triumvir's generals and his two sons, continued for several years and was only finally resolved on the battlefield of Munda in Spain in March 45 BC. Caesar's political pre-eminence was now undisputed and at the beginning of the year 44 BC the dictator gave orders for his portrait to be placed on the regular silver coinage of Rome.

Undoubtedly, this development was instrumental in fueling the grievances of those republicans who feared that Caesar was aiming at the establishment of a monarchy. Accordingly, on the Ides (15th) of March 44 BC he was struck down by a conspiracy of senators led by (Marcus Junius) Brutus (circa 85-42 BC) and his brother-in-law (Gaius) Cassius (Longinus; circa 86-42 BC). He had adopted as his heir Gaius Octavius (-63-14), the grandson of his sister Julia (Minor; before 100-51 BC). Remarkably, the young man was willing to take up the heavy mantle of his great-uncle's political ambitions and was destined to become the founder of autocratic government in Rome under the name Augustus.

+ 0078 BC - Gaule - Hémistatère, dit « aux sangliers » - Aulerques Éburovices (Anonyme):

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquité ; Peuple des Aulerques Éburovices (600-51 BC) ; « Zone du statère » (vers 359-51 BC)
Ruler: Aulerques Éburovices (600-51 BC)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Profil stylisé de tradition apollinienne, à gauche, l'arcade sourcilière, le nez, la bouche et la joue (peut-être tatouée) individualisés, les cheveux composés d'un assemblage de globules entre deux lignes perlées et de courbes représentant les mèches derrière la nuque, sous la ligne de la mâchoire un ornement (peut-être un fleuron ou un simulacre d'un svastika ou d'un triskèle), à la base du cou un sanglier, à l'envers à droite, la crinière hérissée, avec un globule entre les pattes
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Cheval aux membres désarticulés, galopant à droite, surmonté d'un aurige qui paraît en voltige et hésite entre une apparence humaine, animale ou monstrueuse, tenant les rênes de la main gauche et levant un aiguillon de la main droite, devant le poitrail du cheval, une étoile à trois branches (non visible sur cet exemplaire), entre les pattes, un sanglier, à droite, la crinière hérissée
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

Cette pièce a peut-être été créée à mon image. 🐗

Cette pièce me fait penser à mon fils Louis. 🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 07h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R3 Material: Gold
Year: 78 BC (not dated) Fineness: 450
Country: Gaule Weight (g): Measured: 3.3; Expected: 3.3
Issuer: Peuple des Aulerques Éburovices Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 17; Expected: 18
Unit: Statère (vers 359-51 BC) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: ? Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: vers 150-51 BC
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch VF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Étoile à trois branches
References: NAMG2#402; DLT#2404; Blanchet1#233; DepeyrotCeltique5#136; GCV1#115
Varieties:

Il existe plusieurs variétés de style de tête à l'avers, et de cheval et d'aurige au revers. Il existe également de nombreuses variétés dans les symboles devant le poitrail du cheval : annelet perlé, globule, étoile à trois branches, astre, etc. Cet exemplaire est une rare variété avec une étoile à trois branches et non l'habituelle rouelle à quatre branches (DLT#2402).
Note:

Les premières monnaies frappées dans la Gaule Celtique étaient des imitations aussi serviles que possible du statère d'or du roi de Macédoine Philippe II (332-336 BC ; r. 359-336 BC), sur lequel figure à l'avers la tête laurée d'Apollon et au revers un bige galopant conduit par un aurige, tenant les rênes de la main gauche et levant un aiguillon de la main droite, sur une base, l'inscription "ΦΙΛΙΠΠΟΥ" (Philippe en grec ancient) en exergue. Les premières tribus à en avoir fait des imitations assez fidèles semblent être les Arvernes et les Helvètes. Au fil des années, des imitations, et des modifications, ces espèces dévièrent de plus en plus du modèle, à l'avers la tête d'Apollon devenant de plus en plus abstraite, et au revers le bige se transformant progressivement en un seul cheval entouré de divers éléments de décomposition du reste du modèle : l'aurige semble voler au-dessus du cheval, une roue se trouve parfois entre les jambes du cheval. Au delà de l'évolution de leur composition artistique, ces espèces ont également été fortement affectées par l'évolution de leur forme, poids et composition métallique.

Les émissions étaient le fait de tribus (pagi) au sein même des peuples et non des peuples en tant qu'entité. Ces tribus pouvaient être d'égale puissance (conduisant possiblement à de nombreuses émissions monétaires) ou de taille et de poids politique différent (conduisant possiblement à des émissions monétaires dominantes et un système de droit monétaire pour d'autres émissions). Les types dominants d'une tribu était copiés plus ou moins fidèlement par les ateliers monétaires, ce qui explique les évolutions de composition artistique et les transformations de type monétaire.

Dans l'immense masse des monnayages d'or du nord-ouest de la Gaule, ceux frappés dans la basse vallée de la Seine se distinguent par leur style, hérité d'un art celtique des plus énigmatiques, et par quelques traits caractéristiques comme la spécialisation dans la frappe d'un étalon hémistatère. Ces émissions sont généralement attribuées au peuple des Aulerques Éburovices. Cependant, comme l'a montré Guihard (2012), ces hémistatères de la basse vallée de la Seine répondaient à une organisation complexe qui ne peut guère se limiter ou s'accommoder d'une attribution à un peuple déterminé.

Ces hémistatères et leur division présentent des types stables d'une série à l'autre : à l'avers figure un profil stylisé de tradition apollinienne orné d'un rappel de la couronne de laurier, dans une formation triangulaire en arrière de la chevelure ; au revers apparaît toujours un cheval surmonté d'un aurige et accompagné de divers symboles.

Dans le tableau des monnaies d'or attribuées aux Aulerques Éburovices, un ensemble se distingue des autres par son ampleur. Il s'agit de deux séries d'hémistatères faisant intervenir un animal au revers : celle marquée d'un loup et celle marquée d'un sanglier. Devant le poitrail du cheval, on relève également de nombreuses marques secondaires, représentant généralement des symboles (annelet perlé, globule, étoile à trois branches, astre, etc.).

Les affinités stylistiques et typologiques entre ces deux séries sont si étroites qu'il convient de les examiner conjointement. La composition à l'avers et au revers est en cela significative. À l'avers, elles sont liées par le même dessein de métamorphose. Le style général du profil est très proche d'une monnaie à l'autre. Le traitement obéit à une structure particulière d'une remarquable stabilité. L'accent a été mis sur certains éléments du visage. L'arcade sourcilière, le nez, la bouche et la joue (tatouée ou non) sont clairement individualisés. En outre, le traitement de la chevelure présente des ressemblances assez précises. Il est constitué d'une succession de globules entre deux lignes perlées formant un « V ». Sous la ligne perlée de droite, des courbes symbolisent des mèches. À la base du cou, un svastika ou un triskèle est systématiquement représenté. La composition au revers est tout autant régulière. Elle a pour thème principal un cheval aux membres désarticulés. Celui-ci est surmonté d'un aurige qui paraît en voltige et hésite entre une apparence humaine, animale ou monstrueuse. Toutes ces remarques conduisent à considérer ces deux séries comme un ensemble monétaire particulièrement homogène.

Ces deux séries sont précédées d'émissions sur des flans plus larges qui leur sont étroitement liées par trois traits communs et caractéristiques : la permanence d'un profil de tête à l'avers et d'un cheval conduit par un aurige au revers ; la présentation et l'arrangement des cheveux composés d'un assemblage de globules entre deux lignes perlées et de courbes représentant les mèches derrière la nuque ; le symbole du loup sous le cheval. En revanche, leur style n'est pas tout à fait comparable. La décomposition et la simplification des sujets y sont moins marquées : les éléments du visage et du corps ne s'individualisent pas encore clairement. Ces arguments montrent que les émissions interviennent avant les deux séries à flan court « au loup » et « au sanglier ». D'autre part, la présence de simulacre de légende au revers sur certains exemplaires rappelle l'inscription "ΦΙΛΙΠΠΟΥ" sur le statère d'or du roi de Macédoine Philippe II, ce qui conforte l'ordre de succession des émissions.

Une chronologie absolue est cependant difficile à établir. Il est plausible que les émissions à flan large réinterprétant profondément le statère d'or du roi de Macédoine Philippe II de Macédoine, commencèrent vers -150. À partir de la fin de ce siècle, de nouvelles monnaies, frappées sur un flan court, apparurent. Le début de ces émissions fut probablement contemporain des dernières émissions au flan large. Deux séries circulèrent alors parallèlement, l'une marquée d'un « loup » et l'autre d'un «sanglier». Leur frappe se prolongea, semble-t-il, jusqu'à la conquête de la Gaule par César en -51.

Guihard (2012) mit en évidence que ces hémistatères circulaient sur un espace bien déterminé dans la basse vallée de la Seine, en territoires que l'on attribue aux Véliocasses et aux Aulerques Éburovices. La série « au loup » se concentre sur la rive droite de la Seine, en territoire véliocasse, tandis que celle « au sanglier » se concentre principalement sur la rive gauche, en territoire aulerque éburovice. Cela confirme l'attribution de la série « au sanglier » aux Aulerques Éburovices, et suggère que la série « au loup » pourrait plutôt être attribuée aux Véliocasses. Ces deux séries peuvent être considérées comme une série uniforme, signalant ainsi une alliance monétaire entre ces deux tribus partageant une vie économique et commerciale facilitée par la Seine et ses affluents.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Statue de Camulogène, créée par Eugène-Louis Lequesne (ou le Quesne ; 1815-1887), exposée au Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille

Les Aulerques Éburovices étaient un peuple gaulois, fraction du grand peuple des Aulerques, établis globalement entre la Seine et la Loire, et désignés par différents qualificatifs selon la portion du territoire où ils se trouvaient. Ceux de la région de la basse vallée de la Seine portaient le qualificatif « Éburovices ». Ils occupaient une position stratégique sur la rive gauche de la Seine. Leur nom serait composé du préfixe ablatif « au- » signifiant « loin de » attaché à la racine « lerg- » signifiant « trace » et peut ainsi être interprété comme « ceux qui sont loin de leurs traces ». Le qualificatif « Éburovices » serait composé des éléments celtiques « eburo- » signifiant ceux qui vainquent et « -vice » désignant l'if (botanique). Les Éburovices seraient alors « ceux qui vainquent par l'if », ce bois ayant été utilisé pour fabriquer des armes, notamment des arcs en raison de sa flexibilité et de sa résistance. L'ethnogenèse du peuple des Aulerques n'est pas connue, mais elle peut être placée avant 600 BC puisque les Aulerques faisaient partie de la migration légendaire vers l'Italie menée vers 600 BC par Bellovesus, le chef des Bituriges, accompagnées des Éduens, des Ambarres, des Arvernes, des Carnutes et des Sénons. Le peuple des Aulerques Éburovices est pleinement constitué au IIème siècle avant Jésus-Christ. Leur principal oppidum se trouvait dans les environs d’Évreux, probablement non loin de Mediolanum Aulercorum (Évreux) et de Gisacum (le Vieil-Evreux). Les Aulerques Éburovices participèrent à la coalition des peuples armoricains contre les Romains et leurs alliés gaulois en -56. Ils se coalisèrent de nouveau avec les Sénons et les Parisii en -52. Commandés par le chef de guerre aulerque Camulogène, ils affrontèrent le général romain et lieutenant de César, Titus Labienus (vers 100-45 BC), lors de la bataille de Lutèce. Bataille incertaine, elle se soldera par la victoire romaine et la mort de Camulogène. Ils participèrent également à la coalition belge du soulèvement des Bellovaques contre les Suessions alors sous l'autorité des Rèmes, alliés des Romains, en -51. En ajoutant à ces trois coalitions, celle de -52 commandée par Vercingétorix (vers 80 BC-46 BC), les Aulerques Éburovices est un des peuples gaulois les plus engagés dans la résistance face aux Romains. Cette résistance n'aura pas éviter la conquête de la Gaule par César. Les destins de la Gaule et de Rome empruntent alors le même chemin, donnant vie à la culture gallo-romaine qui plus tard sera assimilée par l'invasion des Francs.

Boîte no 06 :

→ Collection thématique – Les 50 Francs, dit « Hercule » (1974-1980) :

+ AD 1980 - France - 50 Francs, dit « Hercule » - Cinquième République:

Open description in new window
Period: Époque contemporaine ; République française (1792-1804 ; 1848-1852 ; 1870-Présent) ; Cinquième République (1958-Présent)
Ruler: Valéry Giscard d'Estaing (1974-1981)
Type: From FDC Set; Collection thématique – Les 50 Francs, dit « Hercule » (1974-1980)
Obverse:

Design: Valeur faciale (50) et dénomination (FRANCS) en deux lignes, en dessous les différents d'atelier monétaire (une corne d'abondance) et du graveur (un dauphin) en ligne, le tout entouré d'une couronne composée à gauche d'une branche d'olivier et à droite d'une branche de chêne, nouées à leur base par un ruban, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) RÉPUBLIQUE FRANÇAISE★, avec le millésime entre deux points (· 1980 ·) sous la couronne à l'exergue
Traduction: République Française
Designer: Augustin Dupré (1748-1833)

Director: Pierre Dehaye (1962-1984)

Engraver: Émile Rousseau (1974-1994); Différent: dauphin
Reverse:

Design: Hercule barbu, demi-nu, debout de face avec la léonté, sur son épaule gauche une patte de lion, autour de la taille la peau de lion de Némée, unissant la Liberté à gauche tenant une pique surmontée d'un bonnet phrygien et l'Égalité à droite tenant dans sa main gauche un niveau, le tout sur une base, en dessous la signature du designer entre deux points (· Dupré ·) à l'exergue, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) (rameau d'olivier) LIBERTÉ ÉGALITÉ FRATERNITÉ
Traduction: Liberté Égalité Fraternité
Designer: Augustin Dupré (1748-1833)

Director: Pierre Dehaye (1962-1984)

Engraver: Émile Rousseau (1974-1994); Différent: dauphin
Features:

J'avais récupéré 8 de ces pièces (1 au millésime 1974, 1 au millésime 1976 et 6 au millésime 1977) que mes parents avaient thésaurisées. Elles ont contribué à déveloper ce projet, mais, probablement tristement, je ne les ai pas gardées. Celles-ci n'étaient pas en bon état de conservation. Cette pièce comble ce vide perceptible d'une certaine façon.
Edge: Incuse Pattern: | ★ ◆ 🔨 ◆ 🛞 ◆ 🧭 ◆ ★ | ★ ◆ ⚖️ ◆ 📯 ◆ 🝐 ◆ ★ | ★ ◆ 🌾 ◆ 🐓 ◆ 🍇 ◆ ★
Alignment: Coin (↑↓) Technique: Milled
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 1980 Fineness: 900
Country: France Weight (g): Expected: 30
Issuer: France Shape: Round
Value: 50 Diameter (mm): Expected: 41
Unit: Nouveau franc (1960-2001) Thickness (mm): 2.7
Mint: Pessac Mintage: 60,000
Mint mark: 📯 Emission period: 1974-1980
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS69 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Gad#882; F#427.8; KM#941.1
Varieties:

Il existe une variété principale pour le millésime 1974, un hybride qui présente le revers de la pièce de 20 Francs. La base de la gravure des personnages est légèrement plus large, le rameau d'olivier est positionné plus haut par rapport au niveau de la draperie, et la lettre L de « ÉGALITÉ » se trouve directement au dessus de la tête d'Hercule.

D'autres variétés existent avec les segments de la tranche inversés ou décalés.

Le millésime 1980 a été produit uniquement pour la série « Fleur de Coin » contenant des exemplaires numismatiques de l'ensemble des dix monnaies de ce millésime (50 Francs, 10 Francs, 5 Francs, 2 Francs, 1 Franc, 50 Centimes, 20 Centimes, 10 Centimes, 5 Centimes et 1 Centime). Les séries « Fleur de Coin » sont présentées dans un coffret dont la présentation a changé plusieurs fois au cours des années et depuis 1968, elles sont scellées hermétiquement sous plastique.
Note:

Cette espèce fut fabriquée suite au décret du 23 septembre et à l'arrêté du 8 novembre 1974, conformément au modèle exécuté en vertu de la loi du 15 août 1795 par le graveur Augustin Dupré (1748-1833).

C'est la pièce française d’investissement en argent par excellence. Elle fut démonétisée par le décret du 20 février 1980. Les français l'ont largement thésaurisée, ce qui a permis au gouvernement français de gagner de l’argent. En effet, les pièces restées en circulation qui n’avaient plus de cours légal sont passées en solde créditeur dans le bilan de la Banque de France.

Les motifs sur la tranche en relief se rapportent respectivement à l'industrie : marteau, roue dentée et compas ; au commerce : balance, corne d'abondance et caducée ; à l'agriculture : gerbe de blé, coq et grappe de raisin.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Hercule affrontant le lion de Némée, peint par Francisco de Zurbarán (1598–1664) en 1634

+ AD 1978 - France - 50 Francs, dit « Hercule » - Cinquième République:

Open description in new window

This coin was sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was MS63. The grade that it received was MS66, which exceeded my expectation.

J'avais récupéré 8 de ces pièces (1 au millésime 1974, 1 au millésime 1976 et 6 au millésime 1977) que mes parents avaient thésaurisées. Elles ont contribué à déveloper ce projet, mais, probablement tristement, je ne les ai pas gardées. Celles-ci n'étaient pas en bon état de conservation. Cette pièce comble ce vide perceptible d'une certaine façon.

Les séries « Fleur de Coin » sont présentées dans un coffret dont la présentation a changé plusieurs fois au cours des années et depuis 1968, elles sont scellées hermétiquement sous plastique.

Elles ont contribué à déveloper ce projet, mais, probablement tristement, je ne les ai pas gardées. Celles-ci n'étaient pas en bon état de conservation. Population:

NGC: https://www.ngccoin.com/census/world/france-1870-to-date/sc-120/s50f/?c=504158&des=MS&grade=64
PCGS: https://www.pcgs.com/pop/detail/hercule-1974-1980/3157?sn=158119&p=MS&g=64

Edge: Incuse Pattern: | ★ ◆ 🔨 ◆ 🛞 ◆ 🧭 ◆ ★ | ★ ◆ ⚖️ ◆ 📯 ◆ 🝐 ◆ ★ | ★ ◆ 🌾 ◆ 🐓 ◆ 🍇 ◆ ★

Issuer: France Shape: Round
Value: 50 Diameter (mm): Expected: 41
Unit: Nouveau franc (1960-2001) Thickness (mm): 2.7
Mint: Pessac Mintage: 7,884,011
Mint mark: 📯 Emission period: 1974-1980
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS64 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Gad#882; F#427.5; KM#941.1
Varieties:

Il existe une variété principale pour le millésime 1974, un hybride qui présente le revers de la pièce de 20 Francs. La base de la gravure des personnages est légèrement plus large, le rameau d'olivier est positionné plus haut par rapport au niveau de la draperie, et la lettre L de « ÉGALITÉ » se trouve directement au dessus de la tête d'Hercule.

D'autres variétés existent avec les segments de la tranche inversés ou décalés.

Le millésime 1980 a été produit uniquement pour la série « Fleur de Coin » contenant des exemplaires numismatiques de l'ensemble des dix monnaies de ce millésime (50 Francs, 10 Francs, 5 Francs, 2 Francs, 1 Franc, 50 Centimes, 20 Centimes, 10 Centimes, 5 Centimes et 1 Centime). Les séries « Fleur de Coin » sont présentées dans un coffret dont la présentation a changé plusieurs fois au cours des années et depuis 1968, elles sont scellées hermétiquement sous plastique.
Note:

Cette espèce fut fabriquée suite au décret du 23 septembre et à l'arrêté du 8 novembre 1974, conformément au modèle exécuté en vertu de la loi du 15 août 1795 par le graveur Augustin Dupré (1748-1833).

C'est la pièce française d’investissement en argent par excellence. Elle fut démonétisée par le décret du 20 février 1980. Les français l'ont largement thésaurisée, ce qui a permis au gouvernement français de gagner de l’argent. En effet, les pièces restées en circulation qui n’avaient plus de cours légal sont passées en solde créditeur dans le bilan de la Banque de France.

Les motifs sur la tranche en relief se rapportent respectivement à l'industrie : marteau, roue dentée et compas ; au commerce : balance, corne d'abondance et caducée ; à l'agriculture : gerbe de blé, coq et grappe de raisin.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Hercule affrontant le lion de Némée, peint par Francisco de Zurbarán (1598–1664) en 1634

+ AD 1976 - France - 50 Francs, dit « Hercule » - Cinquième République:

Open description in new window
Period: Époque contemporaine ; République française (1792-1804 ; 1848-1852 ; 1870-Présent) ; Cinquième République (1958-Présent)
Ruler: Valéry Giscard d'Estaing (1974-1981)
Type: Regular issue; Collection thématique – Les 50 Francs, dit « Hercule » (1974-1980)
Obverse:

Design: Valeur faciale (50) et dénomination (FRANCS) en deux lignes, en dessous les différents d'atelier monétaire (une corne d'abondance) et du graveur (un dauphin) en ligne, le tout entouré d'une couronne composée à gauche d'une branche d'olivier et à droite d'une branche de chêne, nouées à leur base par un ruban, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) RÉPUBLIQUE FRANÇAISE★, avec le millésime entre deux points (· 1976 ·) sous la couronne à l'exergue
Traduction: République Française
Designer: Augustin Dupré (1748-1833)

Director: Pierre Dehaye (1962-1984)

Engraver: Émile Rousseau (1974-1994); Différent: dauphin
Reverse:

Design: Hercule barbu, demi-nu, debout de face avec la léonté, sur son épaule gauche une patte de lion, autour de la taille la peau de lion de Némée, unissant la Liberté à gauche tenant une pique surmontée d'un bonnet phrygien et l'Égalité à droite tenant dans sa main gauche un niveau, le tout sur une base, en dessous la signature du designer entre deux points (· Dupré ·) à l'exergue, le champ entouré d'un grènetis extérieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) (rameau d'olivier) LIBERTÉ ÉGALITÉ FRATERNITÉ
Traduction: Liberté Égalité Fraternité
Designer: Augustin Dupré (1748-1833)

Director: Pierre Dehaye (1962-1984)

Engraver: Émile Rousseau (1974-1994); Différent: dauphin
Features:

J'avais récupéré 8 de ces pièces (1 au millésime 1974, 1 au millésime 1976 et 6 au millésime 1977) que mes parents avaient thésaurisées. Elles ont contribué à déveloper ce projet, mais, probablement tristement, je ne les ai pas gardées. Celles-ci n'étaient pas en bon état de conservation. Cette pièce comble ce vide perceptible d'une certaine façon.

Population:

NGC: https://www.ngccoin.com/census/world/france-1870-to-date/sc-120/s50f/?c=504157&des=MS&grade=65
PCGS: https://www.pcgs.com/pop/detail/hercule-1974-1980/3157?sn=158118&p=MS&g=65

Edge: Incuse Pattern: | ★ ◆ 🔨 ◆ 🛞 ◆ 🧭 ◆ ★ | ★ ◆ ⚖️ ◆ 📯 ◆ 🝐 ◆ ★ | ★ ◆ 🌾 ◆ 🐓 ◆ 🍇 ◆ ★
Alignment: Coin (↑↓) Technique: Milled
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 1976 Fineness: 900
Country: France Weight (g): Expected: 30
Issuer: France Shape: Round
Value: 50 Diameter (mm): Expected: 41
Unit: Nouveau franc (1960-2001) Thickness (mm): 2.7
Mint: Pessac Mintage: 5,544,711
Mint mark: 📯 Emission period: 1974-1980
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS65 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Gad#882; F#427.4; KM#941.1
Varieties:

Il existe une variété principale pour le millésime 1974, un hybride qui présente le revers de la pièce de 20 Francs. La base de la gravure des personnages est légèrement plus large, le rameau d'olivier est positionné plus haut par rapport au niveau de la draperie, et la lettre L de « ÉGALITÉ » se trouve directement au dessus de la tête d'Hercule.

D'autres variétés existent avec les segments de la tranche inversés ou décalés.

Le millésime 1980 a été produit uniquement pour la série « Fleur de Coin » contenant des exemplaires numismatiques de l'ensemble des dix monnaies de ce millésime (50 Francs, 10 Francs, 5 Francs, 2 Francs, 1 Franc, 50 Centimes, 20 Centimes, 10 Centimes, 5 Centimes et 1 Centime). Les séries « Fleur de Coin » sont présentées dans un coffret dont la présentation a changé plusieurs fois au cours des années et depuis 1968, elles sont scellées hermétiquement sous plastique.
Note:

Cette espèce fut fabriquée suite au décret du 23 septembre et à l'arrêté du 8 novembre 1974, conformément au modèle exécuté en vertu de la loi du 15 août 1795 par le graveur Augustin Dupré (1748-1833).

C'est la pièce française d’investissement en argent par excellence. Elle fut démonétisée par le décret du 20 février 1980. Les français l'ont largement thésaurisée, ce qui a permis au gouvernement français de gagner de l’argent. En effet, les pièces restées en circulation qui n’avaient plus de cours légal sont passées en solde créditeur dans le bilan de la Banque de France.

Les motifs sur la tranche en relief se rapportent respectivement à l'industrie : marteau, roue dentée et compas ; au commerce : balance, corne d'abondance et caducée ; à l'agriculture : gerbe de blé, coq et grappe de raisin.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Hercule affrontant le lion de Némée, peint par Francisco de Zurbarán (1598–1664) en 1634

+ AD 1974 - France - 50 Francs, dit « Hercule » - Cinquième République:
