References: RIC4_3#116B; RCV3#9160; RSC4#63; Cohen5#63; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.116B; MRK#75.7
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the hippopotamus looks down (the most common; RSC4#63 and Cohen5#63) or up (the least common; RSC4#64 and Cohen5#64).
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

During the years 247 and 248 the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome included the following reverse inscriptions: "SAECLARES AVGG" (the age of the Two Emperors), "SAECVLVM NOVVM" (the new age) and "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" (the millenia). The "Saeculares" coinage is divided into two reverse series: the reverse animal series showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations) and the reverse architectural series illustrating either a hexastyle temple (containing a seated statue of Roma) (with the inscription "SAECVLVM NOVVM" for the denominations in gold and silver and the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for the denominations in bronze) or a cippus (column) (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations or the inscription "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" for the denominations in bronze). The reverse animal series shows at least eight different wild animals: a lion, a she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus), a gazelle, a European elk (moose), a hippopotamus, a stag, a goat (or hind), and an antelope. Struck in a wide range of denominations the series included the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Included also are issues of Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Philip (Il) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

The "Ludi Saeculares" (Secular Games) organised for the millennium of the foundation of Rome was highlighted by a splendid array of wild animals. These wild animals had originally been collected for the intended triumph of Gordian III in the Persian war, which saw his death and the associated proclamation of Philip (I) the Arab as emperor in 244. The animals were used by Philip (I) the Arab in magnificent displays and (slaughter) games put on in the key venues, like the Circus Maximus and the Colosseum. This large collection of exotic wild beasts included several specimens of antelope, elephant, European elk (moose), gazelle, giraffe, goat, hippopotamus, wild horse, hyena, leopard, lion, rhinoceros, stag, tiger and wild ass. It was these animals, collected for Gordian III, which, no doubt, inspired the many animal reverse types found on the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium of the foundation of Rome. Besides, the she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus) would have been recognised as the symbol of Rome rather than as a reminder of the games' arena.

A remarkable feature of this "Saeculares" coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced the "Saeculares" issue with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius) and are of much interest in that the eight animals illustrated on the reverse were divided among them with Officina I striking only the lion, II the lion and the she-wolf, III the gazelle and the European elk (moose), IV the hippopotamus, V the stag, and VI the goat (or hind) and the antelope. At almost the same time the same six officinae produced a different issue with marks as ancient Greek numerals Α to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Α, II/Β, V/Ε and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina III/Γ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, and Officina IV/Δ minted for Otacilia Severa.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcia) Otacilia Severa (born circa 220; given the title of Augusta in 244; died in or after 249)

(To the right) Bust of Otacilia Severa, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the Hall of the Machines of the Centrale Montemartini in Rome

Marcia Otacilia Severa married Philip (I) the Arab (circa 204-249; r. 244-249) in 234, though very little is known of the biographical details of her life. She may have been of noble Roman birth, as suggested by her name, though if so we can only speculate on how she came to mary the son of an Arab chieftain. She gave birth to their only son, Philip (II) the Younger, about 237 (that is about seven years before her husband's accession as Emperor) and was accorded the title of Augusta early in the reign in 244. She enjoyed a generous share of the imperial coinage, with one of the six officinae (workshops) of the Rome mint being assigned to the production of issues in her name. The Antioch mint also struck antoniniani for her, though these are by no means common. Otacilia's ultimate fate is shrouded in mystery. She was in Rome when her husband was defeated and killed at the Battle of Verona in 249 following a rebellion led by his successor, (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius. However, it is unclear whether she was murdered as their son Philip (II) the Younger by the Praetorians shortly after the death of her husband or merely permitted to live a private life in obscurity.

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (I) the Arab:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Philip (I) the Arab (244-249)
Type: Commemorative issue (Secular Games); Collection thématique – Célébrations du millénaire de la fondation de Rome en 247-248; La ménagerie
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, facing right, radiate, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type B")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) IMPPHILIPPVSAVG (IMP PHILIPPVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Philippus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Philippus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Stag walking right, on a base, the officina mark (V) below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) SAECVLARESAVGG (SAECVLARES AVGG)
Traduction: Secular Games of the Two Emperors (Augusti) (Saeculares Duorum Augustorum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was Ch AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5 or, more realistically, AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5. The grade that it received was Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5, which did not quite meet my expectation.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 01h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 248 (not dated) Fineness: 466
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.45; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 24; Expected: 23
Unit: Antoninianus (Reform of Caracalla; 215-301) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 248
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch XF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5 (NGC) Variety: Stag walking right
References: RIC4_3#19; RCV3#8958; RSC4#182; Cohen5#182; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.19; MRK#74.22.8
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the stag walks right (the most common; RIC4_3#19, RCV3#8958, RSC4#182, Cohen5#182, and MRK#74.22.8) or left (the least common; RIC4_3#20, RSC4#185, Cohen5#185, and MRK#74.22.7).
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

During the years 247 and 248 the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome included the following reverse inscriptions: "SAECLARES AVGG" (the age of the Two Emperors), "SAECVLVM NOVVM" (the new age) and "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" (the millenia). The "Saeculares" coinage is divided into two reverse series: the reverse animal series showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations) and the reverse architectural series illustrating either a hexastyle temple (containing a seated statue of Roma) (with the inscription "SAECVLVM NOVVM" for the denominations in gold and silver and the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for the denominations in bronze) or a cippus (column) (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations or the inscription "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" for the denominations in bronze). The reverse animal series shows at least eight different wild animals: a lion, a she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus), a gazelle, a European elk (moose), a hippopotamus, a stag, a goat (or hind), and an antelope. Struck in a wide range of denominations the series included the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Included also are issues of Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Philip (Il) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

The "Ludi Saeculares" (Secular Games) organised for the millennium of the foundation of Rome was highlighted by a splendid array of wild animals. These wild animals had originally been collected for the intended triumph of Gordian III in the Persian war, which saw his death and the associated proclamation of Philip (I) the Arab as emperor in 244. The animals were used by Philip (I) the Arab in magnificent displays and (slaughter) games put on in the key venues, like the Circus Maximus and the Colosseum. This large collection of exotic wild beasts included several specimens of antelope, elephant, European elk (moose), gazelle, giraffe, goat, hippopotamus, wild horse, hyena, leopard, lion, rhinoceros, stag, tiger and wild ass. It was these animals, collected for Gordian III, which, no doubt, inspired the many animal reverse types found on the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium of the foundation of Rome. Besides, the she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus) would have been recognised as the symbol of Rome rather than as a reminder of the games' arena.

A remarkable feature of this "Saeculares" coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced the "Saeculares" issue with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius) and are of much interest in that the eight animals illustrated on the reverse were divided among them with Officina I striking only the lion, II the lion and the she-wolf, III the gazelle and the European elk (moose), IV the hippopotamus, V the stag, and VI the goat (or hind) and the antelope. At almost the same time the same six officinae produced a different issue with marks as ancient Greek numerals Α to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Α, II/Β, V/Ε and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina III/Γ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, and Officina IV/Δ minted for Otacilia Severa.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Julius) Philippus (born circa 204; proclaimed emperor circa late February 244; died in September 249)

(To the right) Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg

Marcus Julius Philippus, a native of Arabia Trachonitis, was born about 204 and was the son of an Arab chieftain named Marinus (?-?) who had attained Roman equestrian rank. Philip (I) the Arab, as he became known, held a high command in the Roman army during the Persian campaign of his predecessor (Marcus Antonius) Gordianus (225-244; r. 238-244), known as Gordian III, and during the winter of 243-244 he became praetorian prefect in place of Gordian III's father-in-law (Gaius Furius Sabinius Aquila) Timesitheus (190-243), in whose sudden death he may have been implicated. It soon became clear that the new praetorian prefect had designs on the throne itself and he set about undermining the authority of the young Gordian III. By late February 244 he felt sufficiently secure to make his move and the unfortunate emperor was deposed by the army and put to death, Philip (I) the Arab being proclaimed in his place. Anxious to return to Rome as soon as possible he hastily negotiated a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Shapur I (?-270; r. circa 240-270) and assumed the title of "Persicus Maximus". His wife, (Marcia) Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was given the rank of Augusta and their young son, Philip (the Younger; about 237-249), became Caesar, both being granted a share in the imperial coinage. In further moves to strengthen the stability of his new dynasty Philip (I) the Arab appointed his brother (Gaius Julius) Priscus (?-?) to the governorship of Mesopotamia (later supreme commander in the East), and his father- (or brother-) in-law Severianus (?-?) to the governorship of Moesia. He even granted posthumous deification to his father Marinus and coins in honour of the new deity were struck at the recently established colony of Philippopolis in Arabia, probably the emperor's birthplace. Philip was back in Rome by the summer and received formal ratification of his accession from an obedient Senate. Much of the following two years was spent in campaigning on the northern frontier against the Dacian Carpi and the German Quadi and in 247 the emperor celebrated a triumph in Rome. The event was used as the setting for the further elevation of his son Philip (the Younger) to the status of Augustus and co-emperor. The following year magnificent games and other spectacles were staged in the capital in celebration of the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome and the occasion was marked by an extensive issue of coinage in all metals. This was to be the high-point of Philip (I) the Arab's reign. Later in the year serious revolts broke out in Moesia, where the uprising was headed by (Tiberius Claudius Marcus) Pacatianus (?-circa 248), known as Pacatian, and in Cappadocia and northern Syria, where (Marcus Fulvius Rufus) Jotapianus (?-circa 249), known as Jotapian, was proclaimed emperor. Although neither rebellion was successful they were enough to undermine confidence in Philip (I) the Arab's ability to rule. When he sent his general (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, to Moesia to settle the disturbed situation there the army proclaimed their commander emperor in his place. Although reputedly reluctant to accept the doubtful honour Decius nevertheless marched on Italy and met Philip (I) the Arab in battle at Verona. Philip (I) the Arab and his son Philip (II) the Younger were both killed in the disastrous defeat and Decius was left in uncontested possession of the imperial throne in September 249. The tradition has come down to us that Philip (I) the Arab had strong Christian sympathies. However, this may be due to nothing more than the stark contrast between his tolerant attitude in religious matters and the cruel persecutions of his successor, Decius.

The silver denarius, though still occasionally minted under Philip (I) the Arab, was no longer part of the regular monetary system and specimens today are of considerable rarity. It was replaced as the principal denomination by the antoninianus. Gold coinage was also much rarer than under Gordian III, but sestertii continued to be issued in large quantities. In addition to coinage in the name of Philip (I) the Arab himself, issues were made in the names of his son Philip (II) the Younger (as Caesar until 247, thereafter as Augustus) and his wife Otacilia Severa.

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (I) the Arab:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Philip (I) the Arab (244-249)
Type: Commemorative issue (Secular Games); Collection thématique – Célébrations du millénaire de la fondation de Rome en 247-248; La ménagerie
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, facing right, radiate, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type B")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) IMPPHILIPPVSAVG (IMP PHILIPPVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Philippus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Philippus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Antelope walking left, on a base, the officina mark (VI) below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) SAECVLARESAVGG (SAECVLARES AVGG)
Traduction: Secular Games of the Two Emperors (Augusti) (Saeculares Duorum Augustorum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was XF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5. The grade that it received was Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5, which exceeded my expectation.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 05h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 248 (not dated) Fineness: 466
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 4.78; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 26; Expected: 23
Unit: Antoninianus (Reform of Caracalla; 215-301) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 248
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Antelope walking left
References: RIC4_3#21; RCV3#8959; RSC4#189; Cohen5#189; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.21; MRK#74.22.9
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the antelope walks left (the most common; RIC4_3#21, RCV3#8959, RSC4#189, Cohen5#189, and MRK#74.22.9) or right (the least common; RIC4_3#22, RSC4#188, Cohen5#188, and MRK#74.22.10).
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

During the years 247 and 248 the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome included the following reverse inscriptions: "SAECLARES AVGG" (the age of the Two Emperors), "SAECVLVM NOVVM" (the new age) and "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" (the millenia). The "Saeculares" coinage is divided into two reverse series: the reverse animal series showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations) and the reverse architectural series illustrating either a hexastyle temple (containing a seated statue of Roma) (with the inscription "SAECVLVM NOVVM" for the denominations in gold and silver and the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for the denominations in bronze) or a cippus (column) (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations or the inscription "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" for the denominations in bronze). The reverse animal series shows at least eight different wild animals: a lion, a she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus), a gazelle, a European elk (moose), a hippopotamus, a stag, a goat (or hind), and an antelope. Struck in a wide range of denominations the series included the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Included also are issues of Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Philip (Il) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

The "Ludi Saeculares" (Secular Games) organised for the millennium of the foundation of Rome was highlighted by a splendid array of wild animals. These wild animals had originally been collected for the intended triumph of Gordian III in the Persian war, which saw his death and the associated proclamation of Philip (I) the Arab as emperor in 244. The animals were used by Philip (I) the Arab in magnificent displays and (slaughter) games put on in the key venues, like the Circus Maximus and the Colosseum. This large collection of exotic wild beasts included several specimens of antelope, elephant, European elk (moose), gazelle, giraffe, goat, hippopotamus, wild horse, hyena, leopard, lion, rhinoceros, stag, tiger and wild ass. It was these animals, collected for Gordian III, which, no doubt, inspired the many animal reverse types found on the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium of the foundation of Rome. Besides, the she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus) would have been recognised as the symbol of Rome rather than as a reminder of the games' arena.

A remarkable feature of this "Saeculares" coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced the "Saeculares" issue with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius) and are of much interest in that the eight animals illustrated on the reverse were divided among them with Officina I striking only the lion, II the lion and the she-wolf, III the gazelle and the European elk (moose), IV the hippopotamus, V the stag, and VI the goat (or hind) and the antelope. At almost the same time the same six officinae produced a different issue with marks as ancient Greek numerals Α to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Α, II/Β, V/Ε and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina III/Γ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, and Officina IV/Δ minted for Otacilia Severa.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Julius) Philippus (born circa 204; proclaimed emperor circa late February 244; died in September 249)

(To the right) Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg

Marcus Julius Philippus, a native of Arabia Trachonitis, was born about 204 and was the son of an Arab chieftain named Marinus (?-?) who had attained Roman equestrian rank. Philip (I) the Arab, as he became known, held a high command in the Roman army during the Persian campaign of his predecessor (Marcus Antonius) Gordianus (225-244; r. 238-244), known as Gordian III, and during the winter of 243-244 he became praetorian prefect in place of Gordian III's father-in-law (Gaius Furius Sabinius Aquila) Timesitheus (190-243), in whose sudden death he may have been implicated. It soon became clear that the new praetorian prefect had designs on the throne itself and he set about undermining the authority of the young Gordian III. By late February 244 he felt sufficiently secure to make his move and the unfortunate emperor was deposed by the army and put to death, Philip (I) the Arab being proclaimed in his place. Anxious to return to Rome as soon as possible he hastily negotiated a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Shapur I (?-270; r. circa 240-270) and assumed the title of "Persicus Maximus". His wife, (Marcia) Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was given the rank of Augusta and their young son, Philip (the Younger; about 237-249), became Caesar, both being granted a share in the imperial coinage. In further moves to strengthen the stability of his new dynasty Philip (I) the Arab appointed his brother (Gaius Julius) Priscus (?-?) to the governorship of Mesopotamia (later supreme commander in the East), and his father- (or brother-) in-law Severianus (?-?) to the governorship of Moesia. He even granted posthumous deification to his father Marinus and coins in honour of the new deity were struck at the recently established colony of Philippopolis in Arabia, probably the emperor's birthplace. Philip was back in Rome by the summer and received formal ratification of his accession from an obedient Senate. Much of the following two years was spent in campaigning on the northern frontier against the Dacian Carpi and the German Quadi and in 247 the emperor celebrated a triumph in Rome. The event was used as the setting for the further elevation of his son Philip (the Younger) to the status of Augustus and co-emperor. The following year magnificent games and other spectacles were staged in the capital in celebration of the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome and the occasion was marked by an extensive issue of coinage in all metals. This was to be the high-point of Philip (I) the Arab's reign. Later in the year serious revolts broke out in Moesia, where the uprising was headed by (Tiberius Claudius Marcus) Pacatianus (?-circa 248), known as Pacatian, and in Cappadocia and northern Syria, where (Marcus Fulvius Rufus) Jotapianus (?-circa 249), known as Jotapian, was proclaimed emperor. Although neither rebellion was successful they were enough to undermine confidence in Philip (I) the Arab's ability to rule. When he sent his general (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, to Moesia to settle the disturbed situation there the army proclaimed their commander emperor in his place. Although reputedly reluctant to accept the doubtful honour Decius nevertheless marched on Italy and met Philip (I) the Arab in battle at Verona. Philip (I) the Arab and his son Philip (II) the Younger were both killed in the disastrous defeat and Decius was left in uncontested possession of the imperial throne in September 249. The tradition has come down to us that Philip (I) the Arab had strong Christian sympathies. However, this may be due to nothing more than the stark contrast between his tolerant attitude in religious matters and the cruel persecutions of his successor, Decius.

The silver denarius, though still occasionally minted under Philip (I) the Arab, was no longer part of the regular monetary system and specimens today are of considerable rarity. It was replaced as the principal denomination by the antoninianus. Gold coinage was also much rarer than under Gordian III, but sestertii continued to be issued in large quantities. In addition to coinage in the name of Philip (I) the Arab himself, issues were made in the names of his son Philip (II) the Younger (as Caesar until 247, thereafter as Augustus) and his wife Otacilia Severa.

→ Collection thématique – Les ateliers monétaires romains en 247-248 :

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (I) the Arab:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Philip (I) the Arab (244-249)
Type: Regular issue; Collection thématique – Les ateliers monétaires romains en 247-248
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, facing right, radiate, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type B")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) IMPPHILIPPVSAVG (IMP PHILIPPVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Philippus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Philippus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Mars (Roman god of war) standing left, on a base, holding an olive branch in the right hand, resting the left hand on a shield, a spear propped against the left arm, the officina mark (Α) in the field to the left
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) PMTRPVCOSIIIPP (P M TR P COS III PP)
Traduction: Greatest of the Pontifices, holder of tribunician power, consul for the third time, father of the country (Pontifex Maximus, Tribunicia Potestate, Consul Tertium, Pater Patriae)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin will be sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expect it will receive is Ch AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. 🦓

This coin is a "gift" from my son Louis, my mother Geneviève, and my sister Marie, for Christmas 2025. 🦓🐝🦦
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (↺, 08h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 248 (not dated) Fineness: 466
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 4.04; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 23
Unit: Antoninianus (Reform of Caracalla; 215-301) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 248
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (CCN) Variety: None
References: RIC4_3#7; RCV3#8949; RSC4#145; Cohen5#145; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.7; MRK#74.19
Varieties:

None
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

A remarkable feature of Philip (I) the Arab's coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced at almost the same time in 248 the reverse animal series of the "Saeculares" issue, showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG"), with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius), and a different series of a different issue, more banal and following a familiar Greco-Roman iconographic tradition, with marks as ancient Greek numerals Α to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Both series were struck in a wide range of denominations, including the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Α, II/Β, V/Ε and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina IV/Δ minted for Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Officina III/Γ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Julius) Philippus (born circa 204; proclaimed emperor circa late February 244; died in September 249)

(To the right) Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg

Marcus Julius Philippus, a native of Arabia Trachonitis, was born about 204 and was the son of an Arab chieftain named Marinus (?-?) who had attained Roman equestrian rank. Philip (I) the Arab, as he became known, held a high command in the Roman army during the Persian campaign of his predecessor (Marcus Antonius) Gordianus (225-244; r. 238-244), known as Gordian III, and during the winter of 243-244 he became praetorian prefect in place of Gordian III's father-in-law (Gaius Furius Sabinius Aquila) Timesitheus (190-243), in whose sudden death he may have been implicated. It soon became clear that the new praetorian prefect had designs on the throne itself and he set about undermining the authority of the young Gordian III. By late February 244 he felt sufficiently secure to make his move and the unfortunate emperor was deposed by the army and put to death, Philip (I) the Arab being proclaimed in his place. Anxious to return to Rome as soon as possible he hastily negotiated a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Shapur I (?-270; r. circa 240-270) and assumed the title of "Persicus Maximus". His wife, (Marcia) Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was given the rank of Augusta and their young son, Philip (the Younger; about 237-249), became Caesar, both being granted a share in the imperial coinage. In further moves to strengthen the stability of his new dynasty Philip (I) the Arab appointed his brother (Gaius Julius) Priscus (?-?) to the governorship of Mesopotamia (later supreme commander in the East), and his father- (or brother-) in-law Severianus (?-?) to the governorship of Moesia. He even granted posthumous deification to his father Marinus and coins in honour of the new deity were struck at the recently established colony of Philippopolis in Arabia, probably the emperor's birthplace. Philip was back in Rome by the summer and received formal ratification of his accession from an obedient Senate. Much of the following two years was spent in campaigning on the northern frontier against the Dacian Carpi and the German Quadi and in 247 the emperor celebrated a triumph in Rome. The event was used as the setting for the further elevation of his son Philip (the Younger) to the status of Augustus and co-emperor. The following year magnificent games and other spectacles were staged in the capital in celebration of the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome and the occasion was marked by an extensive issue of coinage in all metals. This was to be the high-point of Philip (I) the Arab's reign. Later in the year serious revolts broke out in Moesia, where the uprising was headed by (Tiberius Claudius Marcus) Pacatianus (?-circa 248), known as Pacatian, and in Cappadocia and northern Syria, where (Marcus Fulvius Rufus) Jotapianus (?-circa 249), known as Jotapian, was proclaimed emperor. Although neither rebellion was successful they were enough to undermine confidence in Philip (I) the Arab's ability to rule. When he sent his general (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, to Moesia to settle the disturbed situation there the army proclaimed their commander emperor in his place. Although reputedly reluctant to accept the doubtful honour Decius nevertheless marched on Italy and met Philip (I) the Arab in battle at Verona. Philip (I) the Arab and his son Philip (II) the Younger were both killed in the disastrous defeat and Decius was left in uncontested possession of the imperial throne in September 249. The tradition has come down to us that Philip (I) the Arab had strong Christian sympathies. However, this may be due to nothing more than the stark contrast between his tolerant attitude in religious matters and the cruel persecutions of his successor, Decius.

The silver denarius, though still occasionally minted under Philip (I) the Arab, was no longer part of the regular monetary system and specimens today are of considerable rarity. It was replaced as the principal denomination by the antoninianus. Gold coinage was also much rarer than under Gordian III, but sestertii continued to be issued in large quantities. In addition to coinage in the name of Philip (I) the Arab himself, issues were made in the names of his son Philip (II) the Younger (as Caesar until 247, thereafter as Augustus) and his wife Otacilia Severa.

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (Il) the Younger, son of Philip (I) the Arab and Otacilia Severa:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Philip (I) the Arab (244-249)
Type: Regular issue; Collection thématique – Les ateliers monétaires romains en 247-248
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Philip (II) the Younger, facing right, radiate, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type B")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) IMPPHILIPPVSAVG (IMP PHILIPPVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Philippus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Philippus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Virtus (Roman personification of valour and bravery), in the guise of Mars (Roman god of war), naked, advancing right, on a base, holding a spear in the right hand and carrying a trophy over the left shoulder, the officina mark (Γ) in the field to the right
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) VIRTVSAVGG (VIRTVS AVGG)
Traduction: Virtue of the Two Emperors (Augusti) (Virtus Duorum Augustorum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

References: RIC4_3#223; RCV3#9277; RSC4#88; Cohen5#88; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.223; MRK#76.22
Varieties:

None
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

A remarkable feature of Philip (I) the Arab's coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced at almost the same time in 248 the reverse animal series of the "Saeculares" issue, showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG"), with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius), and a different series of a different issue, more banal and following a familiar Greco-Roman iconographic tradition, with marks as ancient Greek numerals Α to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Both series were struck in a wide range of denominations, including the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Α, II/Β, V/Ε and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina IV/Δ minted for Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Officina III/Γ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

Marcus Julius Severus Philippus (born about 237; given the title of Augustus in 247; died in 249)

(To the right) Bust of Philip (II) the Younger, sculpted by an unknown artist between 247 and 249, displayed in the Musée Saint-Raymond in Toulouse

Philip (II) the Younger, the son of Philip (I) the Arab (circa 204-249; r. 244-249) and Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was born about 237, that is about seven years before his father's accession as Emperor in 244. On his father's accession as Emperor in 244, he was immediately granted the junior imperial rank of Caesar and this he retained for the following three years. He seems to have accompanied his father during the campaigns of 245-247 against the Quadi and the Carpi on the northern frontier and on their return to Rome to celebrate a triumph the boy was rewarded by advancement to the rank of Augustus and co-emperor with his father. When their regime was threatened two years later in 249 by the revolt of (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, the father and son marched together against the usurper, only to perish in battle at Verona. An alternative version of the story is that Philip (II) the Younger survived the battle but was brought back to Rome where he was put to death by the Praetorians.

The coinage of Philip (II) the Younger is divided into two main groups, those issued berween 244 and 247, when he bore the title of Caesar, and those issued after his elevation to the rank of Augustus. The former are all from the mint of Rome, but after he became co-emperor with his father he also shared in the issue of antoniniani from the mint of Antioch. During this latter period he used the same obverse legends as his father and differentiation on some issues from the mint of Antioch may sometimes be confusing, though the younger features of his portrait are generally discernible. Like his mother, Philip (II) the Younger was assigned one of the six officinae (workshops) of the Rome mint to produce issues in his name.

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (I) the Arab:

Varieties:

None
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Julius) Philippus (born circa 204; proclaimed emperor circa late February 244; died in September 249)

(To the right) Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg

Marcus Julius Philippus, a native of Arabia Trachonitis, was born about 204 and was the son of an Arab chieftain named Marinus (?-?) who had attained Roman equestrian rank. Philip (I) the Arab, as he became known, held a high command in the Roman army during the Persian campaign of his predecessor (Marcus Antonius) Gordianus (225-244; r. 238-244), known as Gordian III, and during the winter of 243-244 he became praetorian prefect in place of Gordian III's father-in-law (Gaius Furius Sabinius Aquila) Timesitheus (190-243), in whose sudden death he may have been implicated. It soon became clear that the new praetorian prefect had designs on the throne itself and he set about undermining the authority of the young Gordian III. By late February 244 he felt sufficiently secure to make his move and the unfortunate emperor was deposed by the army and put to death, Philip (I) the Arab being proclaimed in his place. Anxious to return to Rome as soon as possible he hastily negotiated a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Shapur I (?-270; r. circa 240-270) and assumed the title of "Persicus Maximus". His wife, (Marcia) Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was given the rank of Augusta and their young son, Philip (the Younger; about 237-249), became Caesar, both being granted a share in the imperial coinage. This was to be the high-point of Philip (I) the Arab's reign. Later in the year serious revolts broke out in Moesia, where the uprising was headed by (Tiberius Claudius Marcus) Pacatianus (?-circa 248), known as Pacatian, and in Cappadocia and northern Syria, where (Marcus Fulvius Rufus) Jotapianus (?-circa 249), known as Jotapian, was proclaimed emperor. Although neither rebellion was successful they were enough to undermine confidence in Philip (I) the Arab's ability to rule. When he sent his general (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, to Moesia to settle the disturbed situation there the army proclaimed their commander emperor in his place. Although reputedly reluctant to accept the doubtful honour Decius nevertheless marched on Italy and met Philip (I) the Arab in battle at Verona.
